Beccaio, a butcher, a slaughterer. Becca in cauo, a fish whose gall heals

Beccarelli. Beccarocchi, a bird called a Woodpecker. Beccaria, a shambles, a

faulkon, taken for the passenger that will pray for hirselfe. Beccarsi il
ceruello, to bestow or study ones wit about any matter. Beccarsi il cuore, to
fret or gnawe the heart. Beccati su questa, crack me this nut. Swallow this

rammish. Becchina, a woman's quaint or priuities. Beccilo, weak, faint, tired,
feeble. Becco, the bill of a bird: a he goat, a bucke, a ram, a cuckold: the
beak of a ship. Beccodi oca, the herb wild Tansie or silver herb. Becco mal
guardato, a kind of Christmas game used in Italy. Beccone, a fool, an idiot,
a gull, a patch. Beccorella, Beccostorto, as Auosetta. Bechiche, a kind of
pills against the cough. Bechio, Folefoote, All-hose or Horsehoofe. Bid, the
white Thistle. Bedona, a kind of sarge or say. Bedollo, the Birch tree. Been,
wild Sage: some use it for Horsemint. Beffania, the Epiphanie: it is spoken in
mockery. Beffa, a flout, a scoff, a gibe, a frumpe, a jest, a mock. Beffana,
a bug-beare, a bull-begger, a scar-crowe, a toy to mock an ape. Beffare, to
flout, to scoff, to gibe, to frump, to jest, to mock. Beffardo, Beffatore, a
flouter, a scoffer, a frumper, a mocker. Beffeggiare, as Beffare.
Beffeggiatore, as Beffardo. Beffiare, as Beffare. Beffiardo, Beffiatore, as
Beffardo. Bega, a Be, an humble Be. Beghino, as Pinzocchero. Also a kind of
course graie cloth, religious or poor old men were wont to wear. Also used
for a bighin that our children wear. Belare, to bleate as a sheep. Belbello,
fair and softly, leasurely, fairlie. Beleno, a kind of fish. Beletta, as
Belletta. Belfegore, the name of a devil, a bugbeare, a cruel man. Belgimi, a
sweet drug called Benjamin. Belgioino, Belgini, as Belgimi. Belico, as Bilico.
Beliale, the devil, an apostata. Also a prophet. Belido pliniano, as Coppadi
Gioue. Belicato, having a navel or middle. Bella bellina, taken for a woman's
priuities or quaint. Belletta, claie, mire, dirt, a dead water, slime, bogge or
mud. Also a wheale or a pimple. Bellettare, to paint, to beautify, to make
fair. Also to deceive. Belletto, painting that women use for their faces. Also
a deceit. Bellezza, beauty, fairenes, comelines. Bellico, as Bilico. Bellico,
as Bellicoso. Bellico di venere, an herb so called. Bellicoso, warlike,
martial. Bellificare, to beautify. Bellino, pretty and fair: somewhat
fair. Bellirici, a kind of plum or prune. Bellis, the white Daisie. Bello,
fair, beautiful, well-fauoured, handsome, goodly, shene, comely, pretty.
Belloardo, Bellouardo, a bulwark, a blockhouse, a skonce, a forte, a ram^kin.
Bello in piazza, a cracker, a boaster, a vanter, great boast and small roste.
Bellor^, as Bellezza. Belta, Beltade, as Bellezza. Beltramo, fair, handsome
goodly. Beltresche, rampires to defend walls, scaffolds. Beltro, a mixed color
of green, white, and red. Belua, a wild beast or dreadful monster. Beluardo,
as Bellouardo. Beluedere, a place of a fair prospect, or a fair sight, an
herb called Topa regia in latin, which some take to be the toade flax, or
flax weed. Belzini, Belzoino, as Belgimi. Bembe, very well, go to, good
enough. Benaggia, well fare his heart, gods blessings be with him. Ben or been,
very well, well, go to, good, enough, wealth, much. Benandata, a farewell that
men give, or drinking penny given when men go away. Ben been, very well.
Benche, howbeit, although. Benda, a skarfe, a veil, a swathe, a fillet, a
hairelace, a bend in armorie. Also a hosegarter. Bendare, to enskarfe, to
swathe, to hoodwinke, to bend with a bend about, to blindfold. Bendella, a
fillet, a ribond, a tape, a little skarffe, a bandell, a swathe, a rowler.
Bendellare, to go staggering as dronken men do, to bandell, to enskarffe.
Benedicite, a grace before or after meat, a thanks-geuing, a blessing.
Benedicente, a well-speaking man. Benedicenza, a well-speaking, a blessing.
Benedire, to bless, to bliss. Benedittione, a blessing, a bliss. Benedetto,
blessed, happy, blist. Benefattore, a benefactor, doing good, or liberal to
do good deeds. Beneficare, to benefit, to benefice, to do a good turn unto.
Beneficiale, beneficial. Also of or pertaining to benefices. Beneficiare, as
Beneficare. Beneficenza, a benefit, a good deed, a good turn. Also
liberality. Beneficiario, he that receives a good turn. Also a pencioner, or
one that lives upon some annuitie, allowance, or exhibition. Beneficio, a
benefit, a good turn, a benefice, a good deed. Benefico, as Benefattore.
Been habbia, as Benaggia. Been merito, well deserving. Been spesso, very often,
very thick. Been stante, well to live, able, rich. Beneuolenza, benevolence,
or good will. Bengodi, as we say well fare your heart. Also a fained name of a
country where they say dogs run away with whole shoulders of mutton. Bent,
goods, wealth, chattell. Beni castrensi, goods gotten in war. Benignita,
benignity, gentleness, kindness, louingnes, goodness, bounty. Benigno, gentle,
kind, loving, benign, good, bountiful. Beninanza, as Benignita. Beniuolenza,
benevolence, or good will. Beniuolo, as Benigno. Ben parlante, well-speaking,
eloquent. Ben per tempo, early, or very timely. Benuenire, to well come home,
to welcome. Benuenuto, well come home, welcome. Benuenuta, a welcome, a welcome
home. Benuedere, to love, or view with a good will. Benueduto, well regarded,
well respected, well beloved. Benuoglienza, benevolence or good will.
Benuogliente, a good willer, well willing. Benuolere, to love, to affect, to
befriend. Benuoluto, well beloved, affected, regarded. Benna, a kind of
dungcart, or tumbrell. Bennola, a wad of straw or clouts to carry burdens
with upon the head. Also the stalk of a Cucumber. Beone, a careless, idle,
lazy, lo^tring fellow, an ale-knight, a tospot. Bera, a Drone, a Hornet, a
Humblebee. Berbena, the herb Veruein. Berberi, the tree or fruit we call
berberies. Berbici, all manner of sheep. Berbiciaro, a shepherd. Bear, beuo,
or beo, beuui, beuuto, to drink. Beretta, a cap or a bonet. Beretta da prete,
a priests cap. Also a broad leafed weed growing in the water as a dock leaf.
Berettare, to put on a cap, to cap one. Berettaro, a capper, a cap-maker.
Berettata, a capping. Berettina, a little cap or bonet. Berettino, a little
cap, a nightcap. Also gray or ash color. Berettone, a great cap or bonet, a
cap of maintenance as the Mayor of London has carried before him. Bergamotte, a
kind of excellent pears. Bergantino, a Brigandine, a Pinnace, a Foist, a
light boat. Berghinella, a gadding, idle, gossoping, abroad going, a tittle
tattle woman, an idle huswife. Berghinellare, to gad or go idly abroad a
gossoping from house to house as idle huswiues do. Bergola, a sheep that is
dizzie and staggers as she were drunk. Bergolo, a skullion, a drunkard, a
brabler, a wrangler, a common bareter, a beastly foolish fellow. Bergolare, to
brable, to wrangle, to skold, to prate, to loyter idly up and down.
Bergogliere, as Bergolo. Bergumella, a silly wretched woman. Berilla, the
herb water parslie, or yellow water cresses. Berillo, a precious stone called
a berill, in color like oil or seawater, a seawater stone. Berlengo, a
tippling or drinking house where all manner of riffraff company comes.
Berlesche, windows, drawing windows, out-bay windows, or skaffolds. Berli,
little bushes, locks, or tufts of hairs. Berlina, Berlino, a pillerie, or
cuckingstoole, heretofore called a tombrell. Berlingare, to prate, to prattle,
to chat, to skould, to rail. Berlincione, a fool, an idiote, a noddie.
Berlingaccio, the thursdaye before shrouesunday, when every man gives himself
to sport: so called in Florence. Berlinghiera, a prattling, railing, babbling,
skoulding woman. Berlingozzo, a kind of biscuit, simnell, or sugar bread, a
tansie of eggs, a dronken song, a threemens song* Also the wind or wezell pipe,
the name of a bird. Bernacche, the barnickles that grows upon the sides of
ships. Bernasso, a cloak with a hoode as shepherds wear, a thrumbed hat.
Bernia, an irish rug, or mantle, a rug, such as seamen wear. Berretta, a cap
or a bonet. Berrettare, as Berettare. Berrettaro, as Berettaro. Berricocoli,
apricocks. Also a kind of comfets or suckets. Berrina, larde. Also a larding
stick. Berrouiere, a catchpole or seriant. Bersaglio, a but or mark to shoot
at. Bersela, to swallowe a gudgeon: to pocket up any wrong, to believe any
tale. Berta, as Beffa, a bird called a Iai^. Berteggiare, as Beffare.
Berteggiatore, as Beffatore. Bertesche, as Beltresche. Bertolotto, a noddie, a
gull, a ninnie, a foolish shift. Bertonare, to love lecherously or secretly,
abusing married folks beds. Bertone, a married man's or wedded woman's secret
lover, leman, whore or adulterer. Bertonega, a kind of herb. Bertuccia,
Bertuccio, a pugge, a munkie, a marmoset, an ape. Bertuccione, a great munkie,
a babuine or ape. Berzagliare, to condemn, cast, judge, confine or limite. to
shoot at a mark. Berzaglio, as Bersaglio. Berze, the blew marks of any
stripe or beating, the prints of the lashes of a whip. Also used for long
shankes or stalking legs. Besegnini, a kind of ravenous sea foul. Besenfio,
swollen, puffed up, bladdered. Also pursie or broken winded. Bessaggine,
lisping, flutting, stammering, maffling, faltring in speech, foolishnes,
idiotisme. Besso, a fool, a gull, an idiot, a ninnie. Best, in latin Hyrium.
Bestemmia, a blasphemy, a curse. Bestemmiare, to blaspheme, to curse, to
banne, to swear and forswear. Bestemmiatore, a blaspemer, a curser, a banner.
Bestia, any kind of beast: it is taken for a man's privy parts, a bulls pizell.
Bestiaggine, as Bestialita. Bestiale, beastly, terrible, mad, foolish,
unreasonable, furious. Bestialita, beastlines, filthiness, madness, hugenes,
unreasonableness, beastlihead, brutishnes or rudenes. Bestiame, all kind of
cattle. Bestione, a great beast, a gull, a noddie, a fool, a patch. Betilo, a
kind of stone called in latin Betilus. Bettino, a page, a knauish wagge, a
halter sack. Bettola, a common drinking, d^ing, gaming, base ale house, a tap
house, a tippling house. Bettolare, to haunt ale houses, tippling houses, dicing
houses, to play the drunkard, to tipple, to quaffe or to gourmandise.
Bettoliere, Bettolante, a common dicer, a quaffer, a tipler, an ale knight.
Bettonica, the herb Betonie, Speedewell, Groundhale, or herb Fluellin.
Bettula, a kind of herb or tree. Betonica, as Bettonica. Betulo, the Birch
tree. Also as Ceraunia. Beua, a beauie. Beuacchiare, to tipple, to drink, to
sip, to swill, to bouze, to quaffe. Beuacchiatore, Beuacchione, a tipler, a
quaffer, a drunkard, an ale knight. Beuanda, a drink, a drench, a mashe, a
beuerage. Also a potion. Beueltutto, a tipler, a quaffer, a sound drinker, an
ale knight. Beuere, Beuo, Beuei, Beuuto, to drink, to quaffe, to tipple. Also
a drinking penie. Beueraggio, as Beuanda. Also a drinking penie. Beueratoio, a
workemans apron or bib. Also a watring place for cattle. Beuer la briglia,
when a horse draws up the bit with his tongue. Beuero, a beauer, a badger, a
graie whereof they make beauer hats. Also a poole, a pond or watring pit.
Beuerone, a drench or mashe for a horse; swilling for swine, a drunkard, or a
tospot. Beuicare, as Beuacchiare. Beuitore, Beuitrice, a drinker, a quaffer.
Bezar, Bezoar, a beazer stone. Bezzicare, to prick, to sting, to provoke, to
allure, to egg on. Bezzo, a small coin in Venice. Bezuca, an old monkie, an
ill-favored ape, a withered face. Biacca, a kind of white lead, called Ceruse.
Biaccare, to white, to dawbe, to paint with Ceruse. Biada, any kind of corn
or grain, any blade of corn. Also prouender for horses. Biadare, to feed or
prouender a horse. Biancare, to white, to whitten, to blanch. Biancaria, all
manner of naperie or white linen. Biancheggiante, whitish or drawing upon
white, blanching. Biancheggiare, as Biancare. Metaphorically it is taken to
rail at one secretly. Bianchetta, a blanket. Also some thing white.
Bianchetto, as Biacca. Also pretty and white. Also a fish called a Dace, a
Merlane, and of some a Menow. Bianchezza, whitenes, hoarines, palenes.
Bianchiccio, whitish, somewhat white, pale, wan or salow colored.
Bianchimento, a whitening, a blanching, a whitishnes. Bianciardo, as
Bianchiccio. Bianco, white, blanke, pale, wan, horie: the name of a worm
breeding in horses. also a disease in a horses knee or the ioints thereof. Some
take it to be a disease in a horses eye. Bianco del' occhio, the white of the
eye. Bianco del'uuouo, the white of an egg. Bianco mangiare, a kind of white
meat. Biancone, a goodly, great milkesappe, a fresh water soldier, a kind of
coin. Biancure, the monthly flowers that women have. Biaos, a tree with whose
leaves they cover their houses in India. Biasciare, to smack or smacker in
chawing, to mumble as a tooth^^sse old woman. Biasimare, Biasmare, to blame,
to condemn, to accuse, to reprove, to check, to taunte. Biasimabile,
Biasmabile, blamewoorthie. Biasimeuole, Biasmeuole, blamewoorthie. Biasimo,
Biasmo, blame or reproach. Biassare, as Biasciare. Biastemmiare, as Bestemmiare.
Biaua, as Biada. Biauo, a bright pale yellow color. Bibia, Bibbia, the Bible
or holy writ. Also the funnell or tunnell of a butte. Also the leese or dregs
of wine. Bibliopola, a Stationer or seller of books. Bibliotheca, a library or
study of books. Bica, Bicca, a heap, a huddle, a hay cock, a great mass, a
great deal, a rick, a stack, or houell of haie or corn: it is also taken for
anger or pepper in the nose. Montare su la Bica, to take pepper in the nose, to
be sore angry. Bichiacco, a smack or smackring with the tongue. Bichiacchie,
iestes, toys, frumps, flimflam tales, smackrings. Bicchiere, any kind of
drinking glass or beaker. Bicchieraro, a drinking glass maker. Bicchigno,
rammish, goatish, smelling of a goat. Bicchignolo, the socket of a
candlestick or lamp. Bicocca, a hamlet, a cottage, a little village.
Bicocche, the principal feathers of a hawk. Bicollo, a cowle-staffe to carry
behind and before with, as they use in Italy to carry two buckets at once.
Bicornia, a kind of bending anuile that goldsmiths use. Bicorporeo, that has
two bodies. Bidello, a beadle. Bidente, a pitch forke with two teeth, or having
two teeth. Bidetto, a little horse, a nagge, a tit, a little doing horse.
Bieco, squintie, sidelin, crooked, twart awrie. Bieco atto, an dishonest,
unlawful act. Biedone, the dregs of honey. Also the herb Blit or Blites, a
kind of Beet that has no sent. Bielletta, some stone or shell that Ichnemone
uses to kill the crokodill with. Biestemmia, as Bestemmia. Biestemmiare, as
Bestemmiare. Bieta, Bietole, the potherbe Beetes. Bietolone, a fool, a ninnie,
a gull, a meacocke. Bietta, a wedge to cleave wood with. Biettola, as Bettola.
Biffara, a fidle or croude. Biffaro, a fiddler, a crouder, a minstrell. Biffera,
ill, soul, duskie, gloomie weather, a whirlewind, a gust or berry of wind, a
contrariety of winds. Bifera, as Biffera. Bifida lingua, a cloven tongue, that
is cloven in two. Bifoglio, the herb Twaie-blade or Eifoile. Bifolca, a kind
of measure in Italy. Bifolco, a ploughman, a husbandman, a heardes-man.
Biforca, a forke, a pitchforke. Biforcato, or Biforcuto, that has two points
like a forke, forked. Biforcopiede, a cloven foot. Biforme, of two shapes or
forms. Bifronto, with two foreheads, bifronted. Bifulca, any land that is
twice ploughed. Biga, a tumbrell, a dung cart with two wheels. Bigamia, the
marriage of two wives. Bigamo, a man twice married. Bigatti, silke-wormes,
worms. Bigiaccio, a friars gray or sheep russet. Bigio, gray or russet
color. Also homespun cloth or sheep russet. Bigiocco, as Bizocco. Bigiuccia,
a kind of gray or clay color. Bigolo, as Bicollo. Bigoncia, a wine-measure in
Italy. a pulpit or a chair for a common speaker to speak or declaime in.
Bigonzolo, as Bicollo. Bilancia, a balance, or pair of scales. Bilanciare, to
balance, to weigh, to ponder, to consider. Bile, gall, anger, choler,
melancholy. Bilicare, as Bilanciare, Bilicato, having a navel, or middle.
Bilico, the navel of any body, the middle of any thing. Also a mill clapper.
Biligato, part of a wyer-drawers bench. Bilingue, a man that has two toongs or
languages. Bilta, as Bellezza. Bimba, a babe, a babie, a child, a puppie.
Bimembre, of two members or parts. Bimense, of two months. Bimole, of the age
of two years. Binangolo, having two angles or corners. Binare, to accompany
for good fellowship, to gather, to couple, to yoke together. Binato,
accompanied, gathered, coupled, or yoked together. Also twice borne. Bindella,
as Bendella. Bino, two and two, double, twofold. Binomio, that has two names.
Biocca, as Bicocca. Bioccole, locks or fleeces of wool. Bioccoloso, slovenly,
slavery, sluttish, snottie, sniuelie. Bionda, a kind of lie to wash and make
women's hairs yellow. Biondeggiante, shining yellow, or of the color of gold.
Biondeggiare, to make shine, or become yellow, or as the sun. Biondella, the
herb centorie so called, because washing ones head with it, it makes the
hears yellow. Also a goldenlockt wench, as we say a goldilocks. Biondello,
such a one as we call a gouldilock. Biondezza, yellownes of hairs. Bioua,
rain, or drizle. Bipalmo, two handfuls broad or long. Bipalio, a grubbing
axe. Bipara, that has brought forth twice. Bipartire, to divide in two parts.
Bipartito, divided in two parts, bipartite. Bipedale, two foot long, wide or
broad. Bipede, two footed, having two feet. Bipenne, Bipanne, a carpenters
axe that cuts on both sides, a twybill or twale. Also having two wings. Bircio,
I find used for Guercio. Bireme, a ship or gallie with two ranges of oars, or
two oars in a seat. Birettino, as Berettino. Biricuocoli, the fruit
apricocks. Biroldo, a kind of pudding, or haggas. Birra, the drink we call
beer. Birraria, places where knaves and serieants meet together. Also a
bru^house, a beerehouse. Birresco, rascally, or seriantlike. Birro, a serieant,
a catchpoale, a paritor. Birsa, the cheuerill skin to make purses with. Bisa,
a cold wind that brings a frost with it. Bisaccia, a wallet, a scrip, a bag.
Bisacuto, the herb toothpick, or cheruill. Bisanta, a kind of coin. Bisaua,
a great grandmother. Bisauo, Bisauolo, a great grandfather. Bisbigliare, to
whisper, to mutter, to buzze, to murmur. Bisbiglio, whispering, muttering,
buzzing. Bisbiglione, a murmurer, a whisprer, a mutterer. Biscacciare, to
waste, to spend riotously. Biscantare, to sing and sing again. Bischencho, a
jest, a knauish pranke, a mad trick. Bischeri, lute pins or pegs, or virginal
keys. A childs pillicocke or prick. Bischiccio, an agnomination or a
concordance of two words, as piu che un toro tira. Bisciere, a harrow, a rake.
Also a pin or peg of a lute: the key of a virginal. Also a childs hobbie
horse or stick to play with: a furner or a maulkin. Bischizzare, to draw the
first draught of any deed or writing. Also to agnominate or accord words
together. Bischizzoso ceruello, a fantastical, heteroclite wit. Biscia, a
snake, an adder. Bisciare, as Serpeggiare. Biscia scutaia, a tortoise. Biscia
scutelaia, a tortoise. Biscio, as Bigio. Bisco, slime, birdlime. Biscoso,
slimie, clammie. Biscottare, to bake, sees or roste twice. Biscottelli, a
kind of comfet or biscuit bread. Biscotto, biscuit. Also twice sod or roasted.
Biselli, young peason. Bisestare, to change as the leap year. Bisestile, the
leap year. Bisesto, the leap year, or one day added in four years.
Bisgiello, homespun cloth, sheep russet. Bisigare, to be busy or meddle
with any thing. Bisigarare, as Bisigare. Bislacco, a gull, a vain
lightheaded man. Bisleggiante, fair, handsome, pretty, sightly, goodly.
Bislingua, as Bonifacia. Bislongo, twice long, a slangrell. Bismalua, the weed
water mallows, or marsh mallows. Biso, a pease, as Bigio. Bisogna, a business,
an affair, a need. Also, it behooves, it is requisite, it is convenient.
Bisognare, to have need, to behooue, to want. Bisogneuole, needful, needy.
Bisogno, need, necessity, want. Bisognoso, needy, poor, distressed,
wanting. Bisolco, as Bifolco. Bisonte, a great beast like a horse in Polonia.
Bisonto, a filthy, greasy, slowenlie fellow. Bisuntone, as Bisonto. Bissa, as
Biscia. Bissino, a kind of fine silken stuff called bisse. Bisso, idem.
Bistentare, to languish, to pine, to linger. Bistento, languor, languishing,
pining. Bisticciarla con alcuno, to stand out to any thing stoutly, not to
yield or give one an inch of ground upon any controversy, to keep tacke with
one. Bisticcio, a bisticke or two verses. Also as Bischiccio. Bistorta, the
herb snakeweede, bistorte, oysterloite, or adderwort. Bistrattare, to misuse,
or abuse one, to evil entreat. Bisulco, cloven foot, forked. Bitontoni,
certain green figs. Bitorze, the swelling of a blow, bunches or swelling
knobs. Bitorzolare, to make, or go crooked, crankling, winding or turning in
and out. Bitorzolo, a crooked crankling in and out. Bitorzoluto, crabbed,
knottie, knobbie, ruffled, curled or clustrie. Also crooked crankling, winding
or turning in and out. Bittore, a foul called a Bitter. Bitumare, to bepitch,
to make clammie, to tar, to mortar. Bitume, lime, clay, pitch, tar, rosin,
or any such burning or sulphurous slimie or clammie thing. Bituro, Butiro,
butter. Biualuo, opening two ways, twofold. Also that has two, or double
scales, shells, or husks. Biuio, a way parting into two or on both sides. Biui,
a swallow. Biumbe, a kind of pipe, crowd or fiddle. Biuto, used for Beuuto,
drunk. Bizzaria, fantasticalnes, toyishnes, a foolish humor, rashness.
Bizzarire, to grow or become humorous, fantastical or toyish. Bizzarro,
fantastical, humorous, toyish, self conceited, a haire-brane. Bizzer,
heertofore used for Messere, master, sir. Bizzicare, to prick, to stinge, to
pinch. Bizzocca, a puritan dissembling woman. Bizzocco, a friar of the third
order of Saint Fraunces, but taken for a dissembling puritan. Bizzucche,
munkies, apes, pugs. Bladiseri, as Fiorecampese. Blandire, to flatter, to sooth
or smooth one, to blandish. Blandimenti, flatterings, allurings, soothings,
blandishments. Blanditie, as Blandimenti. Blando, flattering, alluring, blithe,
bonny, pleasant, buxome, gamesom, blandishing. Blatta, a little worm or fly
like a moth. Also a beetle or silk worm. Blatterare, to bleate as a lamb, to
clatter out of measure, to make a noise like a camel. Blattaria, the herb
called purple or moth-mullein. Bleconia, pudding grass or peny-royall. Bleso,
stammering or slutting, or lisping, or toong-tide. Boaccia, mud, mire, durte, a
quag mire. Boaccio, a kind of great beast like an ox. Boar, to go to bull as
a cow does, to bellow like an ox, to calue. Boarina, a bird which some take
for the siskin or titmouse. Boaro, an oxeheard or cow-heard. Boazzo, filthy
bull beef or a filthy ox. Boba, mud, mire or puddle. Bobolco, as Bisolco.
Boca, a sea fish that belloweth as a bull. Bocasia, a kind of wine made in
Sicilie like malmesie. Bocca, a mouth, the mouth or fall of any river or haven.
Bocca, look tirar di bocca. Boccadoro, golden mouth, taken for money. Bocca in
capo, a fish called in latin Callionimus. Boccale, a quart pot, a drinking
pot, a crewse, any kind of pot. Also an Ewer. Boccalaro, a pot maker, a potter.
Also a tipler, a tospot, a quaffer. Boccaletto, Boccaruolo, a little pot or
crewse. Boccalino, as Boccaletto. Boccarico, a tribute that is paid, so much
for every head or mouth. Boccasino, properly, such stuff as we call Buckram.
Also such stuff as we call Callimanco. Also a single garment for a woman. Some
have used it for fine Calico or lawne. Boccata, a mouth-full. Also a bucke of
clothes. Also a word used when one is about to tell a thing and knows not what
it is: or that a scholar would feign read his lesson and cannot, and that we by
some sign or voice will let him know that he is out, wide, and says he wots
not what. We use to say Boccata, as in English, yea in my other hose, or iump
as Germans'lips, you are as wise as Waltams calfe, and such other phrases.
Boce, has been used for Voce. Boccellato, a kind of fine biscuit bread.
Boccheggiare, to gape, to yawne, to make moes, to play or check with the mouth
as some ill horses do. Bocchetta, a little pretty mouth. Bocchetto, a posie
or nosegay of flowers. Bocchina, Bocchino, a little pretty mouth. Boccia, a

Also afore-right blow, a thrust over the dagger. Broccatello, thin tinsell, or

CA, as Casa. Cabacello, a kind of fish like a dace or a menow. Some have
taken it for a mullet. Cabala, Cabalia, a hidden science of heavenly and divine
mysteries professed by the Rabbis, a revelation of secret things Cabali, a
kind of beast in Samatra more hunted after than the Bezoar, for the bones of
it are most forcible to stanch bleeding. Cabalista, any professing Cabala.
Cabalistico, mysterious, cabalisticall. Cabarino, a gabardine, a frocke, an
Irish rug, a shepherds cloak or cassocke. Cabinetto, a cabinet, a closet, a
casket. Cabuccio, a cabbage. Cabuli, a tree, the fruit whereof eaten does cure
all manner of diseases, and is of much estimation in India. Cacabalde,
Cacabaldole, foolish, toyish, trifling shitten things or tricks, coggings and
foistings. As Fagiolata. Cacabo, the herb called Solano. Cacabre, a kind of
whitish stone. Cacafiori, a vain, selfe-conceited, others scorning
find-fault-foole. Cacafretta, a hasty fellow, a squirt, a laske, shitten
haste. Cacafuoco, a hot violent fellow, a shite-fire. Cacalia, as Cacalide.
Cacalide, wild Carowaies, or wild Cheruill. Cacaloro, the name of a bird.
Cacama, a kind of many colored stone. Cacamento, a shiting or a cacking, a
shitten toy. Cacamo, a kind of tree that yields a precious liquor. Cacao, a
fruit in India like unto an almo^d whereof they make a kind of wine.
Cacapensieri, a kind of croude, fiddle or kit. Also an idle, lazy, loytring,
careless or thoughtlesse fellow. Cacamusone, a foolish conceited gull, a fond
shitten fellow. Cacare, to shite, to cacke, to scummer. Cacarella, as
Cacaruola. Cacarelle, the trickles or dung of sheep, goats, rats or conies.
Cacaruola, the squirt, the laske or flixe. Cacarie, trifles, toys, vanities,
shitten tricks. Cacasangue, the bloody flixe or laske. Cacasotto, Cacasisotto,
a pisse-kitchin, always cowring by the fire: an idle flurt, a driggle-draggle,
a durtie slut: one that will beray hirselfe. Cacastraccie, a shite-rags, an
idle, l^zie, loobie fellow. A pinch penie, a niggard. Cacastecchi, a hard
chuffe, a shite-sticks, a niggard, a shitte^ fellow: dung or dirt. Cacatamente,
sneakingly, drawingly, fair and softly, faltringly, d^dgingly, shittenly.
Cacatoio, a privy, a iakes. Cacatreppola, a kind of thistle, teazell or such
pricking we^de. Cacauinci, as Cacauincigli. Cacauincigli, a base abject fellow,
a miserable wretch, an idle lubber. Cacazibetto, a fine perfumed effeminate
fellow. Caccherare, to cackle as a hen. Caccherelli, cacklings of hens. Also
eggs, as we say cockanegs. Cacchione, a prating smell-feast parasite. Cacchioni,
the first down or feathers of young birds. Caccia, a hunting, a chasing, a
driving, an expulsion, a fouling. Also a chase at tennis, a blot at tables.
Cacciacornacchie, a skar-crowe in a field. Also a kind of shot or piece of
ordinance. Cacciadiauoli, the herb Saint John's woort. Cacciafrusto, a kind of
sling. Cacciagione, hunting game. Caccialepre, an herb called Sowthistle.
Cacciamosche, a fan to put away flies. Caccianemico, a bragging craking
boaster, a bugbeare, a rawe-flesh and bloodie-bone. Cacciare, to hunt, to
drive, to chase, to banish, to expel, to drive forth or away, to lill, to
thrust forth. Cacciarcarote, to make one swallowe a gudgeon, to make one
believe the moon is made of green cheese. Cacciata, a chase, a chacing, a
banishment, a driving: a gudgeon or gull given to any man. Cacciatore, a
hunter, a chacer, a driuer, a huntsman, a woodman. Caccima, a bitch with
whelps. Caccole, Cacole, as Cacarelle. Case, a blot at tables, a chase at
tennis. Cacetico, as Bolso. Cachessia, an evil disposition or state of the
body, either by long sickness or bad diet. Cachetto, a man of ill disposition
of the body, one that nothing proves with, but pineth and consumes away.
Cachinare, to laugh immoderately, to pule, to cackle, to prattle. Cachino, a
prattling, a whining, a puling, a cackling. Also an immoderate foolish
laughter. Cacro, the mossinesse of the outward part of fruits. Cacoccia,
Cacozza, as Cacasotto. Cacochimia, ill digestion or ill juice in the body.

a precious stone that makes him conqueror that has it about him. Cacume, the
top or height of any thing. Cadaletto, a horse-litter or chair to carry one
in. Also a couch or little bed, also a beer for dead men. Cadauero, a

any kind of chain. Cadenaccio, a boult or bar of a door. Cadenacciare, to
boult or bar of a door. Cadenelle, little chains, chaine-lace or

declining, a low note. Cadere, cado, caddi, caduto, to fall, to decline.

a milk pan, a washing bowl, a charger, a platter, a broad dish. Cadmia,

medicinable. Cadmite, a precious stone having blewe specks about it. Cado, a
certain wine measure. Cadrega, a chair. Cadregaro, a chaire-maker.

Mercuries rod, a caducy, a white rod or wande that Heralds or messengers are

staggring. Caduco, falling, mal Caduco, the falling sickness. Also frail,
inconstante, momentarie, subject to fall, fading. Caduta, a fall, a falling, a
cheat, a winter fall. Caere, Caendo, used for Cercare. Caffettano, a cassocke,
a gabardine, a cloak or such like garment. Caffo, the number which we call od.
Also a kind of worms. Also the working, boiling or skum of new wine. Cafiso,
a kind of weight or measure. Caforchio, a clay pit, a lime pit. Also a cliffe,
a rock, a crag. Cafro, a cipher of nothing. Cagiana, a bird called a coote.
Cagionare, to occasion, to cause. Cagione, an occasion, a cause, a mean.
Cagioneuole, casual. Also weak, crased and feeble, defective. Caggia, let him
fall, that he may fall. Caglia, may care or take thought for. Cagliare, to crud
or congeale as milk does. Also to grow hard as a corn. Also to hold ones
peace. But it is taken from the Spanish. Cagliata, crudded milk. Caglio, a
crudding or congealing. Also a corn in a man's hand. Also rennet to make cheese
with. Cagna, a bitch. Also taken for sloth, idleness or lazy stretching,
sluggishnes. Also an interiection of swearing or denying a thing. Also a
dragging hook, a hook. Cagnaccia, a filthy currish bitch. Cagneggiare, to
play the dog or cur, to be currish. Cagnesco, dogged, doggish, currish.
Cagnetto, a puppie, a whelpe, a little dog. Cagnola, Cagnoletta, a little
bitch. Cagnolare, to whelpe or puppie as a bitch does. Cagnoletti, whelps,
little dogs, puppies. Cagnolino, as Cagnetto. Also a tool to draw teeth with.
Cagnotto, a sheapherds cur or whelpe. Caiandra, a tortoise, or a shell-crab.
Cai di latte, cream. Caie, a kind of ravenous sea bird. Calabrache, a game at
cards which we call laugh and lie down. Calabrone, a fly called a Beetle, a
Hornet. Calace, a precious stone, so called because it remains cold being
cast into the fire: it resembles hail. Calafate, a caulker of a ship, a
shipwright. Also a swabber in a ship. Calaia, a narrow lane or path, a passage,
a foord or ferrie over the water. Calalini, as Farfalla, as Pauiglioli.
Calamagio, as Calamaio. Calamaio, Calamaro, a fish called a sea-cut, or
cuttle-fish. Also a standish, or a pen and inkehorne. Calamandrina, an herb
called Betonie. Calamandrina palustre, water or garlike Germander. Calamenta,
an herb called bush calamint, or hoare calamint: another kind called wild
penniroyall, or nip calamint. Calamistro, an iron that women use to curle and
frizle their hairs with, a crisping wire. Calamita, the adamant stone.
Calamita, calamity, misery. Calamitoso, miserable, poor, needy,
unfortunate. Calamo, a cane or reed, a writing pen. Also an arrow or shaft. a
kind of measure used of yore in Greece. Calandario, an Almanacke, a Calendar.
Calandra, a woodlarke, or a bunting. Calandrelli, wooden shoes, wooden
pattens. Also buntings. Calandrino, a Goldfinch. Also taken for a gull, a
ninnie, or simple fellow. Calappiare, to take by deceit in a trap or cage, as
fishes and birds are. Calappio, a basket, a pannier, a cage of twigs, a trap, a
fishing cage with a narrow mouth. Calare, to diminish, to fall, to stoop, to
descend, to strike sails, to abate, to fall as the tide, to wane as the moon,
to abate or bate in price, to descend a pair of stairs, to stoop from aloft,
to come down from on high, to veil bonet, to stoop to a lure as a hawk, to
welke. Calata, a falling note. Also a fit of mirth. Also a trap door, a
descending. Calatabelletta, as Cacasotto. Calatide, a kind of tree. Calatura,
as Calo. Calaurita, the north pole, Vrsa mayor. Calaurone, a hornet, a beetle.
Calca, a crowde, a press, a throng, a thrust. Also as Calta. Calcagnare, to
dodge, to cog, to wrangle, to cavil, to streeke with ouerheeles. Calcagnaria,
dodging, wrangling, a cauelling. Calcagno, a heel of a man. Calcagnolo, a
term of founders, and is some part of a piece of ordinance. Calcara, a
lime-kill. Calcare, to crowde, to press, to throng, to thrust, to stamp, to
tread, to kick. Calcarello, a lime-maker. Calcatoio, a stick to ram the powder
into a cannon, a rammer. Calcatrippa, Star-thistle, or Saint Barnabaes thistle.
Calce, a kick, a blow with the foot, a wincing blow. Also a vanplate, the
iron about a tilting-staffe near the hand. Also the big end of a lance or
staff. Also hosen, breeches, sl^ps, stockings. Also lyme. Also the heelebone
of a man's leg. Calcecumia, as Calcimia. Calce vergine, unslaked lyme.
Calcedonio, a precious stone called a chalcidonie. Calcese, the nether part of
the mast of a ship. Calcestre, any stone good to build or make lyme withal.
Calcette, hosen, or nether stockings, or shinners. Calcetti, linen socks, by
a metaphore a narrow passage, pinch or straight. Calchi, rogues, crosbiters,
vprightmen, vagabonds. Calcia, any kind of hose. Calciamento, any kind of
hosing or shooing. Calciante, befitting, meete-for, agreeing with, squaring in
proportion, fit. Calciapiade, a shooinghorne. Calciare, to put on hosen, or
shoes. Also to fit, to agree, or square in proportion. Also hosen or shoes.
Calciaio, a shoemaker. Also a hosier. Calciatoio, a shooing horn. Calciette,
as Calcette. Calcidonio, as Calcedonio. Calcie, hosen. Also taken for shoes.
Calcifraga, the weed or herb called Sampeere, growing upon rocks by the sea
side. Calcimia, a word used of alchimists for calcination. Also a kind or part
of alchimie, or transmutation. Calcina, lyme. Also loame or mortar.
Calcinaccio, all manner of rubbish of broken walls, the rugged or stony mute

calcinate, to mortar, to loame, to lyme, to glase earthen pots within.
Calcinato, calcinated, mortred, loamed, glased. Also as Calcinaccio.
Calcinatione, a calcination, or a mortering. Calcinatoio, a lyme-kill.
Calcinetti, a kind of little fish. Some take it for a shell fish. Calcio, a
kick, a yerke, a wincing blow with ones foot. Also lyme. Calcioni, great
breeches, hosen, slops. Also boote-hosen. Calcite, the stone whereof brass is
tried. Also red vitrioll. Also a kind of fish. Calcitrante, kicking, yarking,
wincing, stubborn, froward. Calcitrare, to kick, to wince, to yarke, to
spurn, to sling, to be stubborn. Calco, a dresser, or dressing-boord in a

Calcole, the tredles of a weauer. Also knobs or corns in ones hands or feet.

calculation, a computation. Calda, a heating, a flaming, a skalding. Also hot,
proud, lecherous, or salt as a bitch. Caldacci, soultrie, filthy, faint,
burning, skalding heates. Caldaia, Caldara, a caudron, a kettle, a bruers lead

temperate heat or warmth. Caldo, hot, warm, earnest, violent: also warmth, or
heat. Cale, he cares for, or takes care. Calea, as Solatro. Also dogs
grass. Calefare, Calefacere, to warm, to heat, to chafe. Caleffare, to mock,

Calenzuolo, a kind of little singing bird. Caleselle, foolish, mimik, apish,

will make it freese. Calidita, heat or warmth. Calido, hot or warm in

smouldring of a chi^ney, darkness, miste or duskishnes. Caligo, as Caligine.
Caligoso, a tree that every morning is so full of fog and mist, that it
distills so much water, that the people and cattle of many countries in India
have no other water to drink. Calimana, a kind of Apple in Italy. Calisoni,
a kind of comfets so called. Calistefano, a kind of wild Olive tree.
Calliuola, a narrow little pathe, way or causey. Call, Callaia, a causey, a
pathe, a high way, a narrow lane, a beaten wait or trod. A habit or custom
that a man cannot leave. A braunie flesh or corn growing in men's hands or
feet. Callionimo, a fish whose gall heals scars of wounds. Callire, callo,
callito, to grow hard or brawnie as a corn. Callitrico, a kind of Ape in
AEthiopia. Callo, as Call. Also the fastening of an Oyster shell. Calloso,
brawnie, hard, knobbie with labor, full of corns, having a thick skin.

woman's breast, sour curded milk. Callostro, the shrub we call Priuet or Prime
printe. Calma, a calm or fair weather. Also calm or quiet. Also a branch, a
twig, a sprig, a graft, a sien^, a set, a plant. Calmare, to graffe, to
engraffe, to calm. Calmazza, a kind of Peasant-powte. Some take it for a
Bustard. Calmei, such as speak the rogues language or pedlars French. Calmo,
calm, quiet, peaceable, mild or flexible, and gentle: also as Calma. Calmone,
the roguish language, pedlers French or gibrish. Calo, the diminishing, loss,
abatement or defalking of any thing. Calonica, Calonaca; the chief chapel in
a Church, a queere of a Church, the chancell of a Church. Also a c^ster.
Calonico, as Canonico. Calonicato, as Canonicato. Calonio, a fish that has his
scales contrary to others, and swimmeth against the tide or course of the
water. Calore, heat or warmth. Calorifico, Caloroso, full of heat or warmth.
Calorite, a green stone which set in iron and worn about one, is good against
magic and charms. Calpestare, to trample or tread under foot. Calpestio, a
trampling noise, a pathe or high common way. Calta, the flower Marigold or
brave Bassinet. Also a kind of Violet that comes in Autumn. Calterito, used
for Scaltrito. Caluaria, baldnes. Caluaria, the head or skull of a dead body.
Calueggiare, to become balde. Caluezza, baldnes. Caluire, to become bald.
Caluitie, Caluitio, baldnes. Calunnia, a false or crafty accusation, a forged
crime, a malicious surmise, cavil or detraction to slander or trouble one.
Calunniare, to accuse or lay to ones charge falsely and maliciously.
Calunniatore, a malicious detracter or deceitful accuser. Calunnioso, always
ready to accuse or forge crimes falsely, full of deceitful interpretations,
false, unjust, cauillous. Caluo, bald on the head. Calza, as Calcia.

Calzoppare, to hop, to skip, to go a false gallop. Calzoppo, hoppingly, roundly
away, a false gallop, skippingly. Camaglio, a gorget of maile. Camaldole, a

Zingana. Cambiare, to exchange, to change. Cambiatore, an exchanger, a changer.

liew or place. Cambrai, cambricke cloth, named of the town where much is made

or cockles. Camecisso, some take it for Hare-hoofe: some for ground Iuie, and

poetical song. Camera, a chamber or lodging: the chamber of a piece of
ordinance. Camera locanda, a hiring chamber. Camera terrena, a low chamber

or surprise in time of war, so called because it is done and executed with
shirts over the soldiers armor, a camisado. Camiscio, as Camiscia.
Camiscione, a porters frocke, a body cote or great shirt. Camisciotto, as

to the fields, fieldie. Campagna, a field or a champaine. Campagna rasa, a
razed plain, an open field without any hedge, ditch or other encumbrance.

birdweede. Campana a martello, to ring the bells backward as they use in Italy

a volta, is when the broad end of the campanell is compass like a cannon

Camuffo, a man out of countenance, having lost his speech for shame, or else
made a fool or a gull, and then laughed at by others. Camurra, as Camorra.

called Cantharides. Cantarini, such as sing three men's songs, common begging
singers. Cantarino, Look oro cantarino. Cantaro, as Cantharo. Cantaro, as
Cantharo. Cantaro forfori, Cantarozeroi, a weight called a kintall. Cantatore,
a singer, a chanter. Canterella, as Cantarella. Canteria, a chantrie. Cantharo,
or Canthero, a fish endued with great chastity as the turtle is, having an
unsavory taste. Also a beast whereof there is no female, a black beetle. Also a
kind of boat. Also a ring or hammer to knock at a door. Also a weight called
a kintall. Also a kind of measure of dry things. Also a tankard or iug that
houldeth much. Also a close stool. Cantiere, a tool with a vice in it that
ioyners use. Also a chanter. Cantilena, a ballad, a tale, a report, a flim-flam
discourse. Cantina, a seller, a butterie. Cantinaro, as Canouaro. Cantinbanco,
a mountibanke, a ballad-singer. Canto, a song, a singing, a sonet, the treble
string of an instrument. Also a side. Cantonare, to cozen, to deceive, to
conycatch, to give one the slip at a corner. Also to canton. Cantonato, a
conycatching trick, a corner of a house or street, a meeting at a corner.
Cantone, a corner, a nooke, a canton, an angle. Cantoniere, a cozener, a
conycatcher, a deceiuer, an affronter. Cantore, a chanter, a singer. Cantuccio,
Cantoncino, a little corner. Canudo, a fish called in latin Alphestus, or
Cynaedus. Canuolo, a bobbin to wind silk upon. Also the quill of a spinning
wheel. Canuto, hoarie-white. Canutezza, hoarines. Canzelleria, a Chancerie.
Canzelliere, a Chancellor. Canzona, Canzone, a song, a canzonet, a ballad, a
dittie, a lay, a roundelay, a virelaye. Canzonare, to sing, to chaunt, to make
songs, to write songs and sonets. Canzoniere, a maker or writer, or singer of
songs. Caos, as Chaos. Caosi, a kind of ravenous sea-foule. Caostelli, a kind
of fish. Capa, a kind of wild, black, hairie beast bigger then an ass
breeding in India. Capace, capable, ample, large, or able to receive or
contain. Capacita, capacity, amplenes, ablenes to receive and contain.
Capale, a gorget or piece of armor for the neck. It is also taken for a
skull. Capanna, a cottage, a bullie, a cabin, a cell. Capanella, a little
homely cottage, bullie, cabin, or cell, a stack or houell of bushes. Capanello,
a stake whereat malefactors be tide to be burnt. Capanetto, a kind of call,
pipe, or net for to catch birds. Also as Capanella. Capano, Capanotto, a poor
homely shepherds cloak, or such upper garment. Capanuccia, as Capanella.
Caparbio, froward, stubborn, headestrong, stiffenecked, wilful, obstinate,
humorous. Caparbita, frowardnes, stubbornes, obstinacy, fond selfe-conceite,
testines. Capare, to take, to lay hold or seize upon. Caparra, an earnest
penny given in hand upon any bargain. Caparrare, to lay, give, or leave
earnest upon any bargain. Caparrone, a pugge, an ape, a munkie, a babuine, a
gull, a ninnie, a mome, a sot. Capassone, a nickname as we say a ioulthead, a
gull, a loggarhead, a mome. Cape, it contains or it is capable of. Capecchio,
course hurds of hemp or flax, course towe. Also a hempen halter. Capeccina,
that part of a yoke that goes about an oxes neck. Capeccio, as Capecchio.
Capeccione, the name of a farriers tool. Also as Cauezzana. Capegli, as
Capelli. Capella, a chapel, a little church. Capellaccio, a filthy great
broad hat. Capellania, a chaplain-ship. Capellano, a chaplain. Capelletto, a
chaplet, a little hat, a hanks hood, the labell of a letter. Also the husk of
any fruit that is not altogether close as of the hasell nut. Also a little
tuffe upon a peacocks head. Also a kind of disease about a horses knee.
Capelli, Capei, the hairs of a man or woman. Also hats. Capelli di venere, the
herb Maidenhaire, Venus-haire, or our Ladieshaire. Capelli, ricci, crespi,
inannellati, curled, frizled or crisped hairs. Capellina, a little chapple.
Also a bush or lock of hair before. Also a little hat that women use to wear
in their houses in Italy. Also a kind of lark with a bushe or tuffe on his
head. Also the foreskin of a man's priuities. Capello, a hat, a hood, a hawks
hoode, the dignity of a cardinal. Also a hair. Also a cover of a Still or
Limbecke. Also as Boccata. It is also taken for a check, a taunt, a rating of
one with authority, Fare un capello ad vno, to give a check or rating to one.
Capelluta, a lark with a tuffe on his head. Capelluto, hooded, covered,
hatted, hairy, or full of hairs. Capeluenere, as Capelli di venere. Capere,
Capio, Capei, Caputo, as Capire. Capestrare, to hang or tie with a rope or a
halter. Capestrarie, knaueries, villenies, raskallie or gallows tricks.
Capestratura prima, the first haltring of a coult when he is first taken up.
Capestrature, hurts or gals in horses legs. Capestro, a rope, a halter, a
headstall. Also a wag, a halter-sack or gallowes-clapper. Also a shoomakers
strap. Capeuole, capable, able to contain. Capezza, as Cauezza. Capezzale, a
bolster for a bed. Capezzadi moro, black like a moore, cole black. Capezzolo,
the nipple of a woman's breast. Also a stalk, a stale, or a stem. Capide, a
kind of little Persian measure. Capidieci, a kind of magistrate in Venice.
Capifosso, as Caponegro. Capidio, Capidolio, a kind of great whalefish, or
hurlepoole. Capigliare, to dress, to tresse, to plaite, to curle, to frizle,
to lace, to tie up hairs. Capigliata, the fore-lock of a man or woman's head.
Also hairie. Capigliuto, a man that has good store of hair on his head.
Capidoglio, the fish called a whale. Capifogli, the herb woodbine, bearing
the honnie-suckle. Capifuochi, andirons, rangers, or racks for a chimnie,
brandirons. Capifuori, as Capifuochi. Capillato, hairie, having hairs on his
head. Capillare, the name of a vain in any body. Also the herb called
maidenhaire. Capillatura, the hair of any man's head. Capimaestro, a chief
workman, a suruayer or controuler of others. Capinero, a kind of little
singing bird. Capio, the sliding of a knot. Capire, Capisco, Capito, to
contain, to conceive, or be capable of, to take, to hold, to receive.
Capiromante, a diuiner by looking-glasses. Capirota, a kind of dainty potage
or sauce used in Italy. Capistorico, the staggers in a horse. Capitale,
capital, chief, mortal, principal. Also a man's wealth, goods, worth, or
stock. Capitana, the admiral ship of a fleet or navy. Capitanato, a
captaine-ship, the place or dignity of a captain, a government. Capitano, a
captain, a chiefetaine, a leader, a chief. Capitare, to come, to happen, to
chance, to fall, or light to any place by fortune. Capite, a kind of white
stone. Capitello, the head of any pillar, a little head, a nipple of a woman's
breast. Also frets in any roof, or knobs in any work. Capitolare, to
capitulate, to covenant, to condition. Capitolatione, a capitulation,
condition, or covenant. Capitolo, a chapter. Also a meeting place for any
society, a convocation house. Capitomolo, a tombling trick, or cast, a
downfall. Capitone, a kind of course silk called sleaue silk. Also a fish
called a cur, a gull, a bull-head, or a millers thumb. Capitoni, as
Capifuochi. Capitonzo, an Item with a great letter, or beginning of a chapter.

Capitolo. Capituto, a loggar-head, a ioult-head, a great-headed fellow.

smoke, and fumes. Capo, Cao, a chief, a head, a leader. Also a pate, a nole, a
skonce: a cloue of garlike: an end or beginning: a chiefetaine or principal: a
cape or but of any lands end. Also a fish called a cur, a gull, a bulhead, or a
millers thumb. Capocaccia, a master hunter, a chief hunts-man. Capocchia,
the foreskin or prepuce of a man's privy member. Capocchio, a doult, a noddie,
a loggarhead, a foolish pate, a shallow skonce. Capocerro, the staggers in a
horse or other beast. Capo d'angolo, a chief corner stone. Capo d'anno, the
years end. Capo di latte, the cream of milk. Also clouted cream. Capo di
squadra, a ringleader, a chief, a head master. Capofronte, the forefront of
a horse. Capogatto, a kind of foul evil or falling sickness in a horse. Some
conster it to be a swelling over all the horse head, possessing the eyes, the
throat, and all parts, so as for the time he can receive no food. Capogirli,
foolish, fantastical, sudden, humorous toys, fancies or conceits, giddines
in the head, or qualmes over the stomach. Capoletto, the testerne, or canapie,
or head of a bead, a sparuise or vallance of a bed. Capolino, a little head or
pate. Capolo, a certain instrument about a plough. Caponara, Caponera, a
coope, a pen or cage for capons or poultrie. Caponato, Caponiera, a poultrer,
or seller of poultrie. Caponato, guelded, caponed, splaide, libd. Capone, a
capon. Also a kind of shellfish. Also one that is guelded. Caponegro, a
titlin, a titmouse, or an oxeye. Capoparte, a ringleader, a head or chief of a
faction, or side. Caporale, an officer in a band of men, called a Corporal.
Caporione, a Marshall of a camp, a Corporal of the field, a Iealour, a
Sheriff, a Justice. Capotorto, a bird called a wrynecke. Some take it for a
hickway. Capotto, as Cappotto. Capostorno, the staggers in a horse or other
beast. Cappa, a cape, a cape-cloke, a spanish cloak, the shell of any fish.
Also a kind of veil that women wear about their heads in Italy. Also an
angle, a canton, or a pile in a coat of arms. Also a coape for a priest.

paireawinkles. Capparole, a kind of little cockles, or winkles. Capparone, a

capes, all manner of shellfish, as oysters, cockles, muscles, or scallops.

marks upon the playing cards called spades. Capperone, a hood, frocke or

for sallets, called caperons. Capperuccia, a poor silly cloak or such
gabardine. Cappesante, as Cappelonghe. Cappetonde, a kind of round cockles or
such shell fish. Cappi, the claws of any crab-fish. The knots or steps that be
upon the cords or shrouds of a ship, by which mariners climb up, sliding
knots. Cappio, a snare, a ginne, a spring to catch birds with, a sliding knot.
legata a Cappio, is a joint in the middle of a port or vpset of a horses bit,

scorridore, a sliding knot in a cord, which being drawn will shut and open.
Cappocchio, as Capocchia or Capocchio. Capponara, as Caponara. Cappone, as
Capone. Cappotto, a short Dutch cloak, a Spanish cape cloak, a hood or a coule.

cowle. Capra, a goat in general. A kind of rack or torture to make one
confess. Capragina, goats Rue or Italian fitch. Capraio, a goat heard, a

goats milk. Capricciare, to grow or be humorous, toish or fantastical.
Cappriccio, a sudden toie, a self conceit, a fantastical humor. Also a
chilling cold. Capriccioso, toysh, humorous, fantastical, conceited, wavering
in mind. Capricorno, one of the twelve signs in heaven, called Capricornus, a
beast bodied like a stag, and footed and horned like a goat. Caprificatione, a
seeking of that which may not be. Caprifico, a wild Fig tree, or wild Fig
that will never be ripe. Caprifoglio, Woodbinde or Honysuckle. Caprigno,
Caprino, goatish, rammish, wild, humorous, lecherous. Capri mulgo, a bird or
skrich owl, that in the night sucketh the goats vdders. Also a milker of

da^cing A faune, a kid, a calue of a hind, a young hind, a capriole, a sault

the head of a hat without the brims. Caputo, a kind of sea fish. Cara, a kind
of herb in India, which mingled with milk makes a kind of bread.
Carabattola, a box wherein a shoemaker keeps all his implements, with what

Italy. Carattero, a character. Carattero, a carter. Carato, the touch or
resining, or loye of gold: a weight or degree called a caract. Caratto, a violl
of glass. Also a certain fee which every man paies in Venice to Saint Mark
that obtaines any suite by law. Paying so much the hundred, it is called in
Rome la Sportula. Caraua, a knot, a pack, a rout or crew of knaves. Carauana,
a carauan: properly a company of men and horses marching together, as they use
to travel in Egypt with camels. Carauella, a kind of ship called a carauell.
Also a kind of pear so called in Italy. Carbonaia, a cole-pit or place where
coals are made. Carbonare, to besmeare as black as coals, to besmother.

called a Carbuncle: an infirmity so called: a blaine, a pock, a plague sore, a
bile, a botch, a swelling in any part of the body. Also a little cole. Carbone,
any kind of cole: a carbuncle. Carbone aquatico, a cormorant. Carbone di

for arrows. Carcassone, a kind of course stuff so called, whereof sailers

cardinalship. Cardinalesimo, the order and function of cardinals. Cardine, the
hinge or hook of a door. Cardine del cielo, heavens axle tree. Cardini del
mondo, the four corners of the world. Cardo, any kind of Hartichock or
Thistle or Teazell. Cardoino, a goldfinch. Cardo santo, the blessed Thistle or
Cardus benedictus. Cardoncello, a little Thistle: but properly an herb growing
on walls and tyles, and is hairie in summer with red stalks, called Groundsell.
Cardone, a great Thistle: the husk of a Chessenut. Also a kind of tree in the
east Indies that grows up straight about a quarter of a mile, and no bigger
then the body of a man, and has but few leaves, of the root whereof they
make wine, honey, vinegar, sugar, with many other things: with the leaves they
cover and tile their houses: it is also called Magnei or Meth. Cardonetta, the
herb stinking weed. Careggiare, as Accarezzare. Careggie, as Carezze.
Carello, a square cushion made of diverse pieces as tailors and beggars use to
sit upon. It is also a hassocke or a mat to stop a privy with. Carena, the
keele or bottom of a ship. It is also taken for a whole ship. Carestia, dearth,
penury, want, scarcity. Carestiolo, penurious, full of dearth, want, or
scarcity. Caretto, a weauers tool or loome whereon he warpeth his web.
Carezzare, as Accarezzare. Carezze, cherishings, friendly entertainments,
flatteries, fawnings, blandisments. Carezzeuole, cherishing, making much of
one, blithe, kind, buckesome, gentle, fawning, blandishing. Carfagna, base,
vncared for, neglected, not set by. Cari, Carowaies. Cariaggio, carriage,

lading. Carica l'asino, a play at cards which we call lodam. Caricare, to
charge, to lade, to lode, to burden, to freight. to impute, to wrong. Carice,

wrong, an imputation, an injury. Cariega, a chair or a sear. Cariglionare, to

Caristio, a kind of green marble. Also a bird that will fly through the
fire and not burn his feathers. Carita, charity, love, agreement. Caritatiuo,
Cariteuole, charitable, loving. Carlina bianca, a kind of little Thistle
wherewith Charles the great cured the plague, and of him took the name: it is
also taken for a Fullers teazell. Carlina nera, the common Thistle with a long
stalk wherewith they curde milk to make cheese. Carlino, a small money so
called. Also a fish like a Tench. Carlona, plainly, dunstable way, homely
fashion. Alla carlona. Carlotto, a bird called a Curlue. Carme, a verse or a

lardrie or place to hang and keep meat in. Also a place to cast bones into.

Also a weauers tool. Carnali, some part about a weauers home. Carnalita,

so called in Rome. Carnosita, carnositie, fleshines. Carnoso, fleshie, brawnie,
full of flesh. Carnosso, flesh and bone together. Caro, dear, beloved,
precious, costly, gratefully, acceptable, leefe. Also caruwaie seed. Also a

properly the fruit or tree called the Carob tree, which bears a kind of
sweet cod or husk. Carobia, Carobio, an highway that turns or goes four
ways, a crosseway. Carobo, a carob tree. Carogna, stinking carrion. Carola, a
caroll or a song. Also a kind of dance. Carolare, to caroll, to revel, to
sing and dance, to be merry. Also to make hollow, to worm or moth-eate. Also
to devour or fester with any gnawing sore, to grow to a cuntbotch. Caroliccio,
moth-eaten, worme-eaten, rotten as timber and old wood will be. Carolo, a moth
or timber-worme. Also a cuntbotch or winchester goose. Also dust or powder of
rotten timber used about young children against fleaing. Caromano, a kind of
fine steel so called. Carone, a Carob tree. Carosa, a young maid, a less, a
girl, a wench, a maiden servant. Carosare, to sheare as they do sheep.
Carota, a carot root. Look Cacciar carote. Carouana, as Carauana. Carouelle,

kind of worm or moth that consumes clothes. Carpano, Carpeno, a fish called a
carpe. Carpare, to creep, to craule. Carpea, a kind of dance used among the
Grecians. Carpentiero, a carpenter. Carpesia, an herb that is poison. Also a

one. Carpignare, as Carpire. Carpinare, as Carpire. Carpino, the utmost or last
tree of any rank. Also a charm. Also the Horne-beame, Hard-beame, or
Yoke-elme tree. Carpionato pesce, fish that is marlde, as they use at Hampton.
Carpione, a fish called a carpe. Also creepingly. Carpire, Carpisco, Carpito,
to snatch, to filch, to prowle, to pilfer, to shift for, to get by hook or
crook, to clime or grapple for. Carpita, a snatch and away, a filching, a
prowling, a pilfring, a shifting for, an assent, a mounting or climing up.
Carpo, a way, a path, a street or high way. Carpone, groping in the dark in
creeping or crauling sort. Carra, carts, wagons or waines. Carraguoli, a kind
of cockles or mushles. Carraiuolo, Carraro, a carter, a wheel wright or cart
maker, a waine-man. Carrareccia, a slough or rut that the wheel of a cart
makes in soul way. Carratello, a tumbrell, a wheelebarrow, a little weight
called a caract. Carrattiero, as Carraiuolo. Carreccia, as Carrareccia.
Carreggiare, to bring or carry by carts or waines: to lode or pile up in a
cart. Carreggiata, a cart way, or the rut or slough of a cart wheel.
Carreggiatore, as Carrettaro. Carrera, as Cariera. Carretta, a cart, a wagon,
a waine. Carrettare, to cart or carry by cart. Carrettaro, Carrettiero, a

stool to learn to go by. Carriaggio, as Cariaggio. Carriera, a careere of a
horse. Carribo, manner, form, rule, fashion, sort or guise. Carriola, as
Carriuola. Carriolaro, a bearer or maker of Cariuola. Carriuola, a trundle bed,
a wheel barrow, a stool with wheels that children learn to go by, a standing
stool. The root of a horses tail. Also a kind of chair covered, used in
Italy for to carry men up and down by porters, unseen of any body. Carro,
a car, a chariot, a waine, a wagon. Also a pageant. Also a kind of measure.
Carrocchiero, a coche-man, a coche-maker. Carroccia, Carrozza, a caroce, a
coche, a chariot. Carrocciaro, Carrozzaro, a coch man, a coche maker. Carruca,
Carrucola, as Carrucula. Carruccio, a little cart or wheel barrow, but
properly those little carts or sleds as have low wooden wheels as they use
at Bristow. Carrucula, as Carriuola. Also a pullie of a well or ship. Also the
rumpe of a horses tail. Carrucolare, to trundle or roll or draw upon little
wheels or pullies. Carta, all manner of paper, a leaf of a book, a folio, a
card, a map, a type, a playing card. Also a paste board. Cartaccia, filthy,
course, waste paper. Also a play at cards so called. Carta di figura, a cote
card. Carta da nauigare, a sailing card. Carta da straccio, waste paper.
Carta di punto, any other card beside a coat card. Carta pecorina, vellume
made of sheep skin. Carta pergamina, parchment. Carta sciuga, sucking paper
that will bear no ink. Cartaro, a carder, a card maker, a seller or maker of
paper or cards. Carte, cards, leaves of books, maps, paste boardes.
Cartecca, as Colatro. Also Dogs-gras. Carteggiare, to play at cards. Also to
card silk or wool. Cartellante, a chalenger, a libeller against one with
cartels. Cartelle, a pair of tables, writing tables. Also the side posts of a
door. Cartello, a cartell, a challenge, a defiance, a libell. Cartesimo, the
art or play at cards. Carti, carding cards. Cartiero, a carder or player at

Cartilaginoso, gristly, full of gristles. Carto, a card, to card wool withal.
Catoccio, a piece of waste paper to put any thing in. Also a kind of yonike
work in building so called among masons. Also a charge of powder to put into a

black berrie bush. Carzerino, as Cardellino. Casa, a house. Also a family, a

Also a house or point upon the chesse boorde. Casacca, a cassocke, a frocke, a
horse-mans cote, a long cote. an habitation or dwelling. Casacchino, a ierkin,
a mandillion. Casaccia, a filthy, old, ruinous house. Casale, a hamlet, a
little village, a manor house, a farme-house. Also a dayrie house. Casalengo,
as Casalingo. Casalingo, homely, household, pane casalingo, household bread. Also
tame or belonging to a house or a home. As Colombi casalinghi, house or tame
pigeons. Casamatta, a kind of fortification called in English a Casamat or a
slaughter house, and is a place built low under the wall or bulwarcke, not
arriving unto the height of the ditch serving to skoure the ditch, annoying the
enemy when he enters into the ditch to skale the wall. Casamento, a building,
a house frame, a manor or farm house. Casare, to marry, to wed, to house.
Casata, married, wedded, a household. Casatelle, a kind of paste-meate used in
Italy. Casato, as Casale. Also a house, a stock, a blood or race of a house.
Cascaglio, a kind of course cheese that clownes eat in Italy. Cascante,
falling or pining away, drooping, frail, crased, ready to fall. Cascapeli, a
disease called the shedding of the hair. Cascare, to fall. Cascata, a fall.
Caschetto, a caske or headpiece. Casciare, to squice, to crush, to press, to
wring out. to curd to cheese. Casciaro, Casciaruolo, a cheese-munger, a cheese
maker. Cascina, a country cottage, a houell, a stacke of hay, a shelter of

accoumpt, estimation, reckoning, a casualtie, a case, or manner how a matter

standard. Casta, chaste, temperate, continent, modest. Castagna, a chestnut.
Castagnato, chestnut color. Castagne, is a piece of iron in likeness of a
scallop shell standing up in the midst of a bit, not used now adays.
Castagnette, little shells, such as they use that dance the canaries, to make a
noise or sound or clack with their fingers. Castagnetto, a grove of chestnut
trees. Castagnuole, little wild chestnuts, a kind of fig so called in Italy.
Castaldia, a bailie-weeke for husbandry. Castaldo, a bailie for husbandry, an

which stinks. Also a fish that lives on the land, as in the water. Castoria,
idem. Castorio, an herb which makes a man's nose to bleed but touching it.
Castorre, a brock or badger. Also a beuer. Capello di Castorre, a beuer hat.
Castracane, a dog gelder. Also the Indian fitch or goats rue. Castrametare, to

vide Corona. Castreo, a fish that never eats other fishes, and can be taken
with no bait. Castro, that part of a ring wherein the stone is set.
Castronaggine, foolishnes, grossenes, simplicity, fondnes, sheepishnes,

Casupula, Casucula, a homely simple poor little house. Catacresi, a figure
when one word is abused for lack of the proper word. Catafalco, Catafarco, a
stage, a scaffold. Also a hearse. Catafratta, a kind of engine of war, a
forte or fence against the assault of the enemy. Catalogare, to register, to

Catalogo, a catalogue. Catalessi, a disease, whereof they that be sick have
the holes of their eyes wide and deep, and their body stiff. Cataletto, as
Cadaletto. Catamito, a ganimed, an ingle, a boie hired to sin against nature.
Catanace, an herb used of witches to provoke love and lust. Catapano, the
trial of waights. Catapasma, as Cataplasma. Catapecchie, entanglings,
ensuarings, cranklings, turnings in and out, clifts, crags, holes or dens, or

glass. Cataplasma, a plaster or cataplasme or green salve laid upon a sore.
Catapotio, a kind of pill to be swallowed for physic. Catapulta, a warlicke
engine to shoot darts or long quarrels out of. Also a sling. Cataputia,
Catapuzza, the herb spurge. Also an instrument which Surgeons use to search the
bladder and to open the passage to urine when it is stopped. Cataratte,
cataracts. Also purculleises. Also sluices, or violent falls of waters.

little water mill. Catoblepa, a serpent in India so venomous that with his
look he kills a man a mile off. Catocchia, the neathermost part of the belly
or pauche. Catochite, a stone so clammie that it will stick to his hands that
does but touch it. Catolico, catholic, universal. Catollo, a logge, a block,

gentleman serving on horseback: but in fortification it is a mount or
platform of earth built or raised high, either within or without the wall for
to plant great ordinance upon. Also it is taken for a silk worm or spinner.
Also a kind of sea crab or lobster. Cauagliere a cauallo, is a high mount or
platform of earth, raised very high that the artillery upon the same may
shoot over the walls and bulwarks to scour and clear the fields all about.

importunate and earnest upon them: so termed because it is thought that they

that place. Cecca, a minte or coining place. Ceccardola, a philip with the

monier. Cecare, to blind. Cecatello, somewhat blind. Cechita blindness. Ceci,

Some say the northwest wind. Cecita, blindness. Ceco, as Cieco. Cedere, Cedo,
Cedei, Cesso, or Ceduto, to yield, to give place, to grant, to resign, to

citron, a pomecitron. Also, a kind of wild hen. Cedronella, baulme mint, or
baulmegentle. Cedula, a bill, a schedule, a note, a ticket, an obligation, or
any handwriting, a docket. Cefaglione, leaves of the wild date, which be good
to eat. Cefalica, the humerall or shoulder vain. Cefalo, Cefaro, a fish
called a mullet. Some take it for the fish pollard. Some have in mockery used
it for the bill or beak of a bird: and also for a man's priuities. Cefalu, a
scornful nickname, as we say, a limlifter. Cefaut, a key in music. Ceffare,
to take by the snoute. Ceffata, a box, a clap, or blow given on the mouth.

seameaw. Cefo, a kind of ape, monkie, or marmoset. Cegolite, a kind of
blackish stone. Ceice, a bird called a kings-fisher. Celabro, as Ceruello.
Celadone, a great skull, helmet, morion, or headpiece. Celaga, a sparrow.

single, or unmarried life. Celibeuita, an unmarried or single life. Celidonia,

cell, a cave, a cabine. Also a seller or butterie. Also those hedge berries
which we call black-berries. Cellaro, a butler, or cell keeper. Cellara^o, an
ouerseer of friars cells. Celo, as Cielo. Celoma, the mariners cry when they
pull up ankre, or hoise sail. Celomare, to cry together as mariners do when

Charita, as Carita. Charta, as Carta. Che, that, which, then, than, what, when,
because, for, to the end, except, saving, but, but only, who, wherefore, a
nothing, whereof, so that, the which, in the which, in whom, what? what thing?
since, since that, for so much as, nothing, no whit, least, least that, a
somewhat. Chebuli, a kind of mirobalane plum. Checcalare, to cackle as a hen.
Ch'eche none, a manner of speech used very often in talk, as we say, I know
not how it came to pass, but soon after, but presently. Che che, what soever,
what thing so ever. Che chi, that who, that whosoever. Chec'e? Che ci e? what
news? what is there? Che domin? what a gods name? what a good year? Che e del
fatto tuo? what becomes of thee? how do thou? Cheggiere, as Chiedere, or
Chieggere. Chel, Chello, that he, to the end that he. Chele, the cleyes or
forepart of the celestial sign Scorpio. Chelidonia, a kind of stone sound in
a swallow, or a swallow. Also a kind of serpent. Also the herb Celandine the
great. Some take it for fig-wort, or pilewort, or tetterwort. Also a west
wind. Chelindro, Chelidro, an adder, or water snake. Chella, that she, to the
end that she. Chelonia, or Chelonitide, as Chelonite. Chelonite, a precious
stone like unto a tortoise shell and taken out of a tortoise head, good against
storms. Chemele, Chemite, a kind of stone like iuorie, as hard as marble, the
bodies buried in them are never consumed. It is said that Darius king of Persia
was buried in a tomb made of such stones. Chemerison, a kind of salt for
alchimists. Chema, a greek measure of liquid things. Chene, a kind of stone
found in the eye of an old Heart, good against poison. Chenero, a kind of snake
or serpent. Chenica, a greek dry measure. Che no? Che non? I hold not, what
will you lay not? not so. Che non, if a verb follow, then, least, least that,
that not. Also in any comparison if a second verb follow it affirmith, and
signifies the^, as for example, Il sauio sa piu che non sa il ma^to, the wise
man knows more then the foul. Chente, how much? how? how long? how far?
Also, as, as much, as well. Also a kind of fine linen cloth. Chente fi fia,
how much soever it be. Cherere, chero, chesi, chiesto, as Chiedere. Chergna, a
fish called a ruff or goldhead. Cherica, as Chierica. Chericato, as

locks, by peecemeale, in number and quantity. Chiocciare, to whiske or yarke
as a whip does. Also to cowre or squat down, to reduce into locks or bundles.
Chioccare, as Chiocciare. Chioccia, a clocking or sitting hen, a brood hen or
a clucke hen. Also hoarse in the throat. Chiocciare, to clock, sit or brood
as hens do. Also to be hoarse. Chioccio, hoarse or snorting. Chiocciola, a
cockle, a scallop or any shell fish, but properly those black snailes with
horns and without shells. Chiodare, to nail up. Chiodaro, a maker of nails.
Chiodaruolo, a tenter man. Chiodo, a nail, a spike. Chioma, the whole hair.
Also the maine of a horse. Also a peruwig. Chiomazzuoli. Look Far
chiomazzuoli. Chioppa, a dripping pan. Also a splint or spall of some broken
stone. Chioppare, to clack or snap with ones fingers as barbers use, or such as
dance the canaries. Chioppo, a clacke, a snap, a clicking with ones fingers
ends. Chiosa, a gloss, an interpretation or exposition. Chiosare, to gloss upon
any thing, to interpret, to expound. Chiasatori, glosers, expounders. Chioso,
molten, thawed. Chiostra, Chiostro, a cloister or enclosure. Chiostrare, to
cloister up, to lock up, to coope or shut up, to pen up, to immure. Chiotta,
close, squat, hushed as a hen over her chickens, lurking, secret. Chioua, a
kind of great weight in Italy. Chiouara, tenters for to dry and stretch
clothes upon. Chiouarda, the spokes of a cart or wheel. Chiouardo, a swelling
and vlcering at the cronet of a horses hoof, proceeding of a hurt in the foot
by a nail, or such like accident. Chiouaro, Chiouaruolo, a tenter man or
keeper of tenters. Chiouiale, a sleeuelesse garment. Chiouo, any kind of
nail, peg, tacke or spike. Also a disease in the eyes. Chiouola, the knee pan
of any creature. Chiozza, a sluice to let out waters at, a water gate. Chipassa,
the name of a galliard. Chirade, ruptures or chaps in the hands and feet.
Chiragra, the gout in the fingers or hands. Chiribizzare, as Ghiribizzare.
Chiribizzo, as Ghiribizzo. Chiricoccola, a wagtaile. Chirografo, an obligation
or bill of ones hand, a bond for any debt. Chiromante, a palmester, a diuiner
by the palm of the hand. Chiromantia, palmestrie. Chironie. Look^ Vlcere
chironie. Chiroteca, a flower called our Ladies glove. Chiruca, a little beast
with ears, skin, tail, and shape like a mouse, having under his belly a great
bag, wherein he carries his young ones. It does much hunt after hens and such
poultrie: but there be two sorts of them, one bigger than another, and
somewhat like a fox with a great tail. Chirugia, the art of chirurgerie.
Chirugico, a surgeon. Chitarra, a gitterne, or such instrument. Chistetto, a

Piu. Chiuca, as Chiruca. Chiudara, a turner^ or ioyners, or sadlers tool.

as Crisocollo. Chrisi, the conflict of nature and sickness. Chrisolito, a

history or chronicle. Chronichista, a chronicle writer. Chronico, idem. Ci, an

haggas or liuering. Ciamorro, a disease in horses called the mourning of the
chine, issuing at the nosthrils. Ciampoline, a kind of dainty pear in Italy.

castle, or spacious fort built not only to defend the city, but also to
keep the same in awe and subjection. Citara, a gitterne, a citterne, a crowd.

convent. Citaro, a fish whose teeth are like a saw, called a sharke.
Citatione, a citation, a sommoning, a conuenting. Citatorie, citations,
processes, enditements. Citella, a young wench, a little less, a pretty girl.
Citello, as Cittino. Citeriore, nigher or near to us. Citharista, Citharello,
one that plays on such instruments. Cithera, Citera, a citterne, a gitterne, a
croude, a kit. Citiscare, as Citire. Citi, as Frinfri. Citire, Citisco, Citito,
to move the lips or tongue for to whisper, to hush or be still. Cito, a young
boy or lad. Citri, toys, baggage things, trifles, fancies, humors, conceits,
fooleries. Citrinella, a kind of goldfinch with yellow feathers. Citrino, a
pale yellow limon color. Also a citron. Also a kind of mirabolane plum.
Citriolo, Citriuolo, a citron. Citronata, a kind of sauce made of citrons, a
tart made of citrons. Citrone, a citron, a pome-citron. Citta, Cittade, a city
or cities, a walled town. Cittadella, as Citadella. Cittadinanza, the
comminaltie of a city. Also a franchise or liberty of a citizen. Cittadinare,
to denison or make free of a city, to dwell in a city. Cittadinesco,
citizen-like. Cittadino, a citizen, a denison. Citta di Dite, limbo or hell.
Cittino, a young boy, a lad. Citto, a word to bid children hold their peace, as
we say whusht, hushed. Cittolo, a kind of fish. Cittona, a big wench.
Citusella, the herb sorrel. Ciuadera, the name of a sail in a ship. Ciuaie,
all sorts of herbs in the market, herbage. Ciuanza, profit, gettings, gain,
advantage, overplus, a forecast. Ciuanzamenti, profits, gettings, vailes or
gains. Ciuanzare, to profit, to get, to gain, to prevent or forecast. Ciuffa,
a braule, a contention, a strife, a brabble. Ciuffare, to braule, to contend,
to strive, to snatch, to tug. Also to take by the snout, to lug by the face.
Ciuffetto, a tuft or lock of hair. Also a little snoute, a forehead or front.
Ciuffo, a kind of staff big at one end, wherewith porters hold up their
burdens when they rest. Also a snoute or muzzle of a beast. Also a lock of
hair before. Ciuffolare, to whistle. Ciuffole, Ciufole, toys, trifles,
fooleries, nifles, vanities, foolish tricks. Ciuffolo, a whistle. Ciuetta, an
owl. Look Occhio di ciuetta. Ciuettare, to pry or look narrowly about, to
sneake up and down. Ciuettini, effeminate, wanton, bawdie lads. Also young
owlets. Ciuico, of a city, civil. Look Corona. Civil, civil, modest,
gentle, courteous, temperate, meek, kind. Ciuilita, Ciuilta, civility,
courtesy, modesty. Ciuilire, isco, ito, to grow civil, to tame, to make
courteous. Ciuillari, a common iakes in Florence, or place where all filth and
dung is cast out. Ciuire, isco, ito, to barter, to change, to trucke. Ciuogne,
a kind of device to draw water out of a deep well, as it were with two
buckets. Ciurlo, a twirle or round trick in dancing. Ciurma, the common
rascalitie of gallie slaves, a base route. The mariners call it in English
ghing. Ciurmaglia, as Ciurma. Ciurmare, to play the common base fellow: to
persuade or allure with craft or deceit: to charm: to in^eagle, to prate, cog
and foist, to brag with intent to cosen one. Ciurmarie, cosening or cheating
houses. Also cosening or cheating tricks, trifling baggages, trash, luggage.

swaggrer, a swabber. Ciutaccia, a flurt, a trull, a harlot. Ciziceno, a Greek
coin of gold. Cizza, a dug, a teate, a pap, a woman's breast. Cizzarca, a kind
of peason. Cizzare, to suck a teate or dug. Cizzuta, having great teates or
dugs. Clamore, a clamor, an outery, a noise, a shout, a roaring. Clamoso,

Tutsain or Parke-leaues. Climo, a kind of measure used of yore in Greece.

flower into which Clitia was transformed. Cliuo, a little hill, a hillocke.

Combustioso, that will burn or may be burned. Combusto, burnt, combusted,
parched. Come, when, how? so soon as, even as, since that, as much as, in what

chiome. Come che, howbeit, although, though, albeit, howsoever. Come domine?

Coppa di Gioue. Corona della terra, ground Iuie. Corona castrense, a crown
given to him that first invaded the enemies camp. Corona vallare, idem. Corona
murale, a crown given to him that first scaled the walls. Corona ciuica, a
garland of oak given to him that saved a citizen, by him that was so saved.
Corona nauale, a crown given to him that first boarded a ship. Corona
rostrata, idem. Corona ossidionale, a crown given to a captain that raised a
force. Corona triomfale, a crown sent to an Emperor or captain general in
