a hap a chance. Euersione, an euersion, an overthrowing, a ruin. Eufonia, a
good sound, a pleasant noise or utterance of words. Euforbio, Euphorbiu^, or
gummie thistle. Eufragia, the herb Eiebright. Euganeo, a kind of excellent
cheese. Eugenia, noblenes of blood or birth. Eugenico, noble in blood and
birth. Euidente, evident, clear, manifest, apparent. Euidenza, evidence,
appearance, an evidence, a testimony. Euincere, vinco, vinsi, vinto, to
convince, or euict by law. Euitabile, euitable, that may be avoided. Euitare,
to shun, to avoid, to escape. Euitatione, an avoiding, a shunning, a flying
from. Euittione, a conuicting by law. Eulogia, a praise, an honest and
profitable reason, a thing well spoken. Eumenide, the furies of hell. Eumetre,
a kind of green precious stone like flint, which being put upon ones head
causes him to dream of strange sights. Eunucare, to geld, to eunuch, to
splaie, to libbe. Eunuco, one that is gelded, an eunuch, a gelding, splaid or
libd. Euocatione, an invocation or calling upon, a calling forth. Euo, time
everlasting, euerduring time. Euphonia as, Eufonia. Eupatoria, the herb
Agrimonie, or Liuerwoort. Some take it for Maudelin, or Balsamint. Eupelato, a
precious stone of four colors, fiery, blew, green, and vermillion.
Eupilide, a swelling of the flesh in the gums by the cheek teeth. Eupotria, an
herb good against agues. Euripo, an arm of the sea often ebbing and flowing.
Also a water pipe. Eurithmia, a beauty where every thing or part answers his
just or due proportion. Euro, the easterly wind, the east wind. Euro austro,
a northeast wind. Euronato, a southeast wind. Eusebia, piety, religion,
godliness. Eutimia, security, quietness, hartes-ease. Eutrapelia, good
behavior, gentleness or garb. Euuene, there is of it, or else is there any
thereof? Euui, there is, is there?
F
FA, a note in music. Also he does. Also do thou. Fabraria, the art of
Smithes. Also a smithes forge or workehouse. Fabrica, a frame, a building.
Fabricare, to build, to frame, to forge. Fabricatione, a building, a framing,
a forging. Fabricatore, a builder, a framer, forger. Fabricense, a suruayer, or
master of works and buildings. Fabrile, pertaining to a smith. Also that may
be wrought. Fabro, Fabbro, a smith, a workman, a forger. Also a kind of fish.
Fabuloria, the herb Henbane. Fabulosita, fabulousnes, invention of fables and
lies. Faccette, the name of some part of a horses bit. Facchinante, base,
playing the porter. Facchinare, to play the porter, or the base companion.
Facchinarie, base, filthy, rascally, porterlike-trickes. Facchino, a porter, a
bearer of burdens. Also a soul base knave. Faccia, a face, a visage, a sight
or countenance. Also the sembla^ce, figure, form, fashion, proportion or
likeness of a thing. Also let him do, make, or cause, or that he may do, or
make. Faccia, Facciata, a side of a chamber or of a house, or of a leaf of a
book, a page of a book. Also a sores^^nt. Faccia a faccia, face to face.
Facciolo, Facciuolo, Faccioletto, as Fazzoletto. Face, Faccola, a torch, a
link or any great light, a firebrand, a cresset light. Facella, Facellina, a
little torch or link, or any burning light, a little brande. Facendare, to
busy, to deal, to be doing. Facende, business, affairs, negotiations,
doings, dealings. Also a man's or woman's priuities. Facendiere, Facendaro, a
dealer in business, affairs, a negociator, an agent, a dealer, a factor, or
dooer. Facetie, pleasantnes, mirth, witty conceits. Facetioso, as Faceto.
Faceto, pleasant, conceited, witty. Facile, easy, tractable, pliable, facile,
ethe, light, gentle, tractable, prone. Facilita, easines, readiness, courtesy.
Facilitare, to make easy. Facillimo, most easy. Facinio, a mischief, an ill
deed, a wicked act. Facino, bread made of a kind of pulse or grain called
Ciue. Facinoroso, wicked, ungracious, lewd, full of mischief. Facitore, a
dooer, a maker. Facitrice delle fusa storte, a woman that spinnes crooked
spindles, id est, makes her husband a cuckolde. Facitura, a doing, a making,
a workmanship, or labor. Facolta, Facoltoso, as Faculta. Facondia, eloquence,
pleasant speech, grace in speaking. Facondo, eloquent, well spoken. Faculta,
riches, wealth, goods, faculty, power, ability. Facultoso, rich, wealthy,
well to live. Faganello, the bird called a linnet. Also a kind of fish.
Fagiana, a phesant hen. Fagiano, Faggiano, a phesant. Fagianella, a phesant
poute. Fagianotto, Faggianotto, a phesant poute. Faggio, a beech tree.
Faggiola, a kind of gall or acorne, or maste that the Beech tree bears.
Faggiolata, Fagiolata, a flim-flam tale, as women tell when they shale peason,
which has neither head nor foot, nor rhyme nor reason: a flap with a
foxetaile: court-holie water, a tittle tattle, or such. Fagioli, Fagiuoli, a
kind of pease like unto a bean, called faseoles, french peason, welsh beans,
or kidney beans. Fagioli pinti, french beans, or beans of Rome. Fagiolo, a
colts tooth, whereby a horses age is known. Fagnone, an idle loytring g^ll, a
ninnie. Fagotto, a faggot, a bundell, a bauin, a fardell, a trusse, a pack.
Also a kind of musical instrument. Faguccia, the name of a goldsmiths tool.
Faina, a mincing, coie, nice, puling, squeamish woman, an idle huswife, a
flurt, a gigxi. Also as Foina. Fainare, to mince it, to pule, to be squeamish,
to play the idle huswife. Falangagio, an herb that cures the biting of the
spider Phalangio. Falange, a military order that Alexander the great used, a
great squadron, consisting of eight thousand footmen. Falangiale, pertaining
to that military order. Falangio, a kind of venomous spider. Also an herb
that cures the biting of that spider. Falangose, a kind of disease in a man's
eielids. Falaride, a kind of herb called grass corn. Falbo, a baie color
of a horse. Also a kind of fish. Falcare, to wreath, to wrest, to bend, to
make crooked. Also to abate, to defeat. Also to arm with crampers. Falcati,
hooked, armed with crampers, as the Romans were wont to arm their carts.
Falce, a sieth, a sickle, a hook, a bill, a crampern. Also a fish called in
Latin Taenia. Falce fenaia, a sieth to mow haie. Falchi, are stays when a
horse does rest upon his hinder parts. Falciare, to mow corn or haie.
Falciatore, a mower. Falcidia, a word taken from Falcidius the Roman, who made
a law that the Senate should have the fourth part of the lands that were
gotten. The Italians use it for the abatement of the fourth part of any thing,
but spoken in mockery. Falcifero, a mower, or one that bears a sieth.
Falcinella, a sickle. Also as Auosetta. Falcione, a bending forest bill, or
welsh hook. Falcone, a faulcon. Also a kind of bumbard so called. Also gold
according to Alchimists phrases. Falcon trauescio, a kind of faulcon.
Falconzafiro, a kind of faulcon with yellow legs and feet. Falconeggiare, to
hawk or to faulcon. Falconello, a kind of lanaret hawk. Falconetto, a
faulconet, a kind of shot or bumbard. Falconiera, a faulkners bag, a hauking
pouch. Falconiere, a faulkner, a hauker. Falcon randione, a kind of faulcon
that is king of al birds, for that no bird dares fly near it, no not the
eagle. Falda, a fold, a plate, a wrinkle, a gathering, the skirts of the cote.
It is also the side or foot of a hill. Also the armor called taces or
cuishards. Also a flake. Faldare, to fold, to pleite, to entresse, to wrinkle,
to cockle, to gather, to curle, to entraile. Also to flake. Faldarello, a
little pretty dog, a playing dog, a puppie sitting upon a woman's cotes.
Faldea, a kind of open or loose garment which the noble women of Venice were
wont to were. Falde, swathes, roulers or bandles to swath children with. Also
flakes of snow: also those pieces of armory, that are called cuishards or
taces. Also plaitings, wrinckles, folds, gatherings, curlings, plaites. Also
locks or handfuls of wool or flax. Also a folding, an inwinding or a
plaiting of a garment. Faldelare, as Faldare. Faldigliare, as Faldare.
Faldiglie, as Falde. Also a frocke or gathered garment. Faldigie, idem.
Faldoni, as Falde. Falecio, a kind of verse or poem. Falegname, a carpenter or
timber maker or worker, a cutter down of wood, a woodman. Fall in bello, a
goodly gallant spruise finicall fellow* in the worst sense, a fresh water
soldier, a milk sop. Falace, false, deceivable, deceitful, fraudulent,
guilefull. Fallacia, fallacy, falsehood, deceit, illusion, fraud, guile.
Fallacioso, fallacious, deceitful. Fallaci loquentia, deceitful speech.
Fallante, falling, missing. Fallare, to fail, to miss, to err, to deceive, to
trespass, to fraud. Fallenza, Fallore, Fallanza, as Fallo. Falletto, is a
little ring in the mouth of the bit set at one end of the root. Falli, faults,
as Annelletti. Fallimento, as Fallo, a breaking, a bankrout. Fallire, Fallisco,
Fallito, as Fallare. Also to become bankrout, to crack his credit. Fallito, a
bankrout, one that has cracked his credit. Also broken, bankrout, cracked in
credit, mist, erred. Fallo, Fallore, a fault, an error, a miss, a sin, a
transgression, an oversight, a trespass, couen, fraud or guile. Also a fault
in tenise. Also do it. Falope, a kind of shell fish. Falsare, to falsify,
counterfeit or forge. Falsario, Falsatore, a falsifier, a counterfeiter, a
forger, a false corner. Falseggiare, as Falsare. Falsetto, a false treble or
counter-tenor in music. Falsidico, a lier, a leaser, one that tells no truth.
Falsificare, as Falsare. Falsifico, Falsificatore, as Falsario. Falsita,
falsehood, falsenes, deceit. Falso, false, counterfeit, deceitful. Falsoni,
hawks or faullons. Falsonetti, little young hawks. Falso quarto, a cleft in
the hoof of a horse by the talent nail, commonly called a false quarter.
Faluo, a bay color. Fama, fame, report, brute, renown, reputation, credit.
Fama vt, or Fame vt, in jest used for Fama vt, a note in music, but taken for
hungerly or greedily. Fame, hunger, famine. Also greedines and desire, an
appetite, a good stomach or lust to eat. Fame canina, a hungry dogged
stomach. Also a disease so called. Fame contadina, clounish hunger, ravenous
hunger. Famelico, hungry, greedy, ravenous. Famfaluche, as Fanfaluche.
Famiglia, a family, a household. Famigliaccio, a filthy groom, hind or
swain, a scullion. Famigliare, to set up household, to become familiar, to
tame. Also familiar, tame, gentle, acquainted, conversant, a household guest.
Famigliarita, familiarity, acquaintance. Famiglio, a groom, a servant, a
hind, a swain, a manseruant. Famigliola, Famigliuola, a little family, or
household. Familiare, as Famigliare. Familiarita, as Famigliarita. Fammelo, do
it me, do it to me. Fammi, make me, do me. Famoso, famous, renowned, glorious,
excellent. Famulente, hungry, or hunger starved. Fanale, a lantern of a ship
or gally. Fanatico, used for a pagan priest, properly fanatike, inspired,
ravished, or mad. Fanciulla, a wench, a less, a girl, a child, a maiden.
Fanciullesco, childish, toyish, indiscreete, puerile, brattish. Fanciullezza,
childhood, youth, puerilitie. Fanciullo, a boy, a child, a lad, a page, a
stripling, a brat, a barn. Fando, used in verse for facendo, doing. Fanello, a
little bird, we call it a Linet, some take it for a Lapwing. Fanfaluche,
Fanfalughe, flim flam tales, old wives fables, a ribble rabble discourse, idle
words, speeches of no worth. Fanfaluco, a simple, sottish, prating fellow.
Fanfalucole, as Fanfaluche. Fangare, to bemire, to bemud, to bedash with dirt,
to bedabble. Fangarolla, a kind of bird, always dabling in the mud or mire.
Fango, dirt, mud, mire. Fangoso, durtie, murie, bedasht, muddie, bedabled.
Fangro, a fish called in latin Pagrus. Fan, do us, make us, make of it.
Fano, the lantern of a ship or galley. Fantaccino, a silly soldier, a mean
footeman. Fantaguzzo, a nickname for a fresh water soldier, a milkesop.
Fantaria, infanterie, footmen. Fantasia, a fancy, a conceit, fantasy, humor,
imagination or intent. Fantasma, a ghost, a hag, a robin good fellow, a
holigoblin, a sprite, a jade, the riding hagge, or mare. Fantasticare, to rave
or be fantastical, foolishly conceited, or humorous. Fantasticarie,
fantastical toys, vain humors, idle imaginations. Fantastico, fantastical,
conceited, humorous, rauing, skittish. Fante, a man or woman servant, a groom,
a footeman, a soldier serving on foot, the knave or varlet at cards, a pawn
at chesse. Fantella, a girl, a less, a young maid. Fantesca, a kitchen maid,
a househould servant, a drudge servant. Fanticella, a young maiden servant, a
young wench, a little girl. Fantino, a young lad or boy, a prentice, a child.
Fantocchio, a foolish serving creature. Fantoccia, an elderlie unmarried maid.
Fantolino, a young child, lad or boy, a babie. Farassa, a great round fish that
is an enemy to the Whale. Farciglione, a kind of cormorant or such water
ravenous foul. Farcina, a disease in a horse called a Farcin, or fashions, or
farcies, a creeping ulcer. Farcinoso, a horse that has the farcins, full of
the farcins. Fare, Faccio, or Fo, Feci, Fatto, to do, to make, to cause, to
compose, to act. Fare a guisa della coda del porco, che tutto il giorno se la
dimena and poi la sera non ha fatto nulla, do and undo the day is long enough,
mutch ado and never the nearer, to do as the hog does that all day wags his
tail and at night has done nothing. Fare aguati, to lay ambushes, to seek to
entrap. Fare ala, the name of a certain march sounded upon drum and trumpet in
time of war. Fare alto, as Fare ala. Fare all coltellate, to fight with
weapons that cut. Fare alla grappa piu, to play at musse, to shuffle, or
skamble for. Fare acqua, to water, or take in fresh water in a ship. Also to
piss. Fare a gara, to strive, or to contend for the victory. Fare a
chetichegli, to go closely and secretly about ones business, to play the slye or
subtle companion, the lurking and close fox, to sneake or mich about
lurkingly, to play least in sight. Fare all braccia, to wrestle, to struggle.
Fare a gucchia, to knit as silk hosen be with needles. Fare a cozzi, to shock,
to but as Rams do. Fare accoglienza, to entertain, to give entertainment.
Fare brindisi, to drink a health, to pledge a health to one, to carrouse it.
Fare broglio, to canuas, to trudge about, or shift for, to rob Peeter and pay
Paul, to take up commodities. Fare beffe, to mock, to floute, to scoff. Fare
buon partito, to make a good offer, to give good entertainment. Fare baco baco,
to play boe peep. Fare bell tempo, to be fair weather. Fare a rigatta, to
strive or play at musse for any thing. Fare capitale, to make especial account
of, to account as his own, to gather a stock. Fare chiomazzuoli, a horse to
defend the bit with his nether lip: Some conster it to be when a horse does
cover or defend his gum with his lip. Fare colatione, to break ones fast.
Fare cattiuo tempo, to be foul weather. Fare cornamusa, as Gonfiare alcuno.
Fare di meno, to choose whether one will do a thing or no. Fare di beretta, to
put off ones cap or hat for reverence sake. Fare d'occhio, to wink upon one,
to give a sign with the eyes, to give an inkling. Fare fare, to cause or force
to do. Fare frit frit, to play cricket a wicket. Fare festa, to keep holyday.
Also to cherish, to make much of, to entertain lovingly. Fare giornata, to
fight a battle. Fare forfici, when a horse does wry both his chaps like a
pair of sheares. Fare il rosso, to jest, to dally, to play the wanton. Fare
il solecchio, to make a shadow, to shadow, to shade. Fare il sole, the sun to
shine. Fare il ballordo, to play the noddie or fool. Fare il call, Fare la
piega, to make a habit, to enure. Fare il pane, to dye, to kick up ones heels,
never to have more need of bread. Fare il santo, to play the hypocrite, to
dissemble. Fare il buon pro, to do one good. Fare il sen^e, to come to
perfection, to come to a full groth. Fare la credenza, to take the essay for a
Prince, to be sewer to a prince. Fare la quarantana, to keep lent or fast
forty days, properly in time of plague or sickness, to keep forty days from
company, namely if one come from infected places, as they use in Italy. Fare le
bozze, to graft horns on ones head. Fare le fusa sort, to spin crooked
spindles, a woman to make her husband a cuckold. Fare le carte, to deal the
cards. Fare la sposa, to play the bride, to bride it, to mince it. Fare le
none, to prevent one for borrowing, as if I fear that one comes to borrowe
money of me: as soon as I see him I begin to complain that I am poor and
have no money, and know not where to get any: of such a one they say, Lui fa le
none, that is there is nothing to be hoped for of such a dissembler. Fare la
quaresima, to keep lent. Fare le forche, to know a thing and to dissemble the
knowledge thereof. Also to blame one when one should praise him, used in both
these senses. Fare la busca, to play at musse. Fare le luster, as Fare le
forche. Fare le fica, to bid a fig, a flurt or a turde for one. Fare la honesta
da campi, to counterfeit honesty. Farla in tree paci, to have but three casts
for it, not to stay long upon the matter. Also to make a conclusiue peace
between man and woman putting two in one. Fare la minuta, to make a draught of
any writing or work. Fare montar in collera, to make one be angry or take
pepper in the nose. Fare merenda, to make a drinking after dinner. Fare la
luna, the moon to shine. Fare peduccio, to sooth one up with good words, to
currie favor one, to allow and make good whatsoever one says. Fare tauola, to
make a stale at the play of chess^, to be idle, neither win nor lose. Fare
ribuffi, to chide or give a check. Fare scommessa, to lay a wager, to bet.
Fare tempone, to feast and make good cheer, to pass away the time merrily.
Fare vna finta, to make an offer or show to do any thing. Fare stare, to
coosen, conicatch, to ouerreach or fetch one over. Fare scala, to land or set
footing on any land. Fate vezzi, to wantonize withal. Fare stocchi, to take up
commodities, to rob Peter and pay Paul. Fare le posate, to make a horse
advance, when at a stop he rises twice or thrice with his forefeet.
Fardellare, to fardle, to pack, to trusse, to bundle up. Fardello, a fardell, a
pack, a trusse, a bundle, a burden. Faretra, a quiver for arrows. Faretrare,
to quiver or adorn a man with a quiver. Farfa, the dandrafe that comes from
the head or lies on the head. Farfalla, a gnat, a mote, a fly that houering
about a candle burns it self called a bishop. Farfallone, the filthy snot of
ones nose or gubbon of fleame. Also a kind of great fly, or humble Be. Also
a filthy, snottie, slouenly, slauering, driueling fellow. Also a shameless
lying fellow. One that will lie for the whetstone. Farfanicchio, a foolish
milkesop or fresh water soldier. Farfante, as Furfante. Farfara, Farfarella,
as Farfa. Also the herb folefoote, coltes foot or horsefoote. Farfaro, the

Farnice, a kind of tree bearing a hard fruit. Faro, I will do, I shall make.
Farole, the lantern of a gallie or ship. Also a beacon. Farona, a stubble
goose. Farraina, a kind of mash given to horses made of diverse sorts of grain
together. Farro, a kind of wheat which they make pottage or formentie of in

withs, fardels, gardings, borders, laces, roules, or bindings about a garment.

eyebiting proceeding of the wry looks of envious persons and of wolfes.
Fascinatore, a bewitcher, a charmer with the eyes. Fascinelle, little fagots,

bundell, a sheafe, a burden, as of wood or straw. Fastidiare, to trouble, to
vex, to molest, to be tedious or loathsome, t^o importune, to accloye.

minded, disdainful. Fasuoli, as Fagioli. Fata, a fairie, a witch, an

frantike, mad, bedlam. Fury, furies, the furies of hell. Furigare, to fumble

maulkin. Furioso, furious, raging, mad, frantike, bedlam, outrageous. Furlano,
a pratler, a chatter, a mountebanke. Furmaggio, as Formaggio. Furno, as Forno.
Also they were. Furo, Furon, Furono, they were of the verb Essere. Furo, a
thief, a filcher, a hooker, a pilfrer, a cosener. Furo, he stole, or she did
steal. Furon furone, by stealth, stealingly, secretly, sneakingly. Furore,
Furrore, fury, rage, madness, outrage, bedlam madness. Furtarello, a petty
filching or theeuish trick. Furtiuo, by stealth, stealing. Furto, a theeuery,
a larcine, a burglarie, a pilfring, a filching. Fusaiuolo, a spindle maker, or
a wreather, a turner. Also a swiuell for a spindle. Fusano, Pricke-woode,
Pricke-timber, or Spindle tree. Fusare, to spindle: but taken to flatter or go
about the bush with one. Fusaruolo, Fusardo, as Fusaiuolo, Gambe fusaruole,
spindle shankes. Fusare, to twirle a spindle. Also to spin. Also to wind a man
about as women do their spindles, id est, to flatter or fetch one over.
Fusarie, trifles, vanities, nifles, baggage things. Fusaro, a spindle maker.

Fuscellare. Fuscielle, as Fuscello. Fusciellino, as Fuscellino. Fusellare, to

little pegs. Also flying squibs. Fuseragnolo, a spindler. Fusetto, a kind of
small sharp poynado or dagger used in Italy, as Stilletto. Fusibile, any thing
that will melt. Fusile, any thing that will melt or may be melted. Fusione, a

fussi, fussero, I, he, or they should be, or were. Fusta, a kind of small
bark called a foist, a pinace or Fliebote. Fustagno, the stuff we call
Fustian. Fustagnaro, a fustian maker. Fustagnoso, made like fustian.
Fustagnetto, a kind of fine thin fustian. Fustibalo, as Balista. Fusto, a
stock, a truncke, a stump, a log, a block, a body without a head. Also a
stalk. Also a stock, or a breech for any artillery. Also a tree of a saddle.
Fustoso, like a log, a truncke, a stock or block or stump. Futta, Futa, a
confutation, a confounding. Futtare, Futare, to confute, to confound. Futuro,
future, aftercomming, to come herafter.
G
GAbano, Gabbano, a fishermans or a shepherds cloak or gabbardine. Gabanare,
Gabbanare, to cover with a course cloak or gabbardine. Gabbanello, a gabbardine
or sheapheards coat, or cloak. Gabbare, to cosen, to cheat, to conicatch, to
mock, to flout, to cog withal, to deceive or fetch one over. Gabbatore, a
cosener, a cheater, a conicatcher, a mocker, a flouter, a cogger. Gabba
christo, an hyppocrite, a dissembler. Gabba done, a cosener or deceiuer of
women. Gabba santi, a precise dissembling puritan, an hypocrite. Gabbatella, a
fool or vice in a play or painted upon cards. Gabbatelle, as Bagatelle. Also
a kind of dog to play withal. Also foolish and apish tricks. Gabbatelliere,
as Bagattelliere. Gabbeuole, cosening, cheating, conicatching, mocking,
flouting, deceiving. Gabbo, a cosening, a cheat, a conicatching trick, a
mock, a flout, a deceit, a mockery. Gabella, toll, tallage, custom or
imposition. Gabellare, to toll, to tallage, to custom as merchandise are.
Gabelliere, Gabellotto, a receiver of toles, tallages or customs. Gabbia, a
cage, a coope, a pen. Also the top of the maste of a ship where the shrouds
are fastened. Also a woman's privy parts. Gabbia della naue, the top or cage of
a ship. Gabbiare, to encage, to cage, to coope or pen up. Gabbione, a gabbion,
a great cage or coope. Also those baskets full of earth that are set by the
ordinance in the camp, to hide the canoniers. Gabbionare, to strengthen or
compass with gabbions, to barricados. Gabbionaro, a gabbion or barricado
maker. Gabbietta, a little cage. Gabiano, a fish called in latin Agonus.
Gabrina, an old filthy ouerridden whore or witch, a stallion ramp. Also a
woman's name in Ariosto. Gaffare, to filtch or snatch away, to proule, to miche
or shift for. Gaffo, a snatching or taking hold of, a prowling or shifting.
Gagalare, to chucke or laugh extremely. Gagate, as Gagatronica. Gagatronica, a
stone called ieat or agath stone, that being burned smells of brimstone. Gaggia,
as Gabbia. Gaggia di naue, the cage of a ship. Gaggia di sorgij, a mouse trap.
Gaggiandra, a kind of great snaile. Gaggiare, to wage, to lay a wager, to
engage, to coope, to encage. Gaggio, a gage, a wager, a pledge. Gagite, a stone
found in an eagles neast, which being shaken sounds hollow. Gagliarda, a dance
called a galliard. Gagliardetti, streamers, banerols or ensigns in ships.

io^e, mirth, glee, blithnes, iolitie, buckesomnes, gayness. Gaietto, a

diverse colored clothing or apparel. Gala, Andar a gala, to run a drift or

Heteroscij, those which have their shadows cast but one way, as those which
dwell in either of the temperat zones, we that dwell in the worth temperate have
at noone the sun always south; and therefore our shadows north. They that
dwell in the south temperate have the sun at noone in the north; and
therefore their shadows always south. Hiacintho, a precious stone called a

Hidiopepe, the herb arsemart or culerage. ^^^^pico, a man that has the
drops^e. Hidropisia, the disease called the dropsy. Hiecora, now, at this
instant, even now. Hiemale, winter, of the winter. Hiena, a beast of all other
the most subtle, about the bigness of a wolf. It counterfeits man's voice; it
has a maine like a horse: the doung it yields is called ciuet. Also a kind of
precious stone taken out of the Hienas head. Hier, Hieri, yeasterday. Hieracio,
the herb hauk-weede or sowthistle. Hiera^ite, a kind of precious stone.
Hierapicra, a bitter confection to purge choler. Hierarchia, an holy
governance or principality. Hierde, as Ghierde. Hieria, a kind of precious
stone good against the falling sickness. Hiermatina, yeasterday morning.
Hierobotamo, the herb verueine. Hiersera, yeasternight, yeasterday ceu^ning.
Hiernotte, yeasterday at night, the last night. Hierofante, an expounder of
mysteries or holy scriptures. Hieroglisico, mystical or enigmaticall letters
or ciphers, signifying whole sentences used by the Egyptians. Hierone, the bird
called a hearon. Hile, a kind of salt or mixture that alchimists use. Hillare,
cheerful, glad, blithe, joyous, pleasant. Hillaria, the eight day of the
kalends of April, when the day begins first to increase, and be longer then
the night. Used also for shrouing time or other times of mirth. Hillarita,
gladness, cheerfulnes, glee, rejoicing, mirth, iocondnes, pleasantnes. Hillo,
the little gut. Hilo, the northwind. Himeccere, an interiection of admiration;
as we say good Lord, who would have thought it. Himenei, the weddings or
marriages. Himeneo, the god of marriage. Himmon, a kind of adamant stone, that
on the one side draws iron to it; and with the other drives it away from it.
Hinchinchiare, as Fottere. Hinnire, nisco, nito, to niegh as a horse. Hinnito,
the neighing of a horse, neighed as a horse. Hinno, a hymn, a praising song.
Hinnulare, a kind of kite or buzzard. Hiosquiano, the weed henbane. Hipangi,
the planets so called when they are hidden with the light of the sun.
Hiperbasi, a figure when words are transposed from the grammatical order.
Hiperbaton, an herb that will cure hurts of poisoned arrows. Hiperberico, the
month October. Hiperbole, an hyperboll or excess in advancing or depressing.
Also a certain crooked line coming of the cutting of a cone or cylinder.
Hiperbolico, hyperbolical, beyond all credit or estimation or liklyhood of
truth. Hiperbolizzare, to hiperbolize, to advance or depresse any thing beyond
likelihood and truth. Hiperborei, they which dwell above the blowing of the
northwinde, who commonly live above a 100. years. Hiperdulio, above or
ouerseeing the service of slaves and bondmen. Hiperico, the herb saint John's
woort. Hipericon, an herb called in latin Colion. Hiperzeugma, maniera di
costruttione. Hipice, an herb which chewed in ones mouth takes away hunger.
Hipocausto, a stew or hot house. Hipochisi, a disease in the eyes called
Suffusio. Hipocondria, the forepart of the belly and sides, under which lies
the liver and spleen. Hipocrisia, simulation, hypocrisy, fained holiness.
Hipocrita, Hipocrito, an hypocrite, a dissembler of another man's person.
Hipocritico, hypocritical, full of dissimulation. Hipodorio, a kind of grave
accent in music. Hipofrigio, as Hipodorio. Hipogaustrio, that part of the
belly which reaches from the navel to the hairs of the privy parts.
Hipolidio, a kind of accent or note in music. Hipopij, the bones that be
under the eyes. Hipostasi, a substance. Also residence in urine flitting toward
the bottom. Hipotetica, a word of the civil law importing pledge, bail or
maine price. Hipothesia, an argument or matter whereupon one should dispute and
argue. Hipozeugma, a figure when every clause has his proper verb.
Hippagreto, such a one as is captain over armed men. It is used in Xenophon.
Hippicone, a greek measure of 500. paces, or half an Italian mile. Hippo, as
Hipuro. Also the greek word for a horse. Hippodamo, a breaker, tamer or rider
of horses. Hippodromo, a place where horses are excercised in games, races,
running or coursing. Hippofae, Hippofesto, a kind of herb. Hippofrigio,
Hippolidio, Hippodonio, certain kinds of music or accent in music.
Hippoglosso, the herb horse tongue or double tongue. Hippolapato, the herb
patience. Hippopotamo, as Hippotamo. Hippotamo, a beast living in the river
Nilus, having feet like an ox, back and maine like a horse, tucked like a
bore, and a long winding tail. Hipuro, a kind of lobster or sea-crab. Also the
herb cats tail or horse tail. Hirco, a wild bucke or he goat. Hirondinaria,
as Celidonia. Hirondine, the bird called a swallow. Hirsuto, hairie, brizlie,
shaggie, rough, haired, prickie, horride, sharp, sluttish. Hirto, as Hirsuto.
Hisopo, the herb hysop. Hispido, brizled, hairie, rough, pricked, sharp
haired. Hispidoso, as Hispido. Historia, an history, a story, a declaration
of true things in order set down, a true tale. Historiagrafare, as Historiare.
Historiale, historical. Historiare, to historize, to write or tell histories.
Historico, an historian or historical. Historiographo, an history writer.
Histrice, a porcupine. Histrione, a stage player, an interlude player.
Histrionia, the feate or science of stage plaiers. Hittiofagi, fish eaters or
feeders upon fish. Ho, of the verb Hauere, I have. Hobo, a tree, the root
whereof if a man hold but a piece of it in his mouth it yields so much water
as he shall feel no thirst. Hodierno, modern, of this day, a late man or
thing. Hoggi, this day, to day. Hoggidi, now adays, at these times. Hoggimai,
now at last, now adays, at length, at last. Hola, hoe? who is there? what hoe.
Holestio, a kind of herb. Holiostrophio, an herb, the touch whereof kills
Scorpions. Holla, Holle, I have her, I have them. Hollo, Holli, I have him or
it, or them. Holocausto, a sacrifice killed and laid whole on the Altar.
Homaccione, a great evil favored man, a lubbarly man, a loggarhead. Homai,
now, at last. Homaggio, homage, fealty, liegenes, fidelity. Homeri, the
shoulders. Hometto, a little man. Homicida, a manslayer, a killer of men.
Homicidiale, guilty of man's blood. Homicidio, manslaughter, murder.
Homicidioso, killing of men. Homicranca, a dizzines, or giddines in the head.
Homilia, a sermon, or homily. Homo, Huomo, a man. Homoemere, likeness of
parts, all the parts in a body that have affinity with the brain, liver,
and heart. Homogeneo, of one kind. Homographia, like writing or painting.
Homologia, a confession, a consent, an agreement. Homone, Homoncione, as
Homaccione. Homoncino, a little man. Homonea, concord, agreement. Homonimia,
when diverse things are signified by one word. Homori, humors, conceits.
Honesta, Honestade, honesty, truth, dignity, worship, honor. Honesta da
campi, a dissembling woman. Honestamente, honestly, indifferently. Honestare,
to make honest, to excuse, to color a fault. Honesto, honest, civil,
virtuous, upright. Also honesty it self. Honoranza, as Honor. Honorare, to
honor, to worship. Honorato, honored, worshipped. Honorando, worshipful,
worthy of honor. Honor, honor, worship, reputation, honesty, credit,
estimation, the reward of virtue. Honoreuole, honorable, worshipful.
Honoreuolezza, honor, worship, reputation. Honorificenza, honor, worship.
Honorifico, honorable, worshipful. Hor, now, at this instant, sometimes. Hora,
as Hor. Also an hour. Hora may, Hor may, now, at last, at length, in the end.
Horanza, as Honor. Horario, hourly, the space of an hour. Hora si, yea
marry now, now indeed. Horbene, well go too, it is well. Hor hora, by and by,
even now, presently. Horetta, a small short hour. Horfanita, orphanisme.
Horfano, an orphan, or fatherless child. Horgiata, a kind of meat or drink
made of barlie, barlie-water. Horgio, the grain we call barlie. Horiolo,
Horiuolo, an horologe, a dial, a clock, an hower-glasse, a watch. Horioletto,
Horiuoletto, as Horologio. Horiuolaro, an howreglasse maker. Horologiaro, a
clock-maker or keeper, a dyall maker. Horologiere, idem. Horologio, as Horiolo.
Horologio dal sole, a sun dial. Horoloio Horlogio, as Horologio. Horoscopo,
the ascendent of ones nativity, that part of the firmament that rises every
hour from the cast. Also any thing wherein hours be marked, as in dyall. Also
a diligent marking of the time of the birth of a child. Horizonte, the
horizon, a circle dividing the upper part of the sphere from the lower.
Hormisino, taffetie sarcenet. Hormino, the herb called Clarie, or sage of
Rome. Horranza, as Honor. Horrendo, horrible, frightfull, grizlie, gastfull,
ugly, hideous, dreadful, strange, to be eschued. Horreuole, honorable,
worshipful. Horreuolezza, as Honor. Horribile, as Horrendo. Horribilita,
horriblenes, horror, hideousnes, grizlines, fright, trembling for fear.
Horrido, horride, hideous, terrible, gastlie, grizlie, evil favored,
dreadful, frightfull, lothesome to behold. Horrifico, terrible, horrible, that
makes one quake for fear or cold. Horrisuono, roaring, or having a terrible
sound or voice. Horrore, a horror, a shiuering for fear or cold, a fright, a
terror, or shaking fit. Also a dreadful sound, a reverent fear, a frowning or
iowring co^^tenance. Also a loathing, as when one cannot away with a thing.

Hospitalita, hospitality, entertaing of friends and guests. Hospite, an host.
Also a guest. Also a friend that entertaineth strangers. Hospitoso, a man
keeping hospitality, full of hospitality. Hospitio, an inn or house of
lodging, ready to receive friends and guests. Hostaggio, Hostale, an hostage
or pledge, a surety or pawn. Hostaria, an inn or hosterie, a victualing
house, an alehouse, a tavern; but properly a house where meat and drink and
lodging for men and horse is to be had. Host, an host, a guest, being of the
masculine ginder. Host, an host, a camp or an army of men and soldiers,

Hosteriero. Hostello, an hostell, a house or place of receite, an habitation.

tame. Humiliatione, an humbling, humility, lowlines, meekenes. Humilimmo, most
humble. Humilta, Humilita, humility, lowlines, meekenes, gentleness. Humorale,

liquor, juice or sap. Also a toy, a humor, a fancy, a conceit. Also sap in a
root or tree. Humorista, humorous, fantastical, toyish, passionate in his

Also humorous, toyish, conceited, fond, unconstant, newfangled. Huoi, to day,
this day. Huomo, Huomini, a man, men. Huomo di bardella, a young rider that can

I
I, For Io, namely in verse; I, me self. Also a masculine article of the
plural number; they or the. Iacente, iacent, lying flat, flat. Iacolo, a dart,
and whatsoever else may be thrown, or cast with the hand. Also a kind of very
swift serpent. Iacono, a deacon, a degree among the clergy. Iaculatore, a
shooter, a darter, a dart, slinger. Iada, a kind of precious stone like an
emerauld. Iaia, grauellie sand, gravel. Iambi, certain verses called
Iambickes. Ianchetto, a fish called a pilchard or sparling. Ianizzeri, the
Turks guard, Ianizers. Iantino, as Hiacinto. Iapiga, the western wind; yet some
take it for the northcast wind. Iaspe, a precious stone called a iasper-stone.
Iatraleptica, curing by ointments and frications. Iattantia, bragging,
boasting, vaunting. Iattare, to brag, boast or vaunt. Iattatore, a bragger,
boaster or vaunter. Iattura, loss, damage, hurt, decay or casting away.
Iberide, the herb wild cresses. Some take it for another herb. Ibi, a kind
of bird in Egypt which has stiff legs and a long bill, wherewith when he is
sick he glistreth himself with salt water. And some write that Hippocrates
first learnd of this bird to give glisters. Icnografia, a plot, model or
frame of a house drawn in paper, describing every room of it. Ichneumone, a
rat of India which creeps into the crocodils mouth when he gapeth, and cating
his bowels kills him. I Would, the ides of every month, that is the eight day
after the nones, called so for dividing the month. Iddea, a goddess. Iddio,
God almighty. Idea, the idea, figure or form of anything conceived in
imagination. Ideale, ideally, figuratively, formely, imaginatiuely. Identia, an
imaginary figure of any thing. Idiachigiorni, the fatal, ill or unlucky
days that be in the year. Idioma, a proper perfect tongue, speech or language.
Idiomista, a man professing a proper language. Idiota, an ignorant, a sot, an
idiot, a natural, a fool. Idolatrare, to commit idolatry. Idolatria,
idolatry. Idolatro, an idolator. Idolo, an idol. Idoneo, convenient, fit,
apt, sufficient. Idromante, a soothsayer or deuiner by the air. Idromantia,
dinination by the air. Idropesia, the sickness which we call the dropsy.
Idropico, one troubled with the dropsy. Iella, the root of Elecampane or as
Enola. Iemo, a bottom or clue of thread. Ierda, as Ghierde. Ieri, yeasterday.
Ieuolo, a bird called a woodpecker or eatbill. Ifid^ino, a precious stone good
against the stone in the bladder. Ifsilonne, the letter y, so called in
Italian. Igiena, conseruatiua medicina. Ignauia, cowardnes, baseness of mind,
lithernes, dullnes, sluggishnes. Ignauo, a coward, a dastard, base of courage,
lither, dull, sluggish. Igneo, fiery, of the nature of fire. Ignite, a precious
stone of the color of glass. Ignobile, ignoble, infamous, unrespected, base,
dishonored. Ignobilita, ignobilitie, baseness. Ignocco, a fool, a sot, a patch,
a noddie, a gull, or a ninnie. Ignominia, ignominy, reproach, dishonor.
Ignominioso, ignominious, reproachful, dishonorable. Ignorante, ignorant,
unwitting, not knowing, dull, foolish. Ignorantesco, foolish, or
ignoraunt-like. Ignorantia, ignorance. Ignorare, to ignore, not to know, to be
ignorant of. Ignoto, unknown. Ignudo, naked, bare, void. Also a fish called a
dace or a merlune. Iguale, equal, alike, match. Igualare, to equal, to match,
to make even. Igualita, equality, likeness, euennes. Il, an article masc.
singular, the, namely with nounes. Also a pronoune primitive of the dative and
accusative cases, him the same, it, with verbs. Ileo, the third gut from the
ventricle. Iliaco dolor, an obstruction or stopping of the small guts, causing
a great pain in the belly. Ilio, Ilione, Illione, as Ileo. Ilio osso, that
bone which is committed or joined to the transaers processes of osso sacro,
albeit in old bodies this seem^th to be but one bone, yet because in children
it is by a cartilage intersected with three lines, therefore the anatomists
divide it into three parts, calling the first (which is the supreme part
thereof, being the broadest of the rest and joined to osso sacro) by the name
of the whole Ilio osso, the second osso pube, the third osso cossendico.

vnoffended. Illetamare, to vndoong, to cleanse, to farm. Illiberale, not
liberal, miserable, a snudge, a miser. Illiberalita, couetize, misery,
avarice. Illicito, as Illecito. Ilice, the tree called an oak. Illudere, ludo,
lusi, luso, to mock, to flout, to frump, to delude, to dazzle, to illude.
Illuiare, to turn or enter into another then himself. Illuminare, to
illuminat, to clear, to lighten, to brighten, to enlumine. Illuminatione, an
illumi^ation, a light or opening of the eyes. Illuminatore, an illuminator or
lightgiuer. Illusione, an illusion, a deluding, a mocking, dazzling. Illustrare,
to illustrate, to glorify, to brighten, to dignifie. Iullustratore, an
illustrator, a glorifier, a giver of honors. Illustre, clear, famous,
excellent, honorable, worthy, bright. Illustrezza, brightness, excellency,
woorthines, honor. Illustrissimo, most excellent, most worthy, most renowned.
Il perch, wherefore, the reason why. Ima, low, deep. Imaginabile, as
Imagineuole. Imaginare, to imagine, to think, to surmise, to devise, to
conceive. Imaginario, imaginary. Imaginatione, Imaginamento, an imagination or
surmising. Imaginatore, an imaginer, a thinker, a surmiser. Imaginatiua,
imaginatiue. Imagine, Imago, an image or likeness in form, a similitude, a
counterfeit, a vision, a sancie, an imagination, a figure, a pretense or color
for any matter. Imagineuole, imaginable, that may be imagined. Imbabolare, to
blubber with ones eyes. Imbacuccato, masked, muffled, hooded, hood winkt about

and dr^ssing up of meats. Imbandire, disco, dito, to swath or bandle about.
Also to cry or proclaim by proclamation: but properly to spread or lay the
boorde or cupboords, to play the sewer, to dish or dress up meat ready to be
carried up. Imbanditore, a gentleman sewer, a disher or dresser up of meats, a
laier of the tables. Imbarazzare, to disorder, to put to confusion, ruin,
spoil, or havoc, to trouble, to busy. Imbarazzo, trouble, confusion,
disorder, luggage, trumperie stuff, or an entangling. Imbarbare, as
Abbarbicare. Imbarbigliare, as Imbardare. Imbarberescare, to teach any creature
to do anything, as to teach a horse to run a race, to hunt a match, to come to
the staff, to enter a dog or a hawk, to enseame, the word is taken from
those that teach Barberie horses. Imbarbuglio, a garboile, a trouble, an
entangling. Imbarcare, to imbarke, to ship or take shipping. Also to cosen, to
setch over, to bring one into a fools paradise. Imbarcamento, a shipping or
imbarking. Imbardare, to bard or trap a horse. Also to love foolishly.
Imbardigliare, as Imbardare. Imbarilare, to barrel up, to imbarell.
Imbasciadore, Imbasciatore, an Ambassador. Imbasciata, an Embassage.
Imbascieria, idem. Imbastaggiare, to put a pack saddle, a pad or carriers

dito, as Imbastardare. Imbastinare, as Imbastaggiare. Imbastire, tisco, tito,
to put a pack saddle on. Also to stuff or quilt. Also to furnish, to store or
to be set. Imbasto, a pack saddle, a pad, a carriers saddle. Imbastonare, to
put any ensign upon a staff. Imbattagliare, to embattle. Imbattere, batto,
battei, battuto, to meet or light upon by chance. Also to fight or beat in.
Imbattimento, a meeting or lighting upon by chance. Imbattuto, met or light
upon by chance. Also foughten or beaten in. Imbauagliare, to enbib, to put a
bib before one. Imbaucare, to mask as women be when they go abroad.
Inbeccare, to embill or feed birds, to bill, to smouch. Imbeccata,
Imbeccatura, an embilling, a billing or feeding, a kissing, a smouching.
Imbeccatore, one that embilleth or feeds birds. Imbecherare, to put into ones
fancy or head, to teach, to instruct one to do or say any thing. Also to
deceive or bear false witness, to suborne. Imbecille, weak, feeble, faint.
Imbecilita, weakness, faintness, imbecilitie. Imbelle, weak, bare, unarmed,
naked, unapt to war, cowardous, timorous. Imbellettare, to paint as women do
their faces. Imbellettamenti, slauerings and paintings that women use upon
their faces. Imbellire, lisco, lito, to adorn, to beautify, to deck, to
embellish. Imbendare, to enskarffe, to hoodwinck, to blindfold. Imberbe,
beardles, without a beard. Imberciatore, a shooter in a hand-gun or fouling
piece. Imbertescato, made rampire wise or full of skaffolds. Imbertonato,
besotted, adulterously in love. Imbertestato, aloft or surmounting others.
Imbestialare, as Imbestiare. Imbestialire, as Imbestiare. Imbestiare, to become
a beast, wild or beastly. Imbeuere, to drink or suck in, to swallow or gulpe
up. Imbiaccare, to paint with ceruse or white lead. Imbiaccamento, a whitning,
a blanching or a washing white. Inbiancare, to whiten, to blanch, to wash
white, to become pale or wan. Imbiancheggiare, as Imbiancare. Imbianchire,
chisco, chito, as Imbiancare. Imbianchito, whitened or become pale or wan.
Imbiondire, disco, dito, to make yellow or of a golden color. Imbizzarire,
risco, rito, to become fond, mad or fantastical. Imboccamento, an mowthing or
an entrance. Imboccare, to feed or cram. Also to snatch with the mouth. Also
to stop the mouth of a cannon: also to run into some creek of the land as the
sea does in some places. Imboccata, a feeding or cramming. Also a mouthfull, a
mouthing. Imboccatura, the mouth of a horses bit. Also a mouthing. Imbolare, to
filch, to steal, to purloine, to lurche, to pilfer, to prowle. Imbolio, a
stealing, a filching, a larcenie, a theeuing. Imbollare, to mark with a
branding iron. Also to beplaster or be patch. Imbonire, nisco, nito, to make
good, to endeare. Imborbare, to bemire with dirt. Imborcare, to cloth with
cloth of gold. Imborgare, to enter in a town or borrough. Imborsare, to

to promise, to make an oath. Inurbare, to endenizen, to become or make a
citizen or a civil man. Inurbanita, inurbanitie, rudenes, discourtesie,
clownishnes, vnmannerlines. Inurbano, uncivil, discourteous, rude, clownish,
unmannerly, homely, discourteous. Inusitare, to vnuse, to forget, to leave off,
to disaccustome. Inusitato, unused, forgotten, disaccustomed, left off,
strangely, not wont. Inustione, an inward burning or scalding. Inutile,
unprofitable, to no use, unserviceable, nothing worth. Inutilire, lisco, lito,
to make void, to disanull, to make unprofitable and of no effect. Inutilita,
disprofit, inutilitie, unprofitableness. Inuulnerabile, that cannot be hurt,
wounded, pierced or thrust through the skin. Inuulnerato, unhurt, not wounded.
Inzaccherare, to defile, to make foul, to dash with dirt or mire. Inzafranare,
to die, to color or dress with saffron. Inzampognare, as Gonfiare alcuno.
Also as Infinocchiare. Also to put a bell about some cattles neck.
Inzamprognare, as Gonfiare alcuno. Inzazzeare, to go walking wantonly, idly or
feminatlie up and down the streets, to gaze up and down foolishlie.
Inzazzerare, to wear long locks of hair curled or bushie. Also to make the
hair on the head curled. Inzeppare, to fill brim full. Inzessare, to whiten or
color with chalk, to chalk. Inzoppare, to become or make one to halt or to
cripple. Inzuccherare, to sugar, to candie, to comsit, to cover with sugar.
Inzuccherata, any paste candied or made of sugar, a sugar cake. Inzuppare, to
sop, or lay in sops. Io, the first pronoune primitive, sing. I, my self. Also
a kind of wood that they use to make oars with. Io proprio, medesimo or
stesso, meselfe, I me self. Io per me, as for me, as for my self. Io
t'afferro, I have you fast, I know your mind. Io t'ho per il becco, I have you
by the bill, I have you by the fingers ends. Io t'ho dove si soffiano le noci,
I care not a turd for you. Io vi dico di no, I tell you no, I bid you no. Ione,
a kind of flower. Also a precious stone of the color of that flower, which
rubbed, draws paper and straw to it. Ionica, a kind of ancient
Architecture. Also a kind of music among the Grecians. Ionici, a kind of
verses so called. Iontio, a kind of raye or thornebacke fish. Iosa, plenty,
store, hold belly hold, good store, good plenty. Iota, a jot, a nifle,
nothing, a whit, a crumme, naught. Iozzo, as Ghiozzo. Iperborei, as Hiperborei.
Ippopatamo, a beast in India, with feet like an ox, back and maine like a
horse, tusked like a bore, and a long winding tail. Ipricon, the name of an
herb. Ipsilonne, the letter y. Ipostasi, as Hipostasi. Ira, anger, ire,
wrath, stomach, displeasure, choler, disdain, desire of revenge, vexation,
rage, or such passions that last not. Iracondia, Iracundia as Ira, but that
lasts. Iracondo, Iracundo, wrathful, angry, cholerike, moodie, fretfull,
raging, irefull, fumish, testie. Iradiare, to shine upon, to lighten, to cast
his beams upon, to flare, to stream. Iradiatione, an inlightning or casting
of beams. Iradiante, shining upon, lightning, or casting his beams upon,
flaring, glistring, streaming. Iragioneuole, as Irationale. Irare, to anger, to
wroth, to vex, to fret, to displease, to rage. Irato, angered, wroth, vexed,
fretted, grieved, moved, raged. Irascere, to be angry, moved, or displeased,
to grieve, or be sorry for. Irascibile, subject to anger or wroth, or rage,
unreasonable. Irationale, unreasonable, brutish, without humane reason.
Irationalita, unreasonableness, brutishnes. Ire, Gire, Andare, to go, to wend,
to walk, to march, to wander, to yode. Ireconciliabile, inexpiable, that can
admit no reconciliation. Ireiate, a kind of precious stone. Irice, a hedgehog.
Iride, as Irride. Iringio, a kind of shrub or pricking weed. Iringo campestre,
as Eringo campestre. Iritare, as Irritare. Irios, a kind of sweet white root
called oris-roote. Iritatione, as Irritatione. Iritire, to make void, of no
force or effect, to disappoint, to assuage or mollify. Iritto, unlawful,
undue, unfit, unright. Ironia, a figure in speaking when one means contrary
to the word, a mocking or skoffing. Ironico, erroneous, mocking, meaning
contrary to his words. Iroso, wrathful, cholerike, angry. Irpice, a rake
with iron teeth, wherewith they pull up weeds and roots. Irragioneuolezza,
unreasonableness. Irragioneuole, as Irrationale. Irrecompensabile, that can not
be requited. Irrecordabile, that can not be remembered. Irrecuperabile,
unrecoverable. Irregolare, irregular, void of rule, subject to no order.
Irregolarita, irregularitie, disorder, confusion, want of order, rule or form.
Irregulare, as Irregolare. Irregularita, as Irregolarita. Irreligione,
irreligion, ungodliness. Irreligioso, irreligious, profane, vndeuous, ungodly,
without fear of God. Irremeabile, never to return or pass again.
Irremediabile, remediless, not to be redressed, irremediable, recurelesse.
Irremissibile, irremissible, that can not be forgiven or remitted.
Irremunerabile, that can not be rewarded or recompensed. Irreparabile, that can
not be withstood, warded, resisted, or repaired. Irreprehensibile, faultlesse,
that can not be reproved, without fault. Irreprobabile, as Irreprehensibile.
Irrepugnabile, as Irreparabile. Irresolutione, an irresolution, an
uncertainty. Irresolubile, that can not be resolved, or determined.
Irresoluto, irresolute, unconstant, uncertain, wavering. Irretare, to entrap,
to entangle, to ensuare or take in a net or ginne, to entramell, to ennet.
Irretire, tisco, tito, as Irretare. Irreuerente, vnreuerent, rude, unmannerly.
Irreuerentia, irreverence, rudeness. Irreuocabile, irreuocable, that can not
be revoked or called back. Irride, the rainebow. Also a flower deluce. Also a
kind of precious stone which sparkles all the colors of the rainebow. Also
the circle which is between the white and the apple of the eye, replenished
with diverse colors. Irridere, rido, risi, riso, as Deridere. Irrigare, to
water ground, or fields, to bring water into fields by little gullets, to
stream or streake along. Irrigamento, a watering of any fields by little
gullets. Irrimissibile, unpardonable, that can not be remitted, irremissible.
Irrisione, as Derisione. Irritabile, quickly moved to anger. Irritare, to
provoke, to kindle wrath, to move, to stir, to incense to anger. Irritatione,
a provocation, an incensing, or moving to wrath. Irritire, tisco, tito, as
Irretare. Irrito, void, of no effect or force, nothing worth, vain, blunt,
that can not hurt. Irrocare, to have a boarse voice, to wax hoarse.

frown and wrinkle ones brow. Irrugiadare, as Irrogiadare. Irrugiadoso, dewie,

lion. Irrugginire, nisco, nito, to rust, or grow rustie. Irrugginoso, rustie,
full of rust. Irrumare, to commit all manner of villainy or mischief. Irtare,
to thrum, to make rough, hairie or brislie. Irto, thrummed, rough, hairie,
brislie. Also high or steepie, or upright, as Erto. Also foul or filthy.

of miles, as the gestes or remooues of princes. Itinere, a way, a passage, a
going, a trade, a course, or a mean. Ito, Gito, gone, wandered, marched,
walked. Itteritia, as Mal verde. Ittiocola, a great fish which some take for a
Sturgeon. Iua, ground pine, herb iuie, or field cipres. Iuane, a kind of
serpent in India, which is very good meat. Iubar, the day star called also
Lucifer. Also brightness, or a sun beam. Iugero, as Giugero. Iugulare, as
Giocolare. Iui, Quiui, there, yonder, in that place, thither. Iui a non guari,
not long after. Iulca, Look Foce. Iumenta, as Giumenta. Iurisconsulto, as
Giurisconsulto. Iurisdittione, as Giurisdittione. Iurista, a lawyer, a
professor of the laws. Iusdicente, as Giurisconsulto. Iuspatronato, as
Giuspatronato. Iusquesito, a rightful, just, or lawful demand or suit.
Iusquiano, the herb henbane.
L
LA, an article of the feminine gender, the, but being joined with a verb it
is a pronoune, she, her, it, or the same. It is sometimes an aduerbe of place,
there, thither, yonder, or in that place. It is also a note in music, La. La
dove, whereas, whether, whereupon. Labante, fainting, drooping, decaying.
Labarda, a halbard. Labaro, a streamer, banner, or ensign that is hung up in
churches over noble men's tombs. Also a rich banner or streamer, beset with
precious stones that till Constantine his time, who commanded the figure of the
cross to be carried before him, was wont to be carried before the emperors,
and was worshipped of the soldiers. Labbia, Labbra, the lips, the brims of any
thing. also a man's look or countenance. Labbro, Labro, a lip. Also the brim
or brinke of a fountain, the brim, tip, or edge of a pots mouth, or any thing
else. Labroso, Labbruto, that has big lips, or is well lipped. Labdace,
filthiness in the mouth. Labdoide, that suture or seame which is in the hinder
part of the head and in the foundation thereof, where it goes on both sides
toward the ear, the going up of which in the beginning is broad, but ascending
higher becomes narrower. Labe, a spot, a blot, or a blemish. Also a violent
fall or torrent of rain waters. Labile, to wash with, sliding, slipperie, or
fading, faint or weak, unstable. Labirinto, Labirintho, a laberinth or place
full of intricate windings and turnings, made in such wise that whosoever came
into it could not get out again without a perfect guide, or without a thread
directing him, the clew or bottom whereof should be left at the entry, we
call it a maze. It is also taken for an oration, or any other thing very
intricate, difficult, and entangled. Labizo, a kind of gum not much, unlike to
myrrh, but much more odoriferous and precious. Labole, weak, faint.
slipperie, flitting. Laborioso, laborious, painful, taking pains, difficill,
wearisom. Labretto, a little lip. Labrusca, as Lambrusca. Laca, as Lacca. Also
a rock, a cliffe, a downfall, a ruinous hill. Lacca, white lead, or a kind of
gum. Also a ditch, a puddle, a poole, or muddie place. Lacca ogliata, a kind
of ointment for swelling. Lacche, taken for spaniels with long flapping ears.
Lacchietto, the sweet bread of a breast of veale. Lacchia, as Laccia, Chieppa,
or Alosa. Also a kind of drink made of spices. Laccia, a fish called a
chewme, others take it for a blaye or a bleake. Lacciare, to tie, to bind, to
lace, to claspe, to snare or entangle, to tramell. Laccietto, as Lacciolo.
Laccio, a snare, a tramell, a binding, a lace, a spring or gin to catch birds
with Also a fish who for desire of a vain in a tunnies iawe kills him: a
latchet. Lacciolo, Lacciuolo, a little snare, tramell, binding, ribond, lace,
or string: a latchet of a shoe. Also a maze. Lacerabile, that may be torn.
Lacerare, to tear, to rende, to totter in pieces, to mangle, to dismember, to
torment. Lacerna, a kind of cloak to keep the rain out. Lacero, Lacerato,
torn, rent, ragged, tottred in pieces, mangled, dismembered. Lacerto, the
braune or sinews or muscles of a man's arms or legs. Also the arm from the
elbow to the pitch of the shoulder. Also a muskle because it is like a lizard.
Also a fish which some say grunteth as a hog, and other some take to be the
makrell. Also a lizard. Also a kind of disease in a horse among the muscles
and sinews. Lache, a lackie or footeman. Lachetta, a gum called gum lack.
Lacchezzini, prouokings, enticements, allurements, drifts, devices, sleights.
Lacessitore, he that provoke or abuses one in speech. Lacessire, sisco,
sito, to provoke, stir, or egg a man to wrath, to abuse in speech, to rail
against one, to vex and molest. Lacessita, provoking, provocation, vexation,
or abusing in speeches. Lacinio, a barbers basin, or a milk pan. Lacinioso,
cut in sundry fashions, iagged, snipt, crumpled, full of plaits, intricate,
crankling in and out. Lacno, a dogs name, as we say a shaghaire or ruffian.
Laco, Lago, as Lago. Laconico, brief, laconicall, short, witty, or compendious
in speaking. Laconismo, a short kind of speaking containing in few words much
matter. Laconizzare, to speak compendiouslie. Lacrima, a tear in weeping, a
drop, a trilling, a trickling. Also rosin, turpentine or gum drops.
Lacrimabile, lamentable, to be bewailed. Lacrimare, to weep, to shed tears,
to distill, drop, or trill in tears, to trickle. Lacrimale, Lacrimeuole, as
Lacrimoso. Lacrimoso, weeping, wailefull, whining, distilling tears or drops,
trickling, full tears, sorrowful, lamentable, shedding tears. Lacuna, a
marsh, a moore, a fen, a fennie, marish or waterish ground, a ditch wherein
water stands, a furrowe or trench whereby fields are drained. Lacunoso,
fennie, moorish, or waterish, full of ditches or holes. Lada, a swift runner.
Also a kind of Iuie. Also a kind of Cassia smelling like wine mingled with
spices. Ladano, a kind of sweet gum to perfume with. Also a kind of fish.
Ladetta, a hymn, a psalm or song of praise. Ladino, large, wide, broad. Also
easy and facile. Ladone, the name of a dog as we say harier, or hunt hair.
Ladoue, whereas, there where. Ladrarie, as Ladroncellerie. Ladro, a thief, a
stealer, a filcher, a pilfrer. Ladronare, to filch, to steal, to pilfre or
play the thief. Ladroncello, a little thief, stealer, filcher or pilfrer.
Lardoncellerie, pilfring, stealing, or filching tricks. Ladroncellesco,
theeuish, pilfring. Ladrone, a great or old thief, a high way thief.
Ladroneccio, theft, larcenie, theeuing, stealing, filching, pilfring.
Ladroneggiare, to play the thief, to steal. Lagana, a kind of chough in
India. Lagagnosia, weakness, sloth, faintnes, lazines, negligence, idleness,
lithernes. Lagare, as Allagare. Lagari, a kind of bird. Lagaro, the part of
the body from the stomach to the navel. Laghetto, a little lake, pond, or
poole. Laggio, the aloye or loss of money by exchange, coining or bank.
Lagiono, as Lambena. Lagna, sorrow, trouble, grief, vexation, wailing, moning,
complaining. Lagnare, to wail, to lament, to bemone, to complain. Lago, a
lake, a meare, a poole, a fen, a marrish, a deep place always full of waters.
a kind of foul that always loves storms and foul weather. Lagopo, the herb
haresfoote. Some take it for trinity grass or trinity herb. Lagotalmo, a
disease in the eyes, when as the upper eielid does not move downewarde.
Laguna, as Lacuna. Lagunoso, as Lacunoso. Lagrima, as Lacrima. Lagrimabile,
Lagrimeuole, as Lacrimoso. Lagrimare, as Lacrimare. Lagrimoso, as Lacrimoso.

a horses bit, so called by Grison. Lai, lays, wailings, lamentations, moanes,
complaints. Laia, sea grass, ducke weed or reeke. Laico, a layman, a temporal
man, a secular man. Also popular or vulgar. Laidezza, filthiness, foulenes,
deformity, ilfauourednes. Laido, filthy, foul, deformed, ill-favored.

thanksgiving song. L'althrieri, the other day, the day before yeasterday.
Lama, a blade of any sword, any thin plate of iron to make armor with, any

standing water, poole or puddle or deep ditch with little water in it. Also a
gad of steel. Lambena, a fish which changes his color: for all the year she
is white, and in the spring time speckled. Lambicare, to distill, to limbecke.
Lambicatore, a distiller of waters. Lambichi, stillatories or stils. Lambire,
bisco, bito, to lick or lap with the tongue, to touch softly, to flow, to
glide or slide softly. Lambrace, a fish which having swallowed the hook, does
so much shake himself that he castes it out again. Lambrusca, Lambrasca,
wild, desert, savage, rural. Also a kind of sour wine. Lambruscare, to
prune, to crop or trim the vines. Lamella, a thin plate of metal. Lamentanza,
as Lamentatione. Lamentabile, as Lamenteuole. Lamentare, to lament, to
complain, to bewail, to waiment, to weep or mourn for. Lamentatione, a

moanings, complaints. Lamento, as Lamentatione. La mia passera e nel nido, a
kind of christmas game used in Italy, called my sparrow is in her neast.
Lamia, a beast that has a man's face and the feet like a horse. Also a sea-dog
or dog-fish. Also a kind of fish that has so great a iawe, and is so ravenous
that it will devour an armed man. Also a witch, a sorceresse or a hag. Also
women that were thought to have such eyes as they could put out and put in at
their pleasure, or rather certain devils in a counterfeit shape, which with
flatterings allured fair young springals and boys, and taking upon them the
likeness and fashion of women were thought to devour them and bring them to
destruction. Some thought them to be ladies of the fairies or such as make
children afraid, or such witches as suck childrens blood to kill them. Also
an arche, a vault or such hollow place. Used also for a whore or harlot or
shameless woman. Lamina, any kind of flat stone, plate or slate, wedge or sow
or ingot of metal, as a gad of steel, a thin plate of iron or any other
metal; namely such as they make tags for points. Also a gad of steel or
iron, a shingle or slate. Lamio, dead or blind nettle, archangell. Lamiola, a
kind of dog-fish. Lampada, Lampana, a lamp. Also a torche. Also a leame of
fire or brightness. Lampante, bright, glistring, shining. Lampare, as
Lampeggiare. Lamparo, a lamp-maker. Also the socket of a candlestick.
Lampasco, a disease in a horse called the lampase, it comes in the mouth.

growing among corn. Lampuro, white tail or fox. Lana, any kind of wool.

hurdes of flax or hemp. Also there or in that place. Also the ends, the thrum
or threads of a seluage, or weauing threads at the end of a web of cloth.
Licinia, the base or slat varuen. Also a kind of olives. Licio, box thorn or
thorn box. Licischo, a dog engendered of a woulfe and a dog. Licitare, as
Lecitare. Licito, as Lecito. Licofo, clear light or the first appearing of day
light. Liconobio, he that in stead of the day uses the night, one that turns
day into night. Licontopia, a kind of disease or passion in the brain.
Licopo, the herb motherwoort. Licopodio, a kind of moss called woulfes clawe.
Licopside, garden buglosse. Some take it for hounds tongue. Licoptalmo, a stone
of four colors. Licore, liquor or moistnes. Licorno, as Lioncorno.
Licostaphilo, water elder or dwarf plane tree. Licostomo, a kind of long fish.
Licotono, a kind of poison that hunters use to kill woulfes. Licuide, a kind
of herb bearing a fine flower. Lidio, a kind of mournful solemn music.
Also a touchstone to try gold and silver. Lido, a bank, a side, a coast, or
shore or strond of the sea, or of a river. Liduna, the ebbing of the sea.
Lienteria, a kind of flux of the stomach and belly, which can keep nothing
therein, but presently voideth the same undigested. Lienterico, one sick of
the flux of the stomach. Liepre, a hare, as Lepre. Liesena, as Lesena. Lioto,
glad, merry, joyful, pleasant, glee, buckesome, joyous, frollike, luckie,
fortunate, battle, fruitful, cheerful. Lieua, a bender to bend a crossebow
with, a rack, a gaffel. Also a leauer, an iron crow or such to lift up any

unto it. Liguro, an eft, a lizard, a nute or ask. Ligustico, Lombardie louage.

the noise whereof can not be hard, thieves use them. Limaca, Limaga, as Lumaca.
Limaccioso, muddie, durtie, boggie, mirie, slimie. Limare, to file, to fret, to

Linaccio, course flax. Also canuas, or holland cloth. Linaloe, the aloes tree,

Lincur^o, a stone which is congealed of the urine or water of a luzard, which

line, the vmbelicall vein. Lineale, lineall, successiue. Lineamenti,

Linfico, a kind of precious stone. Lingua, a tongue. Also language or speech.

long ridge running into the sea like a tongue blearing out of the mouth. Also a
kind of herb good against the falling of the hair. Linguaccia, herb adders

hot ague or fever, but outwardly very cold. Liposichia, a swouning when one
seems to be dead. Lippa, a trap or cat, such as children play at. Lippare,
Lipare, to cry or pule like a kite. Lippitudine, a blearednes, rednes, or
running of sore eyes. Some call it a bleare-eyednes, or bloudshot of the eyes.

sandblinde, poreblinde, or dim of sight, as Leppo. Liptota, a figure, when as
the force of words is not answerable to the matter. Lippoftalmia, an
inflammation through sharp humors in the eyes which makes them almost blind.
Liquabile, moist, liquid, full of liquor. Also which may melt. Liquefare,

agglutinations, but behind with the parts or additions of the Suture
Labdoides. Litica, Litiga, a litter, a horse litter to carry sick folks in.

bladder. Litra, a worm in a dogs tongue, which makes him mad if it be not
taken out. Littori, sergeants or such like ministers to execute corporal
punishment among the Romans. Lituo, a crooked staff that augures used in
divination to point the quarters of the firmament. Also a crosier or bishops

disputation according to the art of logike without rhetorical ornaments.

precious stones. Loglio, cockle or darnell growing amongst corn. Logista, he
that casts an account or does diligently weigh a thing, one that causes

in the equinoctial, and begins at the fortunate and Canarie islands. Longo,
long, tedious, irksome, importunate. Longone, a long gangrill, a slim, a long

Lucanica, Lucaniga, a pudding, a haggas, a sausage. Lucanicaro, a pudding

Lucere, luco, lucei, luciuto, to shine, to give light, to be bright. Lucerna, a

eft or lizard. Luchela, as Loquela. Luchetto, as Locchetto. Luci, lights,
