Lucidezza, shining, brightness, glistring, splendour. Lucignola, a kind of
serpent. Lucifero, that brings light. Lucifugo, that flies light and loves
darkness. Lucignolare, to give fire with a match, to put week or cotton in a
candle or lamp. Also to frounze, or curle, or dress up in fine knots as women
now a days do their hair. Lucignolato, I find used for an abrome color of a
woman's hair. Lucigno, a week, a match or cotton of a lamp or of a candle.
Lucignoli, or Lucignuoli, locks, flocks, tuffs, tassels, or feakes of wool,
hemp, hairs or flax, roules of wool or flax ready for the spinners, a lock
of hairs, peakes or tips of beards. Also weeks or cottons of candles. Also
certain sliding knots, entramelings or curlings of hairs wrought and
enterlaced together with ribands, and made in rings as women wear. Also
matches or match cords, as musketeers use. Lucignoletti, the diminutiue of
Lucignoli. Lucimoni, men so called of their madness, because they made those
places unhappy or unlucky whereunto they came. Lucinio, pink-eide or that
has little eyes. Lucio, a child borne at the sun rising. Lucisco, one that
sees little in the night and in the morning. Luco, a thick grove or wood
untouched and uncut, consecrated to gods or nymphs. Lucore, a great light or
blaze or splendour. Lucrare, to gain, to profit, to win, to get. Lucro, lucre,
gain, profit, vantage. Lucroso gainful, profitable, full of lucre.
Lucubratione, a study or work by candle. Lucubrare, to make or study by
candle light. Luculentia, brightness, shining, beauty. Luculento, full of
light, brightness, shining fair, beautiful, pleasant. Luculleo, a kind of
bright shining marble. Lucumone, a man that makes the place unhappy where he
comes. Ludificatione, a deceiving, a mocking. Ludibrio, a mock, a mockery,
or mocking stock to be laughed at. Ludro, a hawks lure. Also a bait.
Ludimaestro, a schoolmasters. Lue, a plague, a pestilence or murrian, or
common destruction in men and cattle. It is also used for the french pox.
Luffo, the skirt or quarter of a cote or ierken. Also a lap or fold of a
garment. Luganiga, Luganica, a pudding or sausage. Luganigaro, a pudding maker.
Luganighette, little small puddings or sausages. Lugarino, a bird called a
siskin, some take it for a goldfinch, and others for a canarie bird. Lugaro,
Luganello, as Lugarino. Luggiala, the name of an herb that is sharp in taste.
Luglio, the month of Iulie. Lugubre, mourning, wailing, grievous, sorrowful,
lamentable, funeral. Also mourning apparel. Lui, Lu, he, the same, him. Lui
medisimo, or stesso, himself. Lulla, a barell, a pipe or hog shead, the
bottom board of a barrel, a teale board to make barrels with. Lulligine, a
kind of sea fish near Mauritania which coming in a skull is able to
overthrow a ship. Lumaca, Lumaga, any kind of snaile. Scala a lumaca, a
winding pair of stairs. Lumaca di mare, a sea snaile, or perawinkle, or other
kind of cockle. Lumacone, a great snaile, a gull, a loggerhed, a ioulthead, a
patch, a lubie, a sneaker, a lurking companion. Lumbagine, feeblenes, pain, or
ach in the loins. Lumbi, the loins, hanches, flanks, or raines of a body,
that part of a body we call the chine. Also the ridges of a house Lumbolo, a
little loyne or leg. Lumbrici, little easses or earth-wormes. Also worms
breeding in any creatures belly, belly worms, or mawe worms. Lumbricelli,
very little earth worms or mawe worms. Lumare, to light, to kindle, to
lighten, to give light. Lumato, lighted, kindled, lightened, given light. Lume,
a light, a lamp, a candle, a brightness, a shining, the seeing or sight of the
eye, or the eye of a man alone. Lume di rocca, roche alume. Lume scaiola, a
kind of allome so called. Lume zuccarina, a kind of allome so called. Lumi,
lights, lamps, candles, shinings, the eyes. Lumia, the slime of fishes.
Lumicino, a little light. Lumiera, as Lume. Luminare, to shine, to give light,
to kindle, to illuminate. Also as Luminario. Luminato, shined, given light,
kindled, illuminated. Also a light or lightning. Luminario, a light, a lamp, a
beacon, a sign fire, a torch. Luminoso, bright, splendent, shining,
transparent. Lumoso, bright, shining, brightsome. Luna, the moon, one of the
seven planets. Also the metal silver according to alchimists phrases. Luna
nuona, the new moon. Luna piena, the full moon. Lunare, of or pertaining to
the moon, like the moon, made like a half moon, crooked, two horned, or
with two peakes like the moon. Also the monthly disease of women. Luna scema,
the waining moon. Lunaria, the herb called torch herb or woollblade.
Lunario, a calendar of the moon, or monthly almanacke. Lunaticare, to be
lunatike or frantike. Lunatico, lunatike, frantike or frenzy at certain times
of the moon, a kind of staggring, or falling disease in a horse, moon sick.
Lune, moons. Also monday, the first day of the week. Lunedi, monday.
Lunetta, a little moon, a cressant. Lunette, a kind of horse shoes, called
half moon shoes. Also the name of a goldsmiths tool. Also loope-holes, and
glasses to look through to keep the dust out of ones eyes in riding. Also
spectacles. Lungagnola, a fishing rod, a fishing pole, an angling rod.
Lungamente, a long time, very long time. Lungare, to prolong, to lengthen, to
stretch forth in length. Lunge, Lungi, far off, far away, wide off, distant,
asunder, far. Lungheria, length, tediousnes, a long flim flam tale, a delay, a
demur. Lunghetto, somewhat long or tedious. Lunghezza, as Longhezza. Lungi, as
Lunge. Lungo, as Longo. Lungone, as Longone. Luogare, Luocare, as Locare.
Luogo, Luoco, a place, a seat, a stead, a rome. Also a state, condition, case,
quality, credit, reputation or account. Also occasion, estimation, leisure,
calling. Also a family, a house, a kindred or country. Also a point in the
tables or in the check board. Luogora, places. Luogotenente, Luocotenente, a
lieutenant, a vicegerent, a substitute, a deputy, a vicar. Lupa, a she wolf,
a disease called a wolf, a disease about a horses legs. Lupaga, a kind of
sea-crab or lobster. Lupanari, stews, brothels or baudie houses. Also wolfes
dens. Lupasso, a gournard, a redfish or a rotchet fish. Some take it for a
dace. Lupato, a horse of a wolfes color, a kind of bright dunne color.
Lupazzo, as Lupasso. Lupeca, Lupecca, a bird called a houp or dunghilcocke.
Some think it to be the lapwing. Lupegaiare, to play the wolf, to howl as a
wolf, to devour greedily. Lupercalia, solemn sacrifices and plays dedicated
to Pan. Luperci, certain priests of Pan. Lupertica, the print, the mark, the
bruze, or swelling of a blow, the black and blew skin after a stripe or blow.
Lupicini, young wolfes, whelp-wolfes. Lupi di fiume, a fish called a sea wolf.
Lupino, a kind of pulse called Lupines or figbean^* Lupo, a wolf. Also a kind
of fish that some take to be a pike. Also a disease called a wolf. Also a kind
of hook or drag to draw things out of a pit, a well or such deep place. Lupo
ceruiero, a beast like a wolf, but spotted and exceeding quick of sight, it
does somewhat resemble a stag which we call a luzarde. Lupo del' api, a
wood-pecker or eate-bill. Lupuli, Lupoli, the herb hop or hops, to brew beer
with. Lurco, Lurcone, a glutton, a cormorant, an Epicure, a gurmond. Lurido,
pale, wan, black and blew. Luriuole, a kind of plum in Italy. Luscignolo,
Lussignolo, a nightingall. Lusciolo, a night bat, a rear mouse. Lusco, as
Losco, purblind. Lucello, a gold-smithes or founders tool. Lusinga, flattery,
adulation, fauning, inticement, allurement, blandishment. Lusingare, to
flatter, to entice, to faune, to allure, to blandish or to claw with fair
words. Lusingaria, as Lusinga. Lusingatore, a flatterer, an inticer, a fauner,
an allurer, a blandisher. Lusingatrice, a woman flatterer, etc. Lusingheuole,
flattering, enticing, alluring, etc. Lusone, a gamster, a player. Lusquiame,
something about Alchimie. Also the herb called Henbane. Lussare, to commit or
live in all voluptuousnes, luxury, and sensuality. Lusso, all manner of
voluptuousnes, luxury, sensuality or worldly pleasure. Lussurare, as
Lussuriare. Lussureggiare, as Lussuriare. Lussuria, leacherie, lust, uncleanness
of life, luxury, all superstuitie and excess in carnal pleasures, riot or
ranknes. Lussuriare, to commit leacherie, to be leacherous, luxurious or
wanton, to exceed in carnal pleasures, and all manner of riot. Lussurioso,
leacherous, luxurious, lustful, wanton, riotous, rank. Lustra, a den, a grot,
a cauerne, a hole where wild beasts do abide. Also a jest or a mockery. Also
a show or proffer to do any thing, a countenance upon any matter. Also a
compassing or going about a matter with fair words. Lustrale, certain
sacrifices or ceremonies that were used every five years, Look Lustro.
Lustrare, to give a luster or a glass, to shine. Also to offer sacrifice once
in five years, as some ancients were wont to do. Also to purge, to cleanse, to
prune. Also to shine, to brighten, to lighten, to burnish or give a glass
unto, to sleeke paper. Luster, Look Fare le luster. Lustrezza, brightness,
clearnes, shining. Lustro, a luster, a glass, a shining. Also the space or
time of five years. Lustrore, as Lustro. Lustroso, shining, bright, clear,
splendent. Luta, a sparcke or sparckle of fire. Lutello, an oil pot, an oil
vessel. Luteo, yellowish or somewhat yellow in color like the yolke of an
egg. Luterani, Protestants, or of Luthers religion. Lutero, a kind of beast so
called. Luto, a kind of deep measure of dry things. Lutta, wrestling.
Luttare, to wrestle. Also to dirt, to mire. Also to mourn, to blubber.
Luttatore, a wrestler. Lutto, Luto, weeping, wailing, mourning, blubbring,
dirt, mire, mud. Luttoso, Lutoso, mourning, wailing, wailfull, muddie, durtie,
mirie. Luttulente, as Luttoso. Luttuoso, as Luttoso. Luzziola, as Lucciola.
Luzziolo, as Lucciolo. Luzzo, as Luccio.
M
MA, but, except, but that, but if. Also joined with other words used for Mia.
Mache? but what? but then? but that. Mapoi, but then, if then, but after.
Mapure, but yet, nevertheless. Ma se, but if, what if Macalepo, a kind of
perfume or sweet smell. Macanopoietico, an inginer, an engine-maker. Macarco,
a barrel, a tub, a steane, a fat or vat or tun. Macarello, the fish called
mackrel, which comes in April. Some have taken Macarello, for a band or a
pander. It is taken from the French. Some take it for a ravenous foul.
Maccagnano, as Magagna. Macca, a bruise, a spot, a tainting. Also a frocke or
such like garment. Also plenty, store, Gods plenty, hold belly hold. Maccare,
to bruise, to batter, to pester. Also to spot, to taint. Maccatura, a bruise, a
spot. Maccarone, a gul, a doult, a patch, a fool a lubber, a loggerhead.
Maccaroni, a kind of paste meat boiled in broth, and dressed with butter,
cheese, and spice. Maccheroni, as Maccarone. Macchia, a spot, a blemish, a
speckle, a note of infamy or reproach. Also a brake, a bramble, a bush, a
brier, a firrie place, a purley, a shrub, a thicket of briers. Macchia nel'
occhio, a pin and web or blemish in ones eye. Macchiare, to spot, to blemish,
to bespeckle. Macchietta, a little spot or blemish. Also a little brake, bush,
or bramble. Macchione, a great brake, bramble, bush, or place full of firres.
Macco, plenty, store, hold belly hold. Maccole, spots, freckles, specks,
blemishes. Maccoloso, speckled, freckled, or spotted. Macedonica, the name of
an herb. Macellaio, Macellaro, a butcher, a slaughterer. Macellare, to kill,
to butcher, to slaughter, to shamble. Macello, a butchery, a shambles, a
slaughterhouse, a flesh market. Macerare, to macerate, to mortify, to
suppress, to tame, to make wanne, to weaken, to mortify with beating or
pressing, to soke or steep in water. Macerie, leanenes, barrennes. Also a row
or set of teeth. Macerie herb, all manner of usual known pothearbs. Macero,
Look Macerare, torn, tottered, ragged, hauocked. Maceroni, a kind of herb
good for sallets. Match, a kind of beast that has no ioints in her legs. Ma
che, but, only, except, but what. Machera, a kind of curtelaxe or woodknife.
Machila, the robe of the Ephod made altogether of blue silk, having round
about the skirts thereof 72. pomegranats of blue silk and purple and scarlet,
and as many bells of gold between them round about. Machina, a frame, an
engine, a devise, a building, an edifice, an invention, an instrument. Also a
conspiracy, a stratagem, a contriuing, a plot, a complot, a skaffold in
building. Machinare, to frame, to devise, to build, to complot, to contriue, to
conspire. Machinatione, a complot, a conspiracy, a contriuing, a framing, a
subtle invention or devising. Machinatore, a framer, a deviser, a builder, a
contriuer, a conspirer, an inuentor, an author, a maker of engines. Macido,
filthy, pale, hoarie, mustie, soft, rotten, mouldie. Macignare, to grow
rustie, rough, rugged, hard, stony, or crabbed. Macigno, rustie, grettie,
stony, rough, rugged, crabbed, grisly, stearne, filthy, pale, hoarie,
mustie, rotten, mouldie, a kind of gray hard stone. Macilente, lean, meagre,
gant, barren, thin. Macilenza, leanenes, meagernes, gantnes. Macina, a
millstone, or grinding stone. Macinare, to grind. Macinato, ground, or
grinded. Also greast or corn to grind. Macinatore, a miller, a grinder.
Macinatura, a grinding. Macine, taken for the teeth and jaws together,
grinding stones, millstones. Macinella, a little mustard mill for a kitchen.
Macinette, little grinding millstones. Also little mils. Also a kind of
shrimps or praunes. Macinio, the grinding or greest. Also taken for carnal
copulation. Macis, the spice we call mace. Maciulla, Macciula, a brake to
kneade dowe withal, or a block to break hemp or flax upon. Maciullare,
Macciullare, to break or beat hemp or flax, after it is dry. Macola, as
Macchia, a spot, a blot, a blemish, an infamy, or reproach. Macolare, as
Macchiare. Macrare, to make or grow lean. Macrezza, leanenes, gantnes,
meagernes. Macro, lean, meagre, gant. Macrologia, long and tedious talk,
wherein is no substance, frivolous idle speech. Macula, as Macchia. Maculare,
as Macchiare. Maculoso, full of spots, freckles, or speckles. Madaglio della
campana, the clapper of a bell. Madale, a barrow hog. Madarazzo, a clown, a
loobie, a loggerhead, a gross fellow. Madeno, no forsooth, no indeed. Madesi,
yea forsooth, yes indeed. Madera, a kind of stuff to dye red withal, called
Mather. Madia, a spokeshaue, a maund to put in bread. Also a kneading tub, a
hutch. Madoni, treene dishes, bowls or treyes of wood used in a kitchen.
Madonna, mistres, mistresmine, madam. Also taken for our lady. Madonna no, no
forsooth mistres, no madame. Madonna si, yea mistres mine, yes madame. Madre, a
mother, a damme. Also taken for the earth. Also the disease called the mother.
Also a woman's womb or matrix. Look Matre. Madrebosco, woodbinde, boniesuckle.
Madremagna, the earth who is the mother and bringer forth of all things. Madre
perla, mother of pearl. Madre selua, woodbinde or bonniesuckle. Madregna, a
stepdam or mother in law. Madremma, Madrema, my mother, my mam, as children
say. Madrezzuola, as Madrebosco. Madrifoglio, knapweede, bullweede, or
matfellon. Madrigali, Madriali, madrigals, a kind of short songs or ditties in
Italy. Madrigaletti, short madrigals. Madrigna, Madrina, a stepdame, a mother
in law. Madrone, a disease called the mother. Madune, a brick or red square
pauing stone. Madunelli, small bricks, or little pauing stones. Maesa, land
that lies fallow. Maesare, to break or grub up land, to let it lie fallow.
Maesta, majesty, soueraintie, dignity, honor, lordlines, honorable dignity,
royal authority, or supremacy. Maestale, maiesticall, sovereign, great,
royal, lordlike. Maesteuole, maiesticall. Maestra, a mistres, or chief, Look
Strada maustra. Maestrale, a magistrate, a superior over other. Maestranza,
maistrie, or cunning, or skill, or workmanship. Maestrare, to teach, to
instruct, to master. Maestrato, taught, instructed, maistred. Also a
magistrate, a great head officer. Also the authority, office, power, and
dignity of a ruler or magistrate. Maestreggiare, to sail north-west. Also to
play the master. Maestreuole, cunning, learned, artificial, like a master,
skillful. Maestria, as Maestranza. Maestro, a master, a teacher, a ruler, an
ouerseer, one that has the instruction of others. Also the north-west wind,
or north-west and by west. Maestro tramontana, the north-west wind. Maestro di
campo, a marshall of a camp, a master of the field. Maestro di casa, a
steward of a house. Also the master or chief gut in any body, in a horse it
is taken for his whole or great paunch. Maestro d' art, a master of arts.
Maestra di scuola, a schoolmaster. Maestro di stalla, a noblemans gentleman of
his horse. Mafaro, the sail of the foremaste. Also a bung or stopple of a
barrel. Maffe, in good sooth, by my faith, yea by our lady. Maga, an
enchantres, a witch, a sorceresse. Also the art of witchcraft or pertaining to
sorcerie. Magace, a kind of musical instrument. Magade, a musical instrument
of twenty strings. Also the bridge of a lute that holds up the strings.
Magagna, fault, corruption, rottenness, addlenes, putrefaction, defect, want,
imperfection, waste, riot, hurt, loss. Also a rankling, a festring. Magagnare,
to rot, to addle, to putrify, to corrupt, to be defective, to hurt, to bruise
to battre as a boar does with his tusks, to rankle, to fester, to mangle.
Magagnoso, rotten, addle, full of corruption, tainted, rankled. Magalda, a
queen, a harlot, a strumpet, an old trot, a trull or minxe, a gixie. Magara, a
witch. Magari, I would to God it were so, would to God. Magaria, witcherie,
witchcraft. Magasi, as Maggiorini. Magazzino, Magazzeno, a storehouse or a
warehouse. Magazzino di grano, a store house for corn. Magazzino reale, a

Maggiore. Maggiore, greater, superior, better, higher, bigger, more ancient, a
senior or a mayor. Maggiordomo, the steward or chief officer of a house.

elders, greatest, aldermen, chief. Also our elders, ancestors, predecessors,
progenitors, or forefathers. Maggiorini, a kind of ducke, mallarde, or wiggin,
or such foul. Magi, wise men, whom we call the three kings of Collein, wise
philosophers. Magia, natural Magike, witchcraft or sorcerie. Magica, art

man's back or chine bone. Magisterio, Magistero, maisterie, mystery, cunning,
art, skill. Magistrale, a magistrate, or capable to be made a magistrate, like
a magistrate. Magistrato, a magistrate, a governor, a judge. Maglia, is
properly the holes in any net. Also a shirt or iacket of maile, as Giacco di

little stakes driven into hedges. Also slips of vines to be set to grow. Magna,
Look Madre. Magnanimita, magnanimity, high courage, greatness and noblenes of
mind. Magnanimo, magnanimous, high minded, all daring, stout hearted. Magnano, a
locke-smith, a key-maker; but properly a tinker or a forger. Magna pagnotte, a
deuourer of Panadoes, a glutton, a cormorant. Magna guadagno, as Mangia

that is to be eaten. Magnati, the ancients, elders, chief, head officers or
aldermen of a town or corporation. Also noble men or great peers of a realm

eater, a deuourer. Magnatora, as Mangiatoia. Magnesia, the load stone which
draws iron to it. Some call it a magnet stone. Magneti, a kind of stone
called catsiluer. Magnificare, to magnify, to honor, to advance, to extol, to

magnificent, noble, nobly minded. Magnificentia, magnificence, the doing or
atchieuing of great things, sumptuousness. Magnifico, magnificent, noble,

Venice. Magniloquentia, a lofty and high style or manner of speaking.
Magniloquo, he that has a lofty style and speaks of great matters.

great, high, mighty, large, big, notable, noble. Magnosa, a coife or caul.

cormorant or seagull. May, ever, never, at no time, at any time. It has also

they make bread in India. Maiuscula, greater then others, text letters, letters

cheek bone. Look osso Malo. Malabatro, a kind of leaf that swimmeth in
pooles without any apparent root: whereof is made a kind of sweet oil.
Malaccorto, vnheedful, foolish, unwary, il-aduised. Malachite, a stone of a
darkegreene color. Malacreanza, evil nurture, bad education, vnmannerlines.
Maladicenza, as Maldicenza. Maladire, dico, dissi, detto, to curse, to banne,
to speak ill, to rail, to slanuder. Maladetto, cursed, banned, spoken ill,

at ease, ill provided for, ill looked unto, hardly bested. Malagro, a disease

the high way, to play the thief. Manlandrino, a high way thief, a robber, a
spoiler. Mal' anno, an ill year, continual trouble and sorrow. They use it as
a curse in Italy. Il mal' anno che Dio ti dia, an ill year God give thee.
Malanuro, a kind of fish. Malare, to fall sick, to sicken. Malato, fallen
sick, sickned, sick, crazed. Malatia, Maladia, a malady, a sickness.
Malaticcio, sickish, subject to sickness. Mala sort, ill hap, ill chance, ill
luck. Malattaccaticcio, contagious, infecting, infectious or sticking unto.
Malaueduto, simple, negligent, vnheedful, foolish. Malauentura, ill luck, ill
fortune, ill hap. Malauenturoso, unhappy, unlucky, unfortunate.
Malauoglienza, ill will, hatred, dislike. Malbauisco, marsh mallows.
Malcaduco, the falling sickness. Malcomposto, ill framed, ill contrived. Mal
concio, ill dressed, in an ill plight, hardly bested. Malcontento, malcontent,
displeased, discontent. Mal creato, ill brought up, unmannerly, ill nurtured.
Mal del' asimo, Look Asima. Mal del corno, a disease about a horses neck. Mal
del panno, a disease about a horses head or neck. Mal destro, unhandsome,
improper, unfit. Maldetto, cursed, banned, forespoken, detracted, ill spoken,
ill said, an ill saying. Maldicente, a detractor, an iniurer, an ill speaker, a
backbiter. Maldicenza, detraction, injury, backbiting, slander, a curse, an
ill report. Maldisposto, ill disposed, unlusty. Mal di pietra, the sickness of
the stone collicke. Mal di febbre, an ague or fever. Mal di tisico, a pining
or lingering disease, a consumption. Male, harm, hurt, evil, ill, mischief,
sickness, disease, infection, pain grief, smart. Also ill, bad, naughty,
hurtful, unseemly, indecent, sickly, euilly, badlie, ill at ease, unhappily,
not well, shreudly, wickedly, lewdly. Male affare, of mischief or ill doing.

Maledicente, as Maldicente. Male del orzuolo, a falling or staggring disease in

evil carrying a former disease. Mal di lingua, the sorenes of the tongue in a
horse. Mal di napoli, the french pocks. Mal del dosso, a hurt in the back,
which in some horses is suffered to run so long that it is not easy to be
cured afterward. Mal francese, the french pox. Malfranciosato, infected with
the french pocks, pockie. Malforo, a mischievous hole, taken for a woman's

manna. In the scripture it is a delicate thing that god caused to fall from
heaven in great abundance in manner of dew, white in color and like a
Coriander seed, and very pleasant in eating. In physic it is a manner of dew
congealed on trees and plants, and so is gathered in certain hot countries and
reserved as a gentle purge of choler. Mano, a hand, a rank, a course or file.

Marana, a kind of ship, hoy, boat, or hulke. Marangonare, to play the
carpenter. Marangone, a carpenter. Maranello, a young pig, or a porklin.
Marano, a Jew, an Infidel, a renegado, a nickname for a Spaniard. It has also
been used for a kind of pinnace or flye-boate, or such ship. Marasandola, a
water-lizard, or newte. Marasca, a kind of sour cherrie. Marasco, a sour
cherrie tree. Marasmo, the third degree or extremity and end of the hectike
and consuming fever when unnatural heat has so prevailed in the
substantial parts of the heart and other members, that the natural moisture
thereof is clean exhausted and consumed, and thereby is become utterly
incurable. Marasmode, a kind of hecticke fever which happens of a burning
ague so far spread as that it consumes the humor of the whole body.
Marasso, a viper. Marauiglia, a wonder, a marvel. a viper. Marauigliare, to
wonder, to marvel. Marauiglioso, wonderful, marvelous, miraculous. Marca,
the bounds, limit, confines or marches of any country, thereof comes the word
Marchese, for he was called a Marquess that had the charge of some bordering
country, or that kept the marches. Also a mark, a sign, a token, or a
brandingiron. Some take it to be a horse, for in such a sense it has bin
taken, a coin called a mark. Marcantare, to cheapen, to bargain, to
merchandise, to mart. Marcante, a merchant, a chapman. Marcantesca,
marchandlike, Mano Marcantesca. Marcantia, merchandise. Marcare, to mark, to
note, to brand, to stamp. Marcasita, as Marchesita. Marcello, a coin current

Marchesato, a Marquisate, a Marquess his Lordship, Marqueship. Marchesata, a

before an Earl. Also the monthly flowers of women. Marchesita, a kind of stone
called a marquesite or fire-stone. Marchetto, a coin current in Italy.
Marchia, a march or marching. Marchiare, to mark or brand horses, to march in
rank and order as soldiers do. Marchio, a brand or mark upon horses. Also a
branding iron. Marchio della stadera, a counterpoise, any thing put in the
balances or scales to make even weight. Marcia, a march or marching of
soldiers or upon the drum. Also rotten matter, corruption or putrefaction
coming from any sore or fistula. Marciacotto, the metal wherewith glasses
are made, as it is in the pots in furnaces. Marciare, to march in order, as
soldiers. Marciapane, a kind of banqueting meat called a marchpane. Marcido,
rotten, feeble, unlusty, withered, flagging, lither, corrupt. Marciliana, a
kind of hulke, pinnace, ship, barge or flie-boate. Marcire, cisco, cito, to
rot, to putrify, to corrupt, to addle, to become faint, unlusty, and
drooping. Marcio, rotten, addle, corrupt, putrified. Also a lurch or a maiden
set at any game. Marcita, as Marcia. Marco, a mark upon any thing, a
goldsmithes weight. Marcozza, a kind of game so called. Mardore, a beast
called a martinet. Marea, a tide, a full sea, a full tide. Mare, the sea, the
ocean, the maine, the watery wilderness. Mareggiare, to flote upon the sea, to
keep the course of the sea. Maremma, the sea strond or shore. Marenda,
Marendare, as Merenda. Marene, a kind of great cherrie. Marescalco,
Marescialto, a marshall of field or house. Also a farrier or horsesmith.
Marescalcheria, a farriers forge. Also a marshalfie or marshalship. Marga, a
pick axe or hedge-hill, a ploughshare or any such cutting tool. Also a kind
of earth named marle, which is a fat claie and chalk together, serving to dung
fields. Margarita, a pearl, a margarite, a gem. Also a flower called a daizie.
Margaritaro, one that makes bugles, or one that pierces and boareth pearls.
Margaritine, bugles or seed pearls. Margaulzo, a strange bird in India.
Margello, sniuell or snot, or filth of ones nose. Marginare, to heal up a scar
or wound, to keep along the coasts of the sea, to leave or make a margin,
side, or bank. Margin, a margin, a brinke, a border, an edge, a brimme, a
bound, a frontire or side of any thing, a scarre or mark or sign of any cut
or hurt healed up. Marginoso, having a large margin, side, border, brim or
edge. Mariche, a kind of wild beast in China, with a face like a woman, a
body like a a lion, and a tail as a scorpion. Mariconda, a kind of dainty
chewet or little pies used in Italy. Marina, the sea coast or stronde, or of
the sea. Also the sea. Marinare, to play the mariner, to travel by sea, to
marl or dres fish with vinegar to make it keep long to storm, to chafe, to
fret, or rore as the sea does, to scoulde, to wrangle aloud that all may hear.
Marinaro, Marinaio, a mariner, a seaman, a shipman, a sailer. Marinaresco,
Marinesco, marrinerlike. Marinarezza, the seafaring trade, or art of
navigations. Marincusach, a monstrous beast in Persia, with a face like a woman,
a body like a lion, and a tail like a scorpion. Marine, Marinelle, sour
cherries. Marinella, Valerian, capons tail, or Setwall. Marino, of the sea,
near or bordering upon the sea, borne or bred in the sea. Also sea water
green, Pesce marino, sea fish. Marino pescatore, a kind of sea frogge.
Mariolare, to play the cutpurse, rogue, or coni-catcher. Mariolarie, cutpurse
or coni-catching tricks, or knaueries. Mariolo, Mariuolo, a cutpurse, a
conicatcher, a villain. Marische, a disease called the pyles or hemorrhoydes
in the fundament. Maritaggio, a marriage, a spousall, or wedding. Maritale, of
or pertaining to marriage or to a husband. Maritare, to marry, to spouse, to
wedde. Maritato, married, spoused, wedded, a bridegroom, a married man, a
husband. Maritata, a bride, a married woman, a wife. Mariteuole, marriage-able,
fit to be married. Maritimo, pertaining to, or of the sea, of the sea side or
coaste, bordering on the sea. Marito, a husband. Mariuolare, to play the cut
purse or conicatcher. Mariuolo, as Mariolo. Marmarita, the herb beare-breech.
Marmegge, a kind of bird. Marmo, marble. Marmocchio, a gull, a fool, an
idiote, a patch or coxcombe. Marmoreo, made of marble, hard as marble. Also a
marble color. Marmoroso, Marmorino, idem. Marmotta, a marmoset, a babie for a
child to play withal, a pugge. Marobio, as Marrobiastro. Maroelle, a disease
called the hemorrhoides or pyles. Maroncini, a kind of simnell, cracknell, bun
or roll of bread. Maroni, Marroni, a kind of greater chestnuts then any we
have. Also something about a plough. Maroso, rough, stormy, full of billows,
tempestuous, blustering. Marra, a mattocke, a spade, a shouell, a rake to mingle
sand and lome together, a pickaxe, or such rusticke instrument. Marrobiastro,
the herb horehounde or marrube. Marrubio, as Marrobiastro. Marrochino, spanish
lether, frizeleather. Marro, the name of some part of a horses back. Marrobio,
as Marrobiastro. Marrone, a great mattocke, paring shouell or pickaxe or iron
rake. Marrucca, a hemp or flax pit, a place in water to rot or steep hemp
or flax in. Also a kind of thornie shrubbe or tree called ram or hearts
thorn. Marruffino, the yoongest prentise in a house, one that is put to all
druggerie, a swobber in a ship. Marsione, or Marsone, as Ghiozzo. Some take it
also to be the dace, the menowe: others the merlane fish. Marsori, a kind of
pot, pitcher, pipkins glass, or other vessel. Marsupio, a kind of pot that
alchimistes use. Also a pouch or a purse. Martagnone, a kind of herb bearing
a fine flower. Martaro, Marturo, as Martora. Mart, tuesday, Mars the God of
war, and one of the planets. Also the metal iron according to alchimists.
Martanica, goats rue, or Italian fitch. Martedi, tuesday. Martedi grasso,
shroue-tuesday. Martegone, as Martegnone. Martellare, to hammer, to forge, to
knock, to make one jealous or appassionated in love, to make ones heart to
pant. Martelletto, Martellino, a little hammer. Martello, a hammer, a sledge, a
carpenters mallet. Also jealousy or suspicion in love: panting or throbbing of
the heart. Martera, a bakers kneading or boulting tubbe. Martiale, a martial
man, a man of Mars his constitution. Martialista, a martialist of the nature of
Mars. Martinacci, a kind of ravenous cormorant or such foul. Martinello, a
gaffell, a rack or bender of a bow. Martinisti, martinists, of Martins
profession. Martingalla, a martingall about a horse. Martino, taken for the
arse or bumme of a man. Martin pescatore, a fish so called, resembling a
frogge: in latin Piscatrix. Martinello, Martinetto, a bender, rack or gaffell
of a crosse-bowe. Martino pescatore, a kings fisher. Also a kind of fish.
Martire, a martyr, one suffering in witness of another. Martire, Martirio,
affliction, torment, martyrdom. Martirizzare, to martyr, to torment, or
afflict. Martora, a beast called a martin, whose furre is very dear.
Martorella, a young martine, or a she martin. Martori, the furre of martins.
Martoria, as Martorella. Martorizzare, as Martirizzare. Martoriare, as

Egrimonie, the herb horehound or Marub. Maruca, as Ma^ruca. Marucco, a

fish. Marzacotto, an instrument or tool that p^tters use. Marzarolo, a haggard

abject fellow. Mascalzone, a rogue, a rascal, a base, an abject shifting
companion. Mascara, a mask, a vizzard, a covert. Mascarare, to mask, to
revel, to mum, to cloak, to hide. Mascarata, a masking, a mask, a mumming or

iaw, a chap, a cheek, the cheek bone, the iawe bone, the mandible, or iaw
wherein the teeth are fixed. Mascellare, belonging to the iaw bone. Denti
mascellari, the cheek teeth or grinders. Mascellone, a box, a blow, a clap or
whirret on the cheeks Maschera, as Mascara. Mascherare, as Mascarare.
Mascheraro, a mask or vizard maker, a masker or mummer. Mascherata, as

Maschio, a male, a mankind, a masculine. Also a keep or hold or fort, or
tower in the mid of a castle, a strong tower or cittadell. Mascolino, as
Maschile. Mase, but if, but what if. Maselli, something about minerals.
Masnada, a company, crew, knot, rout, huddle or cluster of knaves or thieves.
Masnadiero, a ruffler, a swashbuckler, a swaggerer, a high way thief, a

a chaos of any thing, a cub, a haie mow or stacke. Also paste. Massacara, a
kind of shrimps or praunes. Massara, Massaia, a household or kitching woman

manner of household stuff or implements. Massaritioso, thriftie, full of good

most of all. Massimo, greatest or most in estimation, most worthy, noble, and
excellent. Masso, a rock, a shelfe, a cliff, or a shallow standing in the sea,
a mass, a heap, a lump. Mastella, a bathing, washing, or bucking tub.

roapemakers or glassemakers tool. Matapane, a kind of base piece of coin.
Matara, a maund to put bread in. Mataraccio, Matarazzo, a mattresse. Matarazzo,

a mattres maker. Matarozzolo, a bunch to hang keys at. Materia, a matter,
stuff, or substance whereof any thing is framed. Also a thing. Also occasion.
Materia, madness, folly. Materiale, material, substantial, made of any
matter. It is also taken for a foolish, grosseheaded or shallowheaded fellow.
Materna, Materno, motherlie, maternall, of the mother, of the mothers side.
Matematica, or Mathematica, the art or profession or knowledge in mathematike,
which is skill in Augurie, Geometry and Astronomy, or to cast natiuities.
Matematicale, mathematical or pertaining to the Mathematickes. Matematico, a
Mathematician, he that has cunning in Augurie, geometry and Astronomy, one
that casts ones nativity. Materozzolo, as Matterozzolo. Matesia, Mathesia,
learning by demonstration. Maticare, to heal the shrunken sinews in a horse.
Matina, as Mattina. Matinata, as Mattinata. Matita, a thing to color withal,
as blacklead or oker. Matonzini, a kind of goldsmiths work in chains so
called. Matre, a mother, a damme. Also the matrix or womb of a woman. Also a
disease in women called the mother. Matre magna, the earth, for it is the
general mother of all things. Dura matre, the hard and thick pannicle or
membrane, which in compassing the brain about gathers the same not
straightly and closely together, but loosely and in remiss order, after the
manner that Pericardio inuolueth the heart: Pia matre the caules of filmes of the
brain. Matregna, a stepdame, or mother in law. Matremma, mother mine, my
mother. Matrebosco or selua, Woodbine, or honey suckle. Matre perla, mother of
pearl. Matricaria, feuerfeu, whitewoort or motherwoort. Matricali vapori, as
Prefocatione. Matrice, the matrix, mother, or womb of a woman. Matricida, the
murderer of his mother. Matricidio, the murdering of ones mother.
Matricolare, as Matriculare. Matricula, a role or check, or catalogue or
register of names. Also a sea snaile or Venus shell. Matriculare, to
matriculate, to enregister, or admit of a society or university.
Matriculatione, a matriculation, registring, or admitting. Matrigna, as
Matregna. Matrignale, like a stepdame, unnaturally, unkindly. Matrimoniale, of
or belonging to marriage. Matrimoniare, to marry, to wedde, to spouse.
Matrimonio, a matrimony, a marriage, a wedding, a wedlock. Matrona, a matron,
a sage dame, a grave sober woman. Matronale, matrone-like, gravely, soberlie.
Mattacchione, a merry lad, a good fellow, a simple gull. Mattacciuola, a
silly fool, a simple gull. Mattacini, a kind of antique dance or morris
used in Italy. Mattalone, a gull or ninnie, a patch, a meacocke. Mattana, has
bin used in jest for Mattina. Also a madding or gadding humor. Mattapane, a
kind of base little coin. Mattare, to play the fool, gull, or noddie, to
become foolish, to mate or give a mate. Mattarie, foolish toys, fooleries,
mad tricks, sotteries. Mattarozza, the head or big end of a beetle or iron
crow or club. Mattea, as Poauola. Also as Mattana. Matteggiare, to play the

stick, a truncheon, a cudgel, but properly a butchers prick, a pegge, a

at a bunch of keys. Matresco, foolish, mad, fond. Mattezza, madness, folly,

it creepes. Also fools Matrina, a morning, a forenoone, early in the morning.

played in a morning under ones window. Also a mattins. Mattinare, to pray in

weauers loome. Mattotta, a queen, a harlot, a gill, a minx gixie or trull.
Mattutina, early, or morning, or morn, La matutina rosa. Mattutino, mattins

Maturare, as Maturire. Maturezza, ripenes, judgment, prudence, consideration.
Maturire, risco, rito, to be or wax ripe, to ripen, to come to full grouth,
bigness, and perfection, to become mellowe, to grow due. Maturita, ripenes, ripe
age, mellownesse, perfection, maturitie, good season, time convenient. Maturo,
ripe, aged, old, sage, mellowe, fit, convenient. Also grave, wise, discreet,
considerate, perfect, constant. Also due as any payment is, debito maturo, a
due debt. Mauro, the graie color of a horse, a dark graie. Mauseolo, a great
rich tomb or grave, or monument. Maza, a kind of meat made of meal, milk,
oil, and water that countrymen were wont to eat. Mazza, a clubbe. Also a
beetle to cleave wood with. Also a pensioners polaxe. Also a great sledge or
hammer. Look Andar' alla mazza. Also a mace or any thing with a great knob at
the end of it. Mazzabuo, a butcher, an ox killer. Mazza cani, a dogs-slayer.
Mazzacaballo, a great knobbed cudgel, a club. Mazzacara, the tender part of
any bird. In a goose we call it the soul. Also a kind of shrimps or praune.
Mazzacare, to bruise, to beat black and blew. Mazzachera, an angling rod, a
fishing pole. Mazzacotto, a kind of stuff whereof glass is made.
Mazzaferrata, an iron club. Mazzafrusto, a sling to hurl stones withal. Also
a club with some chain or stone or lead or iron fastened to it. Mazzagattone, a
killer of cats, a bugbeare to fear children with. Mazza gente, a killer or
queller of people, a man queller. Mazzapengolo, as Mazzaruolo. Mazzare, to
kill, to slay, to quell, to brain, to knock on the head. Mazza sorda, the

Mazzerare, to diue, to cast, to steep or lay in water, as Macerare, Also to

posie of flowers, a sheafe or handful of corn or such like. Mazzetta,
Mazzuola, a kind of little anuile that goldsmithes use. Mazzicare, to swallow

gentlemen pencioners are. Mazzina, a sheafe, a handful or bundle Also a little
club. Mazzo, a heap, a mass, a lump, a bundle, a sheafe, a bottle or wad of

Some take it for a sea-tench. Some use it also for a whiting mop. Mazzo di
siori, a nosegaie, a posie or bunch of flowers. Mazzocca, as Mazza. Mazzoccola,
as Mazzuola, a woman's roll or rowler for her head. Mazzuola, a little club,

handful, a poesy of flowers, a nosegaie, a little sheafe or club. Me, me,
meselfe, to me, to meselfe, from me, from meselfe. Also mine. Me, used for
Meglio, better. Mea, mine, mine own. Meabile, that which runs or passes
and glideth away easily. Meandro, a winding, a turning or a crankling in and
out. Meanta, a kind of water foul. Meare, to go or pass on further. Meato,
gone or passed on further. Also a way, a passage or moving course. Also the
pores or holes in any body. Mecanico, mechanical, base, vile, a workman in whom
there is a good hand and a good wit, a handicrafts man, a man of an occupation.
Meccere, as Messere, but rather in ill part and as a nickename, as we say sir
knave. Meccole, a kind of disease in a horses legs. Mecenato, a Mecenas, a
patron, a favorer of learning. Meco, with me, together with me. Meco medesmo,
or stesso, with me self. Medaglia, a jewel, a monument, any embossed or
graven work, a bruche, an ouch. It is also taken for a woman's bum or gear.
Also any ancient coin. Madaglietta, any little brouch, ouch, jewel, monument
or ancient coin. Medaglista, a ieweller or an antiquarie of old coins. Medea,
a kind of precious stone, black with veins in it, yielding a sweat like
saffron, and taste like wine. Medela, has been used for a medicine or
physic. Medesimamente, likewise. Also in such sort. Medesimo, self,
selfsame, same, the same. Medemo, Medesmo, idem. Mediale, a black sacrifice
which was offered at noone day. Mediane vene, the middle vein or black
vein, branches of Cefalica and Basilica, constituting the common vein in the
arm. Mediante, by means, through, by. Mediastino, that partition which is
made by certain thin skins, dividing the whole breast from the throat to the
midriffe into two bosoms or hollowes: the one on the right side, the other on
the left Mediate, by means or intercession. Mediatore, a mediator, an
intercessor. Medicale, Medicabile, curable, medicinable, that may be cured.
Medica, a kind of clauer grass or Spanish trefoile. Also a woman physician.
Medicamento, a medicine, a medicament a salve, a curing, a physic, a remedy,
a slibber sauce. Medicame, as Medicamento. Medicante, a physician, a leach.
Medicare, to cure, to heal, to dress, to give physic, to salve, to leach.
Medicastro, an empirike, a foolish physician, a horse-leach. Medicina,
Medecina, physic, a medicine or purgation, the art of curing the sick.
Medicinale, Medecinale, medicinable, good for physic. Medicinare, as
Medicare, to practice physic. Medico, a physician, a leach. Also a kind of
tree in Media which at all times has blossoms. Apples half ripe, and apples
ripe; which when they fall, others come presently in their place. Medimno, a
certain measure used in Greece. Medio, the middle finger of a hand. Also a
kind of black stone. Also a kind of herb. Mediocre, mean, indifferent,
moderate, not too big nor too little. Mediocrita, a mediocritie, an
indifferency, a mean, a measure. Meditare, to meditate or muse with the
mind, to ponder or consider, or study with diligence. Meditatione, a
meditation or musing, a deep discreet consideration, an exercise of the mind.
Mediteraneo, in the middle of the land, in the maine land, far from the sea,
in land country. Meditore, a mower of hay. Medolla, the marrow, pith,
substance or core of any thing. Meffe no, No, no no, no in good sooth, no by my
fay, no sir. Mefite, as Mephite. Mege, a disease in horses feet. Megge, a kind
of sea fish. Megistani, governors, princes, great men, states, nobles, heroes.
Megliaccio, as Migliaccio. Megliarina, a bird called a yellow hammer, a golden
hammer or yowlring. Meglio, Megliore, better, or best, rather. sooner, more, Io
amerei meglio. Megliorare, to mend, to redress, to recover, to better.
Meglioramento, a mending, a recovery, Meguei, a tree among the Indians,
whereof their gardens be full, for of the leaves they make their shoes, and use
them in stead of paper to write upon: of the juice thereof they make wine,
vinegar, honnie, and sugar, the fruit thereof and the roots are very good
meat. Mei, a kind of fish like the Cefalo. Mel', for Mi il, as Mel disse, he
told it me. Mela, any kind of apple. Melabatro, an herb like to camomill.
Melacotogno, the fruit we call a quince. Melacchino, full of honey, honnied,
sweet, a kind of wine in Italy. Melagrana, granata, a Pomegranate. Melagrano,
a Pomegranate tree. Mela insana, a kind of fruit, in latin Melongeua.
Melampiro, an herb full of branches, having a seed like fenigreeke. Melampo,
black-footed, a dogs name used of some poets. Melampodio, an herb called
black hellebor. Melanconia, Melanconico, as Maninconico. Melancio, an orange
tree. Melandrino, a kind of broad flat fish. Melaneto, a bird called a Saker.
Melangole, a kind of cytron, or limon. Also the parings of them, or of other
fruits. Melane, a stone which yields a juice. Melaneo, cole-blacke, a dogs
name so called. Melano, sweet like honey. Melanteria, a kind of black or
ink wherewith physicians use to consume putrified flesh. Melantio, the herb
narde, gitte, or pepperwort. Also a kind of monstrous sea fish. Melanuro, a
kind of fish called a sea breame. Melanzana, the herb mad or raging apple.
Melarancia, an orange. Melarancio, an orange tree. Melare, to sweeten with
honey. Melato, sweetened with honey, honied, sweet, of the color of honey.
Mele, bonie. Also any kind of apples. Also a man's or woman's bum, arse, or
buttocks. Mele cotogna, a quince. Mele d'api, stone-honie, bee-honie. Mele di
canna, has bin used for sugar. Melega, the name of an herb: some take it for
a kind of corn. Melensaggine, foolishnes, or simplicity of wit. Melensare,
to become or play the gull or simple fool. Melerugiadoso, as Manna.
Melesiogallo, a bird called a witwall. Melenso, foolish, gullish, simple
witted. Melia, a tree bringing forth a pleasant fruit. Also a kind of earth
used in physic of the virtue of allom; painters use it to make their colors
last the longer. Meliceride, impostumes that run a kind of matter like honey.
Melico, musical, or musician-like. Melicrato, a drink of water and honey
sodden together. Melifero, Mellifero, bearing or breeding honey. Melificare, to
make or bring forth honey. Melifluo, Mellifluo, honnied, sweet, mellifluous.
Meligine, a mell-dew falling on trees or corn, honie-dew. Meliloquente, a
sweet speaker. Meliloto, the herb melilote, or clauer. Melino, a kind of
sweete-smelling ointment. Also a kind of color that painters use,
honie-colour. Melire, lisco, lito, to honnie, to sweeten, or season with honey.
Melissa, the herb baulme mint, or baulme gentle. Melissofillo, as Melissa.
Melite, a kind of yellow stone, which broken and put in water yields the
savor of honey. Melito, honied, or mixed with honey. Melitena, a kind of
herb. Melitera, a dry medicine serving to fill up the hollownes of ulcers
after they are cleansed. Mellonaggine, as Melensaggine. Mellone, the fruit we
call a musk melon. Also a gull, a log garhead, or a fool. Also a kind of
play that children use in Italy. Also rowels in the mouth of a horses bit like
melons. Melo, any kind of apple tree. Melochite, a kind of green stone.
Melode, melodious, harmonious, musical, sweetly singing. Melodia, melody,
harmony, sweet singing, a tunable singing, whereof be three kinds, that is to
say Harmonia, Chronia, and Diatonia. Melodioso, melodius, harmonius, sweet
singing. Melogna, a kind of fish or beast. Melonaggine, as Melensaggine.
Melonare, as Melensare. Melone d'acqua, a cucumber. Meloparadiso, the paradise
apple. Meloteragno, a kind of shrub, or weed. Meltusio, the fish we call a
hadock, or a cod. Melza, the spleen or milt of any body. Membrana, a
parchment, a sheepeskin, or vellame, the pill or skin between the bark and
the tree, the uppermost thin skin of any thing, a membrane. Membranza,
remembrance. Membrare, to remember, to join together, to form or shape
limbs, parts, and members in due proportion. Membratura, the settling or
order of members or parts. Membreuole, proportionable, according to true
proportion of limbs. Also mindful. Membro, a member, a limme, or a part of
ones body or any other thing, in an oration it is a short sentence or clause.
Membro virile, the priuities of man. Membroso, as Membruto. Membruto, limmed,
strong, long limmed, having great members. Memfite, a stone fattie and of
diverse colors, in curing or burning any member, it takes away sense and
feeling without any danger. Memorabile, memorable, notable, renoumed, to be
remembered, worthy of remembrance. Memoraggine, as Memoria. Memoranza, as
Memoria. Memorando, as Memorabile. Memoria, memory, mindefulnes, remembrance,
souenance. Also time, days, chronicles, writings, histories, records. Memore,
as Memoroso. Memoreuole, as Memorabile. Memoriale, a memorial, pertaining to
memory, a record, a remembrancer. Memorioso, as Memoroso. Memoroso, mindful,
remembering, memorable, that will remember, that is thankful. Men', for Me ne,
Io men vado. I am going hence. Also for Meno. Mena, behavior, fashion, carriage
of a man. Also a kind of weight. Also a cackrell, because it makes whosoever
eats thereof laxatiue. Some take it for a herring or a pilcherd. Menacordo,
the instrument we call Claricords. Menaculo, a smug, nice, wanton, effeminate
fellow. Menaia, as Manara. Menadi, certain women that were wont to sacrifice
to Bacchus, dancing at the sound of horns, and crying as mad women, carrying
staves wreathed about with vine leaves. Menare, to lead, to bring, to conduct,
to direct, to guide, to frig, to wriggle, to iumble, to wag or stir to and
fro. Menamenti, stirrings, friggings, wriglings, leadings. Menata, a leading, a

punta, to thrust or foine at. Menarosto, a jack to turn the spit, a

edgling, with purpose to cut. Menar le calcole, to be a free whore, to occupye
freely. Menatore, a leader, a guide, a conducter, a directer, a bringer.

pure without mixture, very right. Merope, a bird that eats bees, whose
nature is to feed and keep his parents, which never com abroad, called a

as Meritare. Merso, Look Mergere. Merto, as Merito. Merula, a bird called a

string. Also a-lam-ire in music. Mesenterie vene, branches of the vein
Porta, which convey the juice of the meat concocted from the stomach to the

skins that fasten the bowels to the back and each to other, and incloseth a
number of veins, being branches of the carrying vein, by which the guts are
nourished, and the juice of the meat concocted is conuaide to the liver to be

divination of men's conditions by looking in their faces. Metroposcopo, one that
looks in ones face and thereby judges his conditions. Metropoli, the chief

chief city. Also one of a chief city. Mettere, metto, misi, messo, to put,

to put, set, or lay in a bank, or in safety. Metter' in mare, to go to sea,
to go out into the maine, to put to sea. Metter la faua nel bacello, to put the

moitie. Mezzaaria, is taken among horsemen when a horse does bound high
continuing it without rest, whereof comes mezzaaria aspra, which is, bounding
with a yerke. Mazzalancia, as Lanciere, a demilance. Mezzalana, a stuff called
linsic woolsie, or any stuff made of half wool and half silk or linen.

Mezzanita, a mean, a help, an occasion, a cause, a mediocritie. Mezzara, a

kind of powder made of dride beef, which in Earberie, and among the
Fuoruscitos of Italy they use to give to their horses and soldiers to keep
them in breath: and they say, that a horse with half a pound of it will go a
hundredth miles upon the spur, and they never go without some. Micola, a
crumme, a whit, a jot. Micolare, to crum, to cramble. Micolino, a little crum,
whit, jot, or nothing. Miconij, people that be commonly balde of the Island of

meat received into the mouth. Molcere, molcio, molsi, molciuto, to please, to

Molette, as Mollette. Moli, rue, hermall or herb grass. Molichino, a kind of

little mill, and as Ventarello. Also a wheel for a dog to turn the spit in.

a winding, a reeling or turning like a mill. Molinare, to grind in a mill, to
full cloth. Also as Ghiribizzare. Molino, any kind of mill. Molino a braccia, a
handmill. Molino ad acqua, a water mill. Molino a vento, a wind mill. Molino
gazzino, a kind of mill so called. Molino da poglia, an oil mill. Molino
terragno, a kind of low mill or handmill. Moliri, a iocust that destroieth
corn. Molitore, a bird like a swan braying like an ass. Molla, a wheel of a
clock that moves all the rest called the spr^ng. Mollare, to moisten, to
steep in water, to laue, to wet, to wash, to bathe. Also to leave off, to
cease, to finish, to give over. Also to slack, to loosen, to let go a hold.
Molle, soft, tender, sle^der, limmer, lithe or soft in feeling. Also pliable,

pleasant, calm, mild, wanton. Also moist, wet, watrish, dampish or soft under

soft fish: in music it is taken for flat. Molle di fuoco, fire tongs.

effeminately, wantonly, softly, tenderly, slenderly, limmer, watrish. Mollette,

little mullets or pincers or nippers. Mollica, any kind of crumme or
crumbling. Mollicare, to crumble, to crum. Molliche, crumbs. Also a kind of
small pulse. Mollificare, to mollify, to make soft or tender. Mollesino,
Mollosino, Molesino, soft, limmer or slender in feeling, smooth, or lythe.
Mollitia, softnes, wantonness, effeminacie, dalliance, delicatnes, tenderness,
nicenes, calmnes, smoothnes. Mollitre, softnes in feeling, as Mollitia.
Mollitiuo, softning, suppling. Mollo, as Molle. Molo, a wharfe or hithe by the
water side made by art, we properly call it a key. Molobatro, an ointment made

flowers of mallows. Molochite, a kind of precious stone of a thick green
color like to mallows. Molocuccia, an herb so called taken for mallows.
Molosso, a mastiue dog, a bull dog. Also a foot of a verse consisting of three
long syllables. Molte cose, many or sundry things. Molte volte, many or diverse
times. Molti, many, diverse, sundry. Moltiforme, of many fashions, forms or
shapes. Moltiformita, that has many forms, a multiformitie. Moltifidi, cloven

many sides. Moltigenio, of diverse kinds or sundry sorts. Moltinomio, having
many names. Moltiloquente, much speaking or full of words. Moltiplicare, to
multiply, to increase, to augment. Moltiplicabile, that may be multiplied or
augmented. Moltiplicatione, multiplication, increase or augmenting.
Moltiplicatore, a multiplier, an augmentour. Moltiplice, manifold, of diverse
and sundry sorts. Moltipotente, of great power, that may do much. Moltiradice,
the lesser centorie. Moltissimi, very many. Moltitudine, a multitude, a many
or great number. Moltiuoco, of many significations. Moltizzo, a skinners tool
so called. Molto, much, store, very, a great deal, mickle, a long time or
season, a great while. Molto a buon hora, very timely, very early. Molto been,
very well. Molto fa, long ago, long since. Molto meno, much less. Molto per
tempo, very early, very timely. Molto piu tosto, much sooner, much rather.

willingly, most willingly. Molua, the fish we call cod. Some take it for the
hadocke. Molucro, a square piece of timber whereon painims were wont to
sacrifice. Momentale, of moment, of consequence, Also during but a little time.

to moment, to make of consequence. Momento, a moment, a minute, the least part
of time which cannot be assigned, a very little quantity or portion of any

little flies. Also fly bitings, or little spots about horses. Moschetti, a
kind of sparowes in India so little, as with feathers and all one is no bigger

a whole nest full of them waieth but 24. grains. Moschetto, a musket. Also a

muskle of the body: also a top or gigge such as children play with. Moscoloso,

a tree among the Indians which is thought to bear that fruit that Adam tasted
of, for cut the fruit which way you will and you shall find the figure of the
cross. Mossa, moved, stirred, iogged. Also a moving, a stirring, a starting,
a ^ogging, a motion. Also the start or first motion of any thing, the starting
place or start of any horse when he first takes his start to run a race.

moving. Motiuo, a motive, that is mooueable, not abiding. Moto, a motion, a

passion of a man's mind. Motore, a moouer, a stirrer. Also taken for God
almighty. Motoso, muddie, durtie, boggie, myrie. Motteggiare, to frumpe to
quip, to scoff, to jest, to gibe. Motteggiatore, a frumper, giber or iester, a
quipper. Motteggiere, full of merry conceits, quippes, frumps and iestes.

witty saying. Motto, a word, a mot, a phrase, a saying a posie or brief in
any shield, ring, or emprese, a quip, a frump, a scoff, a jest, or witty
saying. Mottozzo, a long tale or discourse of good tidings, a tale of
reioicing. Motu proprio, of self motion and freewil. Mouenza, moving, motion,
or stirring. Mouere, muouo, mossi, mosso, or mouuto, to move, to stir, to

being an isntrumental part of the body, serving for voluntary moving, being
a substance harder and endued with less sense then a sinew, as also softer and

which the Romans were wont safely to approach to the walls of a town to fill
up the ditches. It is also used for a fish which continually swimmeth before
the whale, and serves as a guide unto him that he run not upon rocks.

the hand, 3. with blowing, or as some call it vocal, isntrumental, and
proportional. Also of musical instruments there be three kinds, one in

flote up and down the water, and his feet for oars, and his tail in stead
of a helm or rudder. Naxia, Nassia, a kind of white stone. Ne, without a
verb, neither, nor, also in, or in the: with a verb, sometimes it signifies
any, some, of it, of the same, thereof: sometimes it stands for us, to us, unto
us, from us: and other times it stands for thence, hence, from hence, from
thence, away. Also either, or so much as. Neade, a beast in Samos with so
strong a voice that when it roareth, it shakes the earth, whose bones are so
big that they are kept for a marvel. Nebbia, a cloud, an ouercasting of the
sky, a miste, a fogge, or any such deawie exhalation: it is properly a
thickning of exhalations, having in it plentiful force to engender water:
taken also for a multitude together. Also adversity or trouble or any thing
wherewith the knowledge of man's is hid and ouercast. Nebbiare, to be mistie

a rough, tempestuous, stormy miste or cloud. Nebbioso, mistie, foggie,
cloudie, full of clouds, boistrous, rough, stormy, tempestuous. Nebrite, a
kind of precious stone. Necessario, necessary, needful, inevitable.

takes, a close-stoole. Necessita, necessity, need, urgent business.

O
O, One of the five vowels. O. an aduerbe of exception, either, only, or. the
sign of the vocative case oh, an interiection of grief, of derision, of
admiration, of imprecation, and of reproouing, as oh, alas, aie me, good lord,
oh that, tush, figh, away, and such. Obbrigare, Obrigare, as Obligare. Obbrigo,
Obrigo, as Obligo. Obbrobriare, as Obrobriare. Obbrorio, as Obrorio.
Obbrobrioso, as Obrobrioso. Obediente, obedient, mild, meek, pleasant,
obeying. Obedienza, Obedientia, obedience, humblenes, obeisance. Obedire,
disco, dito, to obey, to please, to yield unto, to do according. Obelisco, a
great square stone, broad beneath, and growing smaller and smaller toward

properly thin wafers, or sugar-bread. Obiettione, an objection. Also a

object, a thing before a man's eyes and may be seen. Also the laying or setting
of a thing before ones eyes or against one, a shadow or overthwart casting.

Pedero. Opefice, a worke-man, a crafts-man. Openione, an opinion, a thought, a

labourer. Operetta, Operina, a little piece of work, a pretty labor.
Operosita, great pain or travel or working. Operoso, full of work, working,
diligent or painful in laboring, toilesome or laborious. Operto, opened, set
open. Opertura, an ouerture or opening. Ophiasi, a kind of sore in the head,
namely in children, causing the hair to fall here and there, fretting the skin
off. Ophiusa, an herb whereof who so tastes is much frighted with spirits
and devils. Ophtalmia, an inflammation of the uttermost skin of the eye called
in latin Adnata, proceeding either of the fulness of the body, or of the sharp
choleric humor, or of gross humors and windines puffing up the place.

infirmity that comes into ones eyes, called in latin Grithe. Osanna, save now

Corona, pertaining to a siege. Ossifraga, a kind of furious beast. Also a kind
of hawk or eagle called a bonebreaker; because that with her beak she
breaks great bones. Ossimathia, a learning when one is old. Ossimathe, one
that learneth or goes to school in his old age or never learnte before.
Ossimoto, a sentence spoken with such affectation of wit and gravity that it
seems foolish. Osso, any kind of bone. Also the stone of any fruit as Olives,
Dates, etc. Osso basillare, as Osso cuneale. Osso cossendico, the middle part
of Ilio osso, which is straighter and thicker, and outwardly engraven with a
large and deep cave. Osso cuneale, the cuneall bone, which being as it were a
ground or foundation to the brain, is thrust in like a wedge between the
bones of the head and the upper iaw. Osso ilio, Vide Ilio. Osso malo, the
cheek bone, which being in diverse places spongious, contains also in it
self a very large cauitie, tenderly walled on each side with thin scaly
bones, for lightness so ordained of nature. Osso pube, the second part of Osso
ilio, which being not so broad as the former is throwed on each side with a
large and ample hole. Osso sacro, the great bone whereupon the ridge bone
rests. Osso sphenoido, as Osso cuneale. Ossolare, to pick out the bones of
any thing. Ossoli, bobbins to wind silk upon, keeles or nine pins as they use
to play at with a bowl. Also knuckles, or knucklebones. Ossolieri, the
strings wherewith the slops are tied up or shirt strings. Ossolini, little
small gristly bones. Ossoso, bonie, full of bones. Ossuario, a charnell house,
a shrine or place where bones are kept. Ossuto, as Ossoso. Osta, the name of a
roape in a ship. Ostacolo, an obstacle, a hinderance, an opposition, an

withstand, to resist, to oppose, to let, to hinder, to stand against or

Ostatione, as Ostacolo. Ostatrice, a Midwife. Oste, an host, an inkeeper. Also
aguest being of the masculine gender. Also a camp or an host of men being of
the feminine gender. Ostea, a kind of stuff called woosted. Ostello, an
hostell, a mansion, a mansion house. Osteleria, as Osteria. Osteliero, an
hostler, an host, an inkeeper. Ostendere, tendo, tesi, teso, to show, to tell,
to declare, to point at, to pronounce, to proclaim. Ostentare, to boast, to
brag, to vaunt, to cr^k^, to show a thing for vaineglorie. Ostentatione, an
ostentation, a bragging, a vaunting, a boasting showing forth vainglory.
Ostentatore, a bragger, a vaunter, a brauer, a vaineglorious braggard. Ostenti,
foretokens or prodigies, all things coming against nature, or otherwise then
nature gives, monsters, wonders, strange things happening seldom, betokening
something to come. Ostentoso, that which makes or causes a monster or strange
sight. Osteria, an hostrie, a Tavern, an Inn, a victualling house. Ostia, the
host, a wafer-cake made for an host, a sacrifice. Also an entry or mouth of
a great river where it falls into the sea. Ostiario, a dore-keeper, a porter.
Also one that keeps the ostias in a church. Ostica, Ostiga, an oyster.
Ostigine, Ostiga, a kind of scab in sheep, lambs, goats, or kids, about their
mouths and lips, being deadly to them whilst they are sucklings. Ostinarsi,
to be obstinate, stubborn, stifnecked, or wilful, to take a resolute constant
resolution or determination, to persist in one sentence or purpose. Ostinato,
obstinate, stubborn, stifnecked, opinatiue, constant, invincible, fixed,
firmly, firm, certainly determined. Ostinatione, obstinacy, wilfulnes,
stubbornes, stifneckednes, self-will, constancy, stifnes in opinion.
Ostipante, a medicine that stops and shuts the mouths of the vessels of
the body, not suffering any thing to pass by euaporation or emptying.
Ostipare, to stop holes or chinkes. Also to lay the head aside upon ones
shoulder as one were musing. Ostracismo, a kind of banishment of the best men
in Athens, and was used not so much for punishment of any offense, but to
abate the immoderate power of noble men: it was for ten years space, and was
done by delivering of certain shells with the names of the condemned persons
written in them. Ostracia, or Ostracite, constancy, stifnes in opinion, or a
precious stone brittle like a shell, and somewhat like the Agathe. Ostreca,
Ostrega, an oyster. Ostregaro, an oyster seller, or dregger of oysters.
Ostrica, Ostriga, an oyster. Ostrigaro, as Ostregaro. Ostro, grain to dye
scarlet with. Also scarlet or stamell it self. Also the south wind, but
properly the liquor, juice and color of the fish, whereof is made the color
of purple, as violet, or scarlet. Ostrocismo, as Ostracismo. Ostrogarbino, a
southwest wind. Ostrosirocco, south and by west. Ostruso, hid, hard to find.
Ostruttione, an obstruction, or stopping. Ostrutto, stopped, shut up, very hard
to attain unto. Oti, the name of a bird. Otio, idleness, rest, leisure, time,
conucniencie of tim^, drousines, sl^th, vacation from business or labor, ease,
peace, quietness, vacant time from study or business, a light exercising of the
mind and body. Otioso, idle, drousie, sluggish, lazy, lither, sure,
careless, quiet, restfull, at ease, at rest, without trouble or business, at
leisure, unoccupied. Otonna, a kind of herb. Otorno, as Oresta. Otriare, to
grant, or yield unto. Otro, a jar, or borracho of leather to carry wine in,
an earthen pot. Otroiare, as Otriare. Otrabile, that may be, or is to be
desired or wished for. Ottacatotta, by and by, even now, at this instant.
Ottagonale, having eight angles, eight cornered. Ottalmia, an inflammation of
the uttermost skin of the eyes. Ottalmo, a kind of blue precious stone.
Ottangolo, eight cornered. Ottanta, the number of eighty, or sour skore.
Ottantesimo, the eightieth in order. Ottare, to wish, to desire and pray, to
covet, to have leauer or rather. Ottatiuo, the wishing or optatiue mood.
Ottato, wished, coucted, desired, or longed for. Ottauario, pertaining to the
number of eight. Ottauo, the eight in order, an eight in music. Ottenebrare,
to darken, to obscure, to ouercloude. Ottenebre, dark, obscure, ouerclouded.
Ottenere, tengo, tenni, tenuto, to obtain, to get, to acquire, to atchieue.
Ottenitore, an obtainer, a getter, an atchieuer, an acquirer. Ottentatore, an
attempter, an assayer. Ottestare, humbly to beseech, to desire for gods sake,
or for the love of any dear thing. Ottestatione, an humble desiring, a taking
of God or some other thing to witness for a thing. Ottica, the science whereby
the reason of sight is known. Ottici, Ottico, pertaining to the sight. Ottici
nerui, the sinews which bring the virtue of seeing unto the eyes. Ottimati,
the chief persons among the people, by whom the rest be governed in a common
weal, noblemen, aldermen, or such great and principal men in any state.
Ottimato, excellent, chief, high, of the chief magistrate, an Alderman. Also
the estate or condition of head men of a town or country. Ottimo, excellent,
exquisit, or perfect good, best of all, very good or best, right good and
honest, most blessed. Otto, the number of eight, an eight upon the cards, used
also for Ottone. Ottobre, the month of October. Otto cento, eight hundredth.
Otto mila, eight thousand. Otto volte, eight times. Ottofero, a kind of
chariot with eight wheels. Ottonaio, Ottonaro, a worker in brass or copper, a
brasier. Ottonario, of eight, consisting of eight. Ottone, brass, latten, or
copper. Otturare, to stop, to shut up, to close up. Ottusare, to make dull,
dim, blunt, heavy or sluggish. Ottuso, dull, heavy, leadenwitted, sluggish,
blunt, dim, without spirit, weakened or decayed, in mathematikes it is the
property of an angle or corner, namely such a one as is bigger then a right
angle. Oua, eggs. Ouadelle, the seeds of silk worms, the hard row or eggs
or spawnes of fishes. Ouale, like an egg, ouall, more long then round, vide
Corona. Oua maritate, eggs in moon shine. Oua di pesce, the fry or spaune of
fishes. Ouatione, the season of laying of eggs Also a captains triumph or
victory. Ouato, as Ouale. Oue, whence, whereas, whither, when. Oueche,
whereas. Over, Ouero, or else, or, either. Oueramente, or else, either, or.
Oueriere, a workman, a worker. Ouiatura, as Ostacolo. Ouile, a sheepefold or
sheepecote, or poun, a sheep pen. Ouo, an egg. Ouo fresco, a new-laide egg.
Oura, as Opera. Ourare, as Operare. Ouriere, a worker or workman. Ouuiare, as
Ostare. Also to meet with one. Ouuiatione, as Ostacolo. Also a meeting.
Ouuiatore, a resister, a withstander. Also a meeter. Ouunque, wheresoever,
whethersoeuer. Ouunque che, wheresoever that, whethersoeuer that. Ozena, a
disease in the nose causing a stinking savor. Also a fish so called of his
strong and rank savor. Oxipori, a kind of piercing or penetrating medicine.

PAcchia, greedines or gluttony in eating, gormandizing, lauishnes, riot.
Pacchiare, to gorma^dize it, to riot, waste or lavish in feeding. Pacchiatore,
Pacchierotto, as Pacchione. Pacchione, a glutton, an epicure, a gormande, one
that makes his belly his god, an ale knight, a quaffer, a lavish, riotous,
wasting, lover of belly cheer. Pace, peace, rest, quietness, agreement,
accord, atonement, liberty. Also pardon and forgiveness, savor, permission or
leave. Also a voice commanding silence. Con vostra pace. Con pace vostra, Con
lice^tia, with your favor, by your good leave, saving your displeasure. Pace di
marcone, a peace, that concludes with an occupying. Paciente, as Patiente.
Pacientia, as Patientia. Pacificare, to appease, to pacify, to assuage, to
still, to quiet, to make peace. Pacificatione, a pacification, an appeasing, a
peacemaking, a quieting. Pacifico, peaceable, quiet, still, that makes or
treats of peace. Paciozza, a good feeding, nunchons, or meals meat, a
repast, a bait. Also a truce, or well meaning peace or agreement. Padella, a
frying pan. Padellata, a pan full of any thing. Padellina, Padelletta, a little
frying pan. Padiglione, a pauilion or tent for a field. Also a canapie or
sparuier for a bed. Padire, disco, dito, to digest, to brook ones meat, to
put over as a hawk does her feeding. Padimento, a digestion, brooking, or
putting over. Padre, a father, a sire. Padre di famiglia, a household father.
Padre e figliuolo, the name of an herb Padreggiare, as Patrizzare. Padregno, a
father in law. Padri, fathers, elders, forefathers, ancients, our ancestors.
Also the grave senators, aldermen, or borrough masters of a city or state,
governors, grave men. Padriciuoli, little fathers. Padrino, a judge or
stickler in any controversy. Also a god father. Padrocinio, patronage or
protection, safeguard, defense, maintenance, refuge in trouble of suite,
supportation, bearing out. Padrona, a mistres, a dame, an owner, a patroness,
a defendres. Padronare, as Padroneggiare. Padronato, the act of patronage or
protection, a patronage. Padrone, a master, a patron, a sir, an owner, a lord,
a possessour. Also an advocate, a proctor, a counselor, or one that speaks
for him that is accused, an attorney, a spokesman, he that in trouble or peril
defends. Also he that manumisseth and makes free a servant or bondsman.
Padrone di casa, the lord, the possessour, the master, the owner, or goodman of
the house. Padrone del tutto, lord, master, or owner of all. Padrone di naue,
the master or owner of a ship. Padroneggiare, to patronize, to protect. Also to
play the master, to defend them that be poor and falsely accused, to uphold,
to support, to bear out, to maintain ones right or quarrel, to back one.
Padronimico, derived of the fathers or ancestors name. Padule, a fennie
ground, a mere, a marrish soil, a moore. Paduloso, fennie, marrish, boggie.
Paesano, a countriman, a peasant, a clown, a swain, a hind. Also a man of
the same country. Paese, a country, a region, a province. Also the country.
Paffuto, pampred, well fed, in good liking, fattie fed, crammed. Paga, a pay,
wages, or hire for soldiers. Pagamento, a payment. Paga morta, a dead pay.
Paganalia, the wakes or ploughmans feasts, country hollie-daies, as weeks of
ploughmen, or sheepeshearing. Paganelle, a kind of fish. Paganesimo, as
Pagania. Also the profession of paganes or heathens, paganism. Pagania, the
country of painims, pagans, or heathens. Also paganism or heathenisme.
Paganina, a kind of dance used in Italy. Pagano, a pagan, a painim, an
infidel, a heathen. Pagare, to pay, to content, to satisfy, to please, to
apa^e, to reward. Pagare lo scotto, to pay the shot or reckoning. Pagare
contanti, to pay ready money, or to pay down right. Pagare la buona mano, to
pay or give a new years gift, or a drinking penny. Pagare la mancia, idem.
Pagare di posta, to pay at inposte or post as our gamesters use. Pagare di
moneta morta, to pay with words. Pagato, paid, contented, satisfied,
rewarded, pleased. Pagatore, a pai-maister, a paier, a p^rcer, a steward, a
treasurer. Paggio, a page or young squire, a benchman. Paggietto, a young page,
squire, or benchman. Pagina, a page or side of a leaf in a book. Also taken
for a writing. Paglia, straw, also hawme or litter. Pagliaccia, filthy broken
straw or litter, a pallet or straw-bed. Pagliaio, Pagliaro, a ricke or stacke
of straw. Also a straw-bed. Pagliarella, a small cottage made of straw, serne
or such like stuff. Pagliaresco, made of straw, strawish, as commonly our
mudwals be. Pagliariccio, a pallet of straw, a strawbed. Also old broken straw
or litter. Pagliato, pallet, pale or straw color. Pagliccio, of a straw
color. Also as Mondezza. Pagliola, Pagliuola, the lying in childebed of a

meat like a panado, or sops. Also whusht, close, squatting down. Pagnottina,
a little dainty panado. Pago, paid, pleased, apaid, contented, satisfied.
Also punished. Also a country town or village. Also a pay or paiement.

Paiula, as Paiuola. Pala, a fan, a winnow, a spade, a shoouell, a skoope, a

Also a fishing line. Palamento, any kind of fence or hedge made of poles or

garment. Palandrana, as Palandra. Palandrina, a common queen, a harlot, a

rolling piece of timber to lanche out ships from the docke or to remove timber
with. Palangario, an ale-stand-bearer, a porter that carries burdens with
slings. Palange, slings to carry burdens with between two, as brewers use.

field-fare. Palare, to cast with a shoouell, spade or scoope. Also to garnish
with stakes or with thick square lathes, to set up vines or hops with stakes,
to pale, to hedge in or underprop with stakes. Palascermo, as Paliscermo.
Palata, a shoouell, spade or scoopefull. Also a staking, empaling or

Paretara. Palatari, a disease in a horse. Palatina, the impostumation or

vuola or upper roof of the mouth. Palatore, a caster with a shoouell, spade or

or Princes court. also a Guild-hal, a seat of justice, a sessions house.

Palazzo reale, a Kings palace, mansion or court, a royal palace or house.

little sollar, floor, loft, tarras, stage or skaffold. Palco, an Elephants
trunk. Also a stage, a floor, a skaffold, a sollar or seeling. Palcone, a
great sollar, floor, loft, tarras, stage or skaffold. Palcora, the plural of
Palco. Pale, those parts of the back which stand out on the right and left
side. Pale del molino, the boordes of the mill-wheele which the water turns
about. Palegro, a beer to carry dead folks on to be buried. Paleneza, a kind
of little fish. Palengaro, a devise or basket made of osiers to catch fish
with. Paleo, a top or gigge that children use to play with. Also an Elephants
truncke or snout. Palesare, to reveal, to publish, to manifest, to bewraie.

barriers or other feats of bodily actiuitie, any thing or any place wherein a
man does chiefly exercise himself. Palestrade, iron hooks that be made fast

belonging. Also one that teaches or uses wrestling. Paletica, something about
a plough. Paletta, any kind of fire shoouell, slice, trowell, scoope or

maker. Pali, poles, stakes, piles, staves, perches, long rods. Paliare, to
cloak, to mantle, to cover, to shade, to hide, to shroude. Paliatiua, that may

Pallido, etc. Palificare, to make a foundation under water of piles, stakes,
poles or timber. Palificamento, Palificatione, Palificata, a foundation of
piles under water. Pa^lli, as Paliscelli. Palimbacchio, a foot consisting of
one long and two short syllables. Palingenesia, regeneration, new birth or
second nativity. Palinodia, a recantation or unsaying of that has been spoken
or written, a contrary song. Palio, a cloak, a roabe, a mantle, a long
garment, a cover, a vesture. also the prize, game or goal of any running,
race, wrestling, leaping or iusting. Also a race or running course for horses.

ship, pinace, boat, barge, gallie or foist, such as sea men triumph in.

Paliselli, small sticks as chandlers use to make candles with. Paliuro, ram of

to enmantle, to cloak, to enrobe, to shroude. Pallidetto, somewhat pale, wanne,
whitish, sallow colored, or bleake. Pallidezza, palenes, wanness, sallownes,
bleakenes. Pallidire, disco, dito, to be, to make or grow pale, wanne, sallow,
